questions.text: A 55-year-old male presented with verrucous carcinoma around the glans of the penis. Examination reveals that the inguinal lymph nodes are not enlarged. What is the appropriate management for this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Partial penectomy

Explanation:

  • Partial penectomy is the management of localised tumors on the glans penis.

Management of Penile carcinoma:

Cancer Type/Stage

Management

Localized Tumor - Glans Only

Partial penectomy

Distal Penile Involvement

Partial penectomy with 2cm margin

Proximal Penile Involvement

/Anaplastic Tumors

Total penectomy with perineal urethrostomy

Carcinoma in situ, T1 Lesions, Well-Differentiated Tumors in Young

Circumcision followed by curative radiotherapy

Inguinal Lymph Node Involvement

Bilateral ilioinguinal lymph node dissection

Advanced Disease - T2 or Poorly Differentiated Tumors

Prophylactic inguinal nodal dissection

Carcinoma in situ

Topical treatments (5-FU cream, imiquimod), Mohs surgery, laser therapy, or limited excision

Chemotherapy

Combination chemotherapy (5-FU, methotrexate, bleomycin, cisplatin, vincristine)

 

TNM staging of penile cancer AJCC 8th edition, 2018:

Stage

Description

TX

Primary tumours cannot be assessed

T0

No evidence of a primary tumour

Tis

Carcinoma in situ (Penile intraepithelial neoplasia, PeIN)

Ta

Noninvasive localised squamous cell carcinoma

T1

Tumor invades lamina propria, dermis, or connective tissue with/without lymphovascular or perineural invasion

  • T1a: without invasion/high grade
  • T1b: with invasion/high grade

T2

Tumor invades corpus spongiosum with or without urethral invasion

T3

Tumor invades corpora cavernosa with or without urethral invasion

T4

Tumor invades adjacent structures (e.g., prostate, scrotum, pubic bone)

cNX

Regional nodes cannot be assessed

cN0

No palpable or visible enlarged inguinal nodes

cN1

Palpable mobile unilateral inguinal lymph node

cN2

Palpable mobile unilateral ≥2 inguinal lymph nodes

cN3

Palpable fixed inguinal nodal mass or pelvic lymphadenopathy (unilateral or bilateral)

cM0

No distant metastases

cM1

Distant metastases

pM1

Distant metastasis microscopically confirmed

questions.text: Identify the marked region in the given spirometry.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Functional residual capacity

Explanation:

  • Spirometry measures airflow in and out of the lungs, which is useful in diagnosing and monitoring lung diseases.
  • The marked region in the given spirometry represents the Functional Residual Capacity (FRC).
  • FRC is the lung air volume after a normal, passive exhalation. It is calculated as the sum of the Expiratory Reserve Volume (ERV) and the Residual Volume (RV) and is around 2.3 L.

Lung Volume/Capacity

Description

Typical Volume (mL)

Formula

Tidal Volume (TV) (Option B ruled out)

Amount of air inhaled or exhaled during normal breath

500

-

Inspiratory Reserve Volume (IRV) (Option D ruled out)

Additional air that can be inhaled after a normal inhalation

3000

-

Expiratory Reserve Volume (ERV) (Option C ruled out)

Additional air that can be exhaled after a normal exhalation

1200

-

Residual Volume (RV)

Air remaining in the lungs after a maximal exhalation

1200

-

Anatomical Dead Space

Volume of air in conducting airways where no gas exchange occurs

150

-

Total Lung Capacity (TLC)

Maximum amount of air the lungs can hold

6000

TLC = TV + IRV + ERV + RV

Vital Capacity (VC)

Maximum air exhaled after a maximal inhalation

4800

VC = TV + IRV + ERV

Inspiratory Capacity (IC)

Maximum air inhaled after a normal exhalation

3500

IC = TV + IRV

Functional Residual Capacity (FRC) (Option A)

Air remaining in the lungs after a normal exhalation

2400

FRC = ERV + RV

questions.text: A man was brought to the emergency after suddenly becoming unconscious while working in the field. On examination, his temperature was 105 degrees fahrenheit and his skin turgor was decreased. Which of the following would not be seen in the patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Sweating

Explanation:

Physiological Changes in Heat Stroke

  • Heat stroke is a life-threatening condition marked by a core temperature >40°C, leading to CNS dysfunction and multi-organ failure.

Key Physiological Changes

  • Hyperthermia:
    • Core temperature rises above 40°C; cellular necrosis occurs at 49°C-50°C, red hot skin. (Option D ruled out)
  • CNS Dysfunction:
    • Symptoms: Confusion, agitation, seizures, coma.
    • Causes: Cerebral hypoperfusion, increased intracranial pressure, and systemic inflammation.
  • Cardiovascular Changes:
    • Tachycardia, hypotension, widened pulse pressure. (Option B ruled out)
    • Distributive shock due to vasodilation and vascular permeability.
  • Metabolic Disturbances:
    • Metabolic acidosis from anaerobic metabolism.
    • Electrolyte imbalances (hyperkalemia, hyponatremia).
  • Inflammatory Response:
    • Cytokine release (e.g., IL-6) causing endothelial damage, microthrombosis, and DIC.
  • Acute Kidney Injury (AKI):
    • Causes: Rhabdomyolysis, dehydration, reduced renal perfusion.
  • Respiratory Changes:
    • Tachypnea compensates for metabolic acidosis. (Option A ruled out)
    • Kussmaul breathing reflects severe acidosis, indicating critical metabolic derangement.

questions.text: Identify the procedure being performed in the image given below.

choices.text: Intraosseous route access for giving IV fluids

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Intraosseous route access for giving IV fluids

Explanation:

The image likely depicts a procedure for establishing an intraosseous route to administer IV fluids. This technique is commonly used when IV access is difficult or not possible. Intraosseous infusion (IO) involves injecting drugs, fluids, or blood products directly into the medullary cavity of the bone, providing a non-collapsible entry point into the systemic venous system.

  • IO route is an alternative to the IV route in the transfusion of fluids in shock.
  • The marrow of long bones has a rich network of vessels that drain into the central venous canal, emissary veins, and ultimately to central circulation. So, bone marrow functions as a non-collapsible venous access route.

 

Intraosseous cannulation:

  • Intraosseous cannulation is a widely accepted technique for both children and adults.
  • The EZ-IO® system is commonly used in the UK.
  • A hand-held electric drill is used to insert a cannula through the tibia or humeral head into the marrow cavity.
  • The response time for drug administration is similar to intravenous (IV) access.
  • Entire resuscitations, including anaesthetic drugs and fluids, can be performed through intraosseous cannulae.
  • Due to resistance to flow, fluids should be given as boluses using a 50 mL syringe.

questions.text: A diabetic patient presents with sudden-onset perineal pain. On examination, foul-smelling discharge and necrotic tissue, as seen in the image, are noted. Which of the following is true about the given condition?

choices.text: Anti-gas gangrene serum is indicated for all cases
Urinary diversion is the next step
A bilateral orchidectomy must be done

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Mixed aerobic and anaerobic infection

Explanation:

  • The clinical presentation suggests Fournier's gangrene, a severe soft tissue infection involving the perineum. This condition is typically caused by a mixed aerobic and anaerobic infection.
  • The most common aerobic microorganisms include Escherichia coli, Proteus, Staphylococcus, Klebsiella, and Streptococcus.
  • The predominant anaerobic microorganisms are Bacteroides, Clostridium, and Peptostreptococcus.

 

Fournier's Gangrene

Definition
  • Necrotizing infection of the soft tissues in the perineum, external genitalia, and perianal region, akin to necrotizing fasciitis.

Clinical Presentation
  • Symptoms: Intense pain in the genitalia, progressing through five phases:
    • Prodromal Phase: Fever and lethargy.
    • Early Pain Phase: Intense pain, possible edema, pruritus.
    • Progressive Phase: Increased pain and erythema.
    • Crepitation Phase: Dusky skin with subcutaneous crepitation.
    • Gangrene Phase: Gangrene with purulent discharge.
  • Pain may decrease as gangrene progresses.
  • Severity ranges from localized tenderness to septic shock.

Risk Factors
  • Peripheral vascular disease, diabetes mellitus, malnutrition, alcoholism, immunocompromised states.

Diagnosis
  • Clinical presentation supported by imaging or lab findings.

Management
  • Initial Treatment:
    • Fluid resuscitation.
    • Broad-spectrum antibiotics.
    • Surgical debridement of necrotic tissue.
  • Additional Measures:
    • Urinary and faecal diversion to prevent wound contamination.
    • Intensive monitoring for sepsis.
    • Wound review and vacuum-assisted dressing.
    • Skin grafting post-infection control.

questions.text: Identify the correctly matched pair of substances with their renal clearance from the graph below.

choices.text: A-Glucose, B-РАН, С- Bicarbonate and D - Inulin
A-Glucose, B- Bicarbonate, C- Inulin and D - PAH
A-PAH, B-Inulin, C- Glucose and D - Bicarbonate
A-Inulin, B- Glucose, C - Bicarbonate and D PAH

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) A-Glucose, B- Bicarbonate, C- Inulin and D - PAH

Explanation:

  • The given graph shows renal clearance of different substances.

Substance

Clearance

Key Feature

A (Glucose)

Zero

Fully reabsorbed in the proximal tubule; not excreted in urine.

B (Bicarbonate)

Less than GFR

Mostly reabsorbed by the kidneys, resulting in lower clearance than GFR.

C (Inulin)

Equal to GFR

Filtered but neither reabsorbed nor secreted; ideal for measuring GFR.

D (PAH)

Greater than GFR

Filtered and actively secreted; clearance exceeds GFR.

 

  • Clearance measures the volume of plasma completely cleared of a substance by the kidneys per minute (mL/min), reflecting renal excretory efficiency. It is essential for evaluating kidney function, including filtration, reabsorption, and secretion processes.

To calculate the clearance rate (Cs) of the substance, use the formula:

Clearance Formula: (Cs) = (Us x V) / Ps

Us: Urine concentration of the substance

V: Urine flow rate

Ps: Plasma concentration of the substance

Plugging in the values:

Cs = (10 ×2)/5  = 4 ml /min

So, the clearance rate of the substance is 4 mL/min.

Types of Clearance Measurements:

Inulin Clearance
  • Used to measure Glomerular Filtration Rate (GFR) as it is freely filtered but not reabsorbed or secreted.
  • Not ideal for routine use due to intravenous administration.

Creatinine Clearance
  • Estimates GFR using creatinine, which is primarily filtered by the glomeruli.
  • Slightly inaccurate due to tubular secretion, but practical for clinical settings.

PAH Clearance
  • Estimates Renal Plasma Flow (RPF).
  • PAH is cleared through both glomerular filtration and tubular secretion.
  • Correction for PAH extraction ratio improves accuracy.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common complication following ligation of the first vessel during abdominoperineal resection for rectal carcinoma?

choices.text: Parasympathetic - bladder dysfunction and retrograde ejaculation
Sympathetic - retrograde ejaculation and bladder dysfunction
Sympathetic - impotence and loss of cutaneous sensation in the perineal region

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Sympathetic - retrograde ejaculation and bladder dysfunction

Explanation:

  • The first vessel ligated during abdominoperineal resection is typically the inferior mesenteric artery (IMA). High ligation of the IMA can damage the superior hypogastric nerve, leading to sympathetic dysfunction. This dysfunction can result in complications such as retrograde ejaculation and bladder dysfunction due to disruption of the sympathetic nerve pathways that control these functions.

Abdominoperineal Resection (APR): APR, or the Miles procedure, is performed when the sphincters are infiltrated by tumour, requiring excision of the rectum, anus, and sphincter apparatus with a permanent colostomy. It's also used for elderly patients with distal rectal cancer and poor sphincter function.

  • Abdominal phase:
    • The IMA is divided.
    • The descending colon is mobilised and divided above the rectosigmoid junction.
    • The rectum is dissected to the levator ani, and a colostomy aperture is created.
  • Perineal phase:
    • A purse-string suture is placed around the anus, and an elliptical incision is made.
    • The anus, sphincter, and rectum are excised en bloc.
    • The specimen is removed, and the perineum is closed in layers.
  • The pelvic space can be filled with an omental pedicle or muscle flap if needed.
  • Wider excision may be performed to reduce the risk of recurrence (up to 33%).
  • Risks: APR has higher recurrence rates (up to 33%) due to specimen perforation and positive circumferential margins (up to 40%). A cylindrical resection helps avoid “coning” toward the rectum.
  • Complications:
    • Higher recurrence rates compared to low anterior resection
    • Anastomotic leaks/dehiscences
    • Necrosis of transposed colon
    • Bleeding
    • Strictures

questions.text: Which statement is accurate about the nerve action potential curve provided?

choices.text: The threshold point is at A
At point E, the nerve is more excitable
Point C to D is due to the opening of Na+ and closure of K+ channels
Point B to D is a refractory period

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Point B to D is a refractory period

Explanation:

  • The given graph represents an action potential curve of a nerve.
  • Point B to D represents the refractory period, a phase during which a second action potential is impossible or difficult to trigger. This period includes the absolute refractory period (impossible to trigger a second action potential) and the relative refractory period (a second action potential can be triggered but requires a stronger stimulus).

Phase

Membrane Potential

Na+ Channels

K+ Channels

Resting State- Point A (Option A ruled out)

Polarized (-70 mV)

Closed

Closed

Depolarization (Rising Phase)

Less negative, towards 0 mV

Rapidly opening, then inactivating

Slowly opens

Overshoot (Peak)

Briefly positive (+35 mV)

Inactivated

Open

Repolarization (Falling Phase)- Point C to D (Option C ruled out)

Returning to negative

Inactivated

Open

After-hyperpolarization

More negative

Closed

Slowly closing

Return to Resting State- Point E (Option B ruled out)

Returning to -70 mV

Closed

Closed

Propagation of Action Potential:

  • Mechanism: Action potentials travel along the nerve fiber without diminishing. Depolarization at one site causes local current flow that triggers action potentials in adjacent regions.
  • All-or-Nothing Principle: An action potential occurs only if the threshold is reached, maintaining consistent magnitude regardless of stimulus strength.

Refractory Periods: (Option D)

  • Absolute Refractory Period: Na+ channels are inactivated, preventing another action potential.
  • Relative Refractory Period: Requires a stronger stimulus to trigger another action potential due to partial repolarization.

Myelination and Saltatory Conduction: Myelin Sheath insulates nerve fibers, formed by Schwann cells. Action potentials "jump" between nodes of Ranvier, speeding up transmission and saving energy.

Energy Dependence: Na⁺-K⁺ Pump restores ionic gradients after an action potential, consuming ATP.

Factors Influencing Excitability:

  • Calcium Ions (Ca²⁺): Low extracellular Ca²⁺ increases excitability by lowering the activation threshold for Na⁺ channels; high Ca²⁺ decreases excitability.
  • Local Anesthetics: Block voltage-gated Na⁺ channels, reducing excitability and preventing action potentials.

questions.text: A 5-year-old child was brought with bony deformities, as shown in the radiograph below. These could be due to a deficiency of which of the following?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Vitamin D

Explanation:

X-ray shows bowed legs (Genu varum) in a 5-year old child, suggestive of Rickets owing to Vitamin D deficiency.

 

Description
  • Bone disorder characterized by failure of normal mineralisation

Etiology
  • Vitamin D deficiency: Decreased intake, malabsorption syndromes
  • Impaired Vitamin D metabolism: Hepatic and Renal causes
  • Defective Phosphates absorption:
    • Hypophosphataemic Rickets (X-linked dominant)
    • Fanconi syndrome
    • Renal tubular acidosis

Clinical features
  • Craniotabes: pin-pong ball sensation of skull bone
  • Rachitic rosary: Painless prominence of costochondral junctions
  • Harrison sulcus: horizontal depression on the lower part of chest
  • Pigeon chest: Prominent sternum
  • Deformities: Knock knees, bow legs
  • Muscular hypotonia
  • Delayed teeth eruption

Radiographic features
  • Delayed appearance of epiphysis
  • Widening of epiphyseal plates
  • Cupping of metaphysis
  • Splaying: irregular ends of metaphyseal plates
  • Refraction of diaphyseal cortex
  • Deformities: Genu varum, Genu valgum, Windswept deformity (Genu varum + valgum)

Treatment
  • Medical: Vitamin D supplementation 6 Lakh IU single dose followed by 400 IU daily.
  • Non-operative: Splints, orthopaedic shoes
  • Surgical: Corrective osteotomies > 6 months of age

 

Vitamin C deficiency (Scurvy) (Option D): Characterized by weakened connective tissue, poor wound healing and bleeding gums. Bony deformities are usually not associated with Scurvy.

questions.text: Identify the type of transport across the cell membrane given below.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Facilitated diffusion

Explanation:

  • The image represents facilitated diffusion, a passive transport that moves substances down their concentration gradient without using cellular energy but requires the assistance of specific carrier proteins embedded in the cell membrane.
  • This process is essential for transporting large or polar molecules that cannot cross the cell membrane's lipid bilayer by simple diffusion.

Types of diffusion:

Simple diffusion (Option A ruled out)

Facilitated diffusion (Option B)
  • Move from high to low solute concentration (downhill transport)
  • It does not require energy.
  • Not require carrier protein (channel protein may or may not be present)
  • No saturation: more concentration leads to a higher rate of transport.
  • Fick's law: Rate (J) = D.A.∆C/x
    • D: Diffusion constant.
    • A: Surface area of diffusion.
    • X: Thickness of the membrane.
    • ∆C: Concentration difference between membranes (most important determinant).
  • Movement of molecules across a membrane via carrier protein.
  • No expenditure of energy.
  • For example, glucose is transported by all types of GLUT.
  • Saturation is achieved after a certain point called the plateau.
  • The maximum transport rate occurs at the plateau or saturation point, called maximum (Tm).

Primary active transport (Option C): This active transport uses cellular energy (ATP) to transport substances against their concentration gradient. This process often involves specific carrier proteins, such as the Na+/K+ ATPase pump.

Secondary active transport (Option D): This type of active transport uses the energy stored in the form of ion concentration gradients, established by primary active transport, to drive the transport of other substances against their concentration gradient.

questions.text: A patient presents to the clinic with a lesion as shown in the image. He had a traumatic injury to the chest one year ago, and the scar has grown beyond the boundary of the initial injury. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Keloid

Explanation:

  • The lesion described is most consistent with a keloid that is characterised by the excessive growth of scar tissue beyond the boundaries of the original injury, and it often develops after trauma or surgery. They are known for being raised, thick, and sometimes itchy.

 

Hypertrophic scar: (Option B)

  • Confined to the original wound boundaries, unlike keloids that extend beyond the wound area.
  • Raised scar with excess collagen.
  • It grows rapidly and contains myofibroblasts.
  • It tends to regress over time (months) and recur less compared to keloid

 

Keloid:

  • Scar grows beyond the original wound boundaries and doesn’t regress.
  • More common among African Americans.
  • Develops after deep dermal injuries.

 

Hemangiomas (Option A) are benign tumours of blood vessels, usually present at birth or appearing in early childhood. They do not develop as a result of trauma.

Hypertrophic scar: Similar to a keloid, a hypertrophic scar is the result of an overactive healing process. However, unlike keloids, hypertrophic scars do not extend beyond the original wound boundaries.

Neurofibromas (Option D) are benign nerve sheath tumours, commonly associated with genetic conditions like neurofibromatosis rather than trauma.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents with right thigh pain after undergoing bilateral laparoscopic hernia repair for an inguinal hernia. Which nerve entrapment is most likely responsible for this symptom?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Lateral cutaneous nerve of thigh

Explanation:

  • The lateral cutaneous nerve of the thigh is commonly implicated in thigh pain following laparoscopic hernia repair. It can become entrapped during the surgical procedure, leading to meralgia paresthetica, a condition characterised by pain, tingling, or numbness along the outer thigh.
  • The most common nerve injured in:
    • Open repair: Ilio-inguinal (Option A) > Iliohypogastric (Option B) > Genital branch of GFN.
    • Laparoscopy: Lateral Cutaneous nerve of thigh > Genito-femoral nerve(GFN).
  • Landmarks in Laparoscopic Surgery:
    • Triangle of Doom: Injury to Iliac vessels
    • Triangle of Pain: Injury to Nerves causing postoperative pain

Triangle of Doom

Triangle of Pain

Boundaries:

  • Medial: Vas deferens
  • Lateral: Gonadal vessels
  • Base: Fold of peritoneum
  • Apex: Deep inguinal ring

Boundaries:

  • Medial: Gonadal vessels
  • Lateral: Fold of peritoneum
  • Superior: Iliopubic tract

Content:

Iliac vessels are located behind the peritoneal fold.

Content: (Medial to Lateral)

  • Femoral nerve
  • Femoral branch of the genitofemoral nerve
  • Anterior cutaneous nerve of the thigh
  • Lateral cutaneous nerve of the thigh

Clinical Significance:

Sharp dissection in this area risks damaging the iliac vessels, which can lead to severe bleeding and potentially life-threatening complications

Clinical Significance:

  • Potential risk of nerve damage if electrocautery is used.
  • The lateral cutaneous nerve of the thigh is the most commonly injured nerve.

 

Complications of Surgery:

  • Immediate Complications:
    • Bleeding/Hematoma: From subcutaneous or inferior epigastric vessels.
    • Urinary Retention: May require catheterisation.
    • Femoral Nerve Blockade (Option C)
  • Early Postoperative Issues (within the first week):
    • Pain, Bruising, Swelling: Common.
    • Seroma Formation: Often resolves spontaneously; may need aspiration.
    • Wound Infection: Less frequent; routine antibiotics not recommended.
    • Testicular Infarction: Damage to the testicular artery during dissection or repair.
  • Long-term Concerns:
    • Chronic Pain:
      • Nerve Injury: Damage to nerves such as the ilioinguinal or iliohypogastric nerves during surgery.
      • Nerve Irritation: Chronic irritation by suture material or mesh.
      • Psychological Factors
    • Hernia Recurrence: Inadequate repair or weakness in the abdominal wall; mesh-related issues may also contribute.

questions.text: A preterm baby who was delivered at 28 weeks developed respiratory distress syndrome. Which of the following is true about surface tension and compliance in this baby?

choices.text: Both surface tension and compliance decreased
Both surface tension and compliance increased

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Surface tension - increased; Compliance decreased

Explanation:

  • This statement is accurate regarding surface tension and compliance in a preterm baby with respiratory distress syndrome (RDS).
  • Elastic tissue recoil and surface tension are the two opposing forces to lung compliance and are not opposing forces to each other.

Two primary factors influence lung compliance:

  • Elastic forces of the lung tissue:
    • These forces are primarily determined by the presence of elastin and collagen fibers within the lung parenchyma (the functional tissue of the lungs).
    • In a deflated lung, these fibers are contracted and kinked. As the lung expands during inspiration, these fibers stretch and unkink, generating an elastic force that opposes further expansion.
  • Surface tension:
    • A thin layer of fluid lines the inside of the alveoli. At the air-fluid interface within the alveoli, surface tension arises from the stronger attraction between water molecules compared to the attraction between water molecules and air molecules.
    • This surface tension creates an inward pull, attempting to minimize the surface area of the fluid lining the alveoli. Consequently, this inward pull contributes to the elastic recoil of the lungs, making them tend to collapse

questions.text: What is the Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) score of a patient who was admitted to the emergency room after being involved in a road traffic accident and, on examination, opens his eyes in response to a painful stimulus, speaks inappropriately, and withdraws his limbs in response to a painful stimulus?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) E2V3M4

Explanation:

  • Eye-opening (E): The patient opens their eyes in response to a painful stimulus, which corresponds to E2 (eye-opening to pain).
  • Verbal response (V): The patient speaks inappropriately, corresponding to V3 (inappropriate words).
  • Motor response (M): The patient withdraws their limbs in response to a painful stimulus, which corresponds to M4 (withdraws to pain).

 

Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS):

Category

Response

Score

Eye Opening (E)

Spontaneous

4

To speech

3

To pain

2

None

1

Verbal Response (V)

Oriented

5

Confused conversation

4

Inappropriate words

3

Incomprehensible sounds

2

None

1

Motor Response (M)

Obeys commands

6

Localizes to pain

5

Withdraws from pain

4

Abnormal flexion (decorticate)

3

Abnormal extension (decerebrate)

2

No response

1

 

Head Injury Severity: Clinical Classification

Minor head injury

GCS 15 with no LOC (loss of consciousness)

Mild head injury

GCS 14 or 15 with LOC

Moderate head injury

GCS 9 - 13

Severe head injury

GCS 3 - 8

 

The GCS-P score is calculated by subtracting the Pupil Reactivity Score (PRS) from the Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) total score: GCS-P = GCS - PRS.

Pupils Unreactive to Light

Pupil Reactivity Score

Both Pupils

2

One Pupil

1

Neither Pupil

0
  • GCS-P score can range from 1 to 15
  • GCS-P score values between one and 8 denote a severe injury

questions.text: A patient presents with fever, abdominal pain, and jaundice. Investigations show the given findings. Which of the following statements is true regarding this condition?

choices.text: Angioembolization is the treatment of choice
Echinococcus species is involved in etiology

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Echinococcus species is involved in etiology

Explanation:

  • The patient's symptoms of fever, abdominal pain, and jaundice, along with the provided findings of a serpentine linear membrane (a wavy membrane within the cyst), suggest a diagnosis of hydatid disease or echinococcosis. This condition is caused by infection with the Echinococcus species of tapeworm, typically transmitted through contact with dogs or livestock.

Hydatid disease:

  • Caused by Echinococcus granulosus (dog tapeworm).
  • Humans are intermediate hosts, infected through oral ingestion of eggs from dogs.
  • Clinical features:
    • Common organs affected: Liver (most common), lungs, brain.
    • Symptoms: Abdominal pain, jaundice, dysphagia, dyspnea, neurological signs (headache, ICP).
    • It can present after trauma or with anaphylactic shock.
  • Diagnosis:
    • Eosinophilia, positive serology (ELISA, immunoelectrophoresis).
    • Imaging: Ultrasound, CT, MRCP (for biliary involvement).
  • Treatment:
    • PAIR technique (Puncture, Aspiration, Injection, Reaspiration) after albendazole or praziquantel.
    • Radical pericystectomy or segmentectomy for hepatic cases.
    • Omentoplasty or laparoscopic marsupialization for cysts.
    • Scolicidal agents: Hypertonic saline, ethanol, or povidone-iodine used during surgery.
  • Laparoscopic marsupialization (deroofing) for cysts.
  • Cyst aspiration, followed by scolicidal agent application and sealing biliary communications.

 

Surgery is mandatory (Option A): While surgery is often an effective treatment for hydatid cysts, it is not always required. In some cases, non-surgical options such as antiparasitic medications or percutaneous drainage may be more suitable.

Fine-needle aspiration cytology is diagnostic (Option B): Fine-needle aspiration (FNA) is generally avoided in the diagnosis of echinococcosis due to the risk of triggering anaphylaxis and the potential to spread the infection.

Angioembolization is the treatment of choice (Option C): Angioembolization is not typically the first-line treatment for hydatid disease and is not commonly used as a primary approach.

questions.text: A patient came to the hospital after a road traffic accident. He had severe muscle injury, and his serum K+ level was found to be 6.5 mEq/L. What will happen to the resting membrane potential in this patient?

choices.text: First becomes more positive then negative

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Becomes more positive

Explanation:

  • In hyperkalemia, where serum potassium levels are higher than normal (as in this patient with muscle injury), the concentration gradient of potassium ions across the cell membrane changes.

RMP in hyperkalemia, hypokalemia and hypocalcemia

Condition

Hyperkalemia

Hypokalemia

RMP

Depolarized (Decreased RMP)

Hyperpolarized (Increased RMP)

Explanation
  • Increased extracellular potassium reduces the gradient for potassium to exit the cell, causing depolarization.
  • The resting membrane potential becomes less negative than the typical -70 mV. (Option C) (Options A & D ruled out)
  • In hypokalemia, cells lose more potassium ions due to leaky channels.
  • The loss of positive charge increases the negative charge within the cell, causing hyperpolarization. (Option B ruled out)

Effect on Neuron Excitability
  • Increased excitability can lead to spontaneous firing and even cell death.
  • Persistent depolarization inactivates voltage-gated sodium channels, preventing action potential generation.
  • Decreased excitability occurs as the membrane potential is further from the threshold for action potential.
  • Hypokalemia also inhibits the Na-K-ATPase pump.

Hypocalcemia:

  • When blood calcium is normal or high, calcium remains bound to the extracellular mouth of voltage-gated Na⁺ channels, stabilizing them.
  • Low blood Ca2+ (hypocalcemia) causes calcium to detach from the channel, leading to easier sodium entry. This detachment increases Na⁺ channel sensitivity, enhancing excitability and action potential generation.
  • Calcium and magnesium act as membrane stabilizers.
  • Hyperkalemia can eventually lead to increased activity of the Na+/K+-ATPase pump as a compensatory mechanism; this is not a direct or immediate effect on the RMP.

questions.text: A 55-year-old alcoholic patient presents with sudden and unintentional weight loss. Lab investigations revealed serum alkaline phosphatase (ALP) of 240 IU/L, alpha-fetoprotein (AFP) of 600 ng/ml, and normal serum AST and ALT levels. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Hepatocellular carcinoma

Explanation:

  • The patient's normal AST and ALT, along with the raised ALP, are consistent with cholestasis or hepatic malignancy.
  • Hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) is a primary liver cancer often seen in patients with chronic liver disease, including those with alcoholism. The elevated alpha-fetoprotein (AFP) is a marker commonly associated with HCC.

Hepatocellular carcinoma:

Tumor Markers:

  • Elevated Alpha-fetoprotein (AFP) levels above 20 ng/ml are observed in approximately 70% of cases of hepatocellular carcinoma.
  • An increase in PIVKA-II (Protein Induced by Vitamin K Absence or Antagonism-II) is also noted.

Diagnosis:

  • The initial diagnostic test for suspected Hepatocellular carcinoma is an ultrasound (USG).
  • The preferred method for definitive diagnosis of HCC is a Triple Phase CT scan, which highlights arterial hypervascularization and venous washout.
  • A triple-phase CT scan has the following phases:
    • Arterial Phase - HCC shows hyperenhancement due to its arterial blood supply.
    • Portal Venous Phase - HCC may appear isodense or hypodense as it becomes less conspicuous compared to the surrounding liver tissue.
    • Delayed Phase - HCC exhibits washout, a characteristic feature - appearing hypodense relative to the liver parenchyma.

Quadriphasic images of the enhancement features in a typical large HCC (arrows) demonstrating hypo-attenuation on non-contrast (NC)-enhanced phase, mosaic hyperenhancement on arterial phase (AP) and washout on portal venous phase (PVP) and delayed phase (DP)

 

  • For screening individuals at high risk, the recommended test is an ultrasound (USG)

 

Risk factors for HCC:

Cirrhosis

Metabolic disorders

Environmental factors
  • HBV infection
  • HCV infection
  • Alcohol
  • NAFLD
  • Primary biliary cirrhosis
  • Chronic active hepatitis
  • Hemochromatosis
  • Wilson's Disease
  • Glycogen Storage Disorder
  • α1AT-deficiency
  • Porphyria cutanea tarda
  • Citrullinemia
  • Orotic aciduria
  • Alagille's syndrome
  • Cigarette Smoking
  • Anabolic steroids
  • Aflatoxin
  • Thorotrast

questions.text: Which of the following zymogens requires gamma-glutamyl carboxylase?

choices.text: Factors II, VII, IX, and X

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Factors II, VII, IX, and X

Explanation:

  • Gamma-glutamyl carboxylase is an enzyme located in the rough endoplasmic reticulum that modifies glutamate residues in vitamin K-dependent proteins, converting them to gamma-carboxyglutamate.
  • This modification is essential for their biological activity. Vitamin K acts as a co-substrate along with carbon dioxide and oxygen.
  • Factors II (Prothrombin), VII (Stable factor), IX (Christmas factor), X (Stuart-Prower factor), and Protein C depend on vitamin K for synthesis in the liver.
  • Proteins modified by this enzyme are involved in blood coagulation, inflammation, and vascular health.

 

Factors VIII, XI are not Vit K dependent. (Option A, C, D ruled out)

questions.text: A patient presents with features of chronic pancreatitis, including recurrent attacks, and has a 10 mm dilatation of the pancreatic duct with intraductal calculi present. Which of the following is the surgery of choice?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Longitudinal pancreaticojejunostomy

Explanation:

  • In chronic pancreatitis with dilated pancreatic ducts and intraductal stones, a longitudinal pancreaticojejunostomy is commonly performed to relieve obstruction and drain the pancreatic duct. This procedure is effective in managing pain and improving pancreatic function.

Treatment of Chronic Pancreatitis:

Medical Management: Most patients with chronic pancreatitis can be managed with medical measures. There is no single therapeutic agent proven to relieve all symptoms. The primary goals are to manage pain, prevent complications, and address nutritional issues. Medical approaches include:

  • Treating the Addiction
  • Pain relief
  • Nutritional Support and Pharmacological Measures:
    • Diet: Low in fat, high in protein and carbohydrates.
    • Pancreatic Enzyme Supplementation with meals to aid digestion.
    • Micronutrient Therapy: Correct malabsorption of fat-soluble vitamins (A, D, E, and K) and vitamin B12, and provide supplements like methionine, vitamins C and E, and selenium, which may reduce pain and slow disease progression.
    • Reducing gastric secretions may help some patients.
    • Diabetes Management may be required if pancreatic damage leads to endocrine dysfunction.

Surgical interventions:

  • Pancreatic Sphincterotomy: May benefit patients with papillary stenosis or elevated pancreatic ductal pressure.
  • Stent Placement: For patients with dominant pancreatic duct strictures and upstream dilatation. Stents should be removed after 4-6 weeks to prevent blockage.
  • Pancreaticoduodenectomy or Beger Procedure (duodenum-preserving pancreatic head resection) is recommended for mass lesions in the pancreatic head.
  • Longitudinal Pancreatojejunostomy or Frey Procedure: For markedly dilated ducts to provide pain relief, especially in cases where the disease affects the pancreatic duct.
  • Distal Pancreatectomy: May be curative in patients with disease limited to the tail of the pancreas.
  • Total Pancreatectomy: For intractable pain and diffuse disease, though it significantly impacts pancreatic function and quality of life. The pain relief success rate is approximately 33%, with a high risk of mortality and complications.

 

Pancreaticoduodenectomy (Option A) is a major surgical procedure, also known as the Whipple procedure, typically reserved for pancreatic head tumours. It is not usually the first-line treatment for chronic pancreatitis with intraductal calculi.

ERCP and Sphincterotomy (Option C): This endoscopic procedure is effective in treating certain cases of chronic pancreatitis, especially when there is a dominant stricture or obstruction in the pancreatic duct. However, when there is significant ductal dilation and the presence of large stones, surgical options tend to be more effective than endoscopic treatment.

Coring of Pancreas Head (Frey’s Procedure) (Option D): This procedure, commonly used in patients with chronic pancreatitis affecting the head of the pancreas, involves the removal of the diseased tissue. It is not the first-choice intervention in cases with a markedly dilated duct and intraductal calculi.

questions.text: A patient presented with diarrhea, dermatitis, and dementia. Which of the following vitamin deficiencies would you suspect in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Vitamin B3 deficiency

Explanation:

  • The above scenario is a case of Pellagra due to Vitamin B3 deficiency.

Pellagra is characterized by the classic triad of symptoms:

  • Dermatitis
    • Bright red erythema- in sun-exposed areas (face, ankles, feet)
    • Casal’s necklace- ↑pigmentation around the neck
  • Diarrhoea, and
  • Dementia.

 

 

Causes of pellagra :

  • Dietary Deficiency- Maize and Sorghum based diet
  • Impaired Tryptophan Metabolism
    • Factors Affecting Tryptophan to Niacin Conversion:
      • Vitamin B6 Deficiency
      • Medications: Isoniazid (INH), OCPs
      • Hormonal Influences: Estrogen metabolites hinder tryptophan metabolism.
      • Genetic Disorders: Inherited conditions like Hartnup disease can impede tryptophan absorption in the intestines and reabsorption in the kidneys
  • Carcinoid Syndrome
  • Other Contributing Factors:
    • Alcoholism: Interferes with nutrient absorption, including niacin and tryptophan.
    • Malabsorption Syndromes

 

Vitamin B1 deficiency (Option B): Thiamine (vitamin B1) deficiency causes

  • Wet beriberi- pedal edema and cardiomegaly;
  • Dry Beriberi- CNS manifestations such as peripheral neuritis, sensory disturbances, difficulty walking, and paralysis due to CNS manifestations;
  • Lactic acidosis
  • Maple Syrup urine disease- Accumulation of branched-chain keto acids leads to convulsions, severe mental retardation, vomiting, acidosis, coma, and death.

 

Vitamin B6 deficiency (Option C): Pyridoxine (vitamin B6) deficiency can cause cheilosis and glossitis but is not associated with specific combination of dermatitis, diarrhoea, and cognitive disturbances seen in this case.

Vitamin B12 deficiency (Option D) can lead to symptoms such as fatigue, neurological issues, and anemia. However, it is not typically associated with the specific combination of dermatitis, diarrhoea, and cognitive disturbances seen in this case.

questions.text: What findings would be observed in a patient who has suffered a cervical spine injury due to a road traffic accident, whereby the fracture fragment has penetrated the lateral aspect of the dorsal column tract?

choices.text: Absence of ipsilateral lower limb proprioception
Absence of fine motor movement of fingers
Absence of contralateral lower limb proprioception

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Absence of Ipsilateral arm Proprioception

Explanation:

  • The dorsal column tract of the spinal cord is responsible for proprioception, vibration sensation, and fine touch.

Pathway

Sensory Modalities

Dorsal Column-Medial Lemniscal System
  • Touch: Provides precise localization and fine gradations of intensity.
  • Vibration: Detects rapid changes in stimulus through phasic sensations.
  • Proprioception: Contributes to the sense of body position and movement.
  • Pressure: Allows for the perception of fine degrees of pressure intensity.

Dorsal column-medial lemniscal pathway:

Pathway

Sensory receptors → Spinal cord (dorsal roots) → Brain (somatosensory cortex)

Neurons

First-order neurons
  • Originate in mechanoreceptors, and enter spinal cord via dorsal roots
  • Pseudo-unipolar neurons with cell bodies in the dorsal root ganglion
  • Split into medial and lateral branches:
    • Medial branch: Travels up dorsal column to brain
    • Lateral branch: Synapses in dorsal horn, forming local reflexes, spinocerebellar tracts
  • Fibers from lower thoracic, sacral, and lumbar regions (T7-T12, L, S) ascend to medulla without synapsing, forming the fasciculus gracilis
  • Fibers from cervical and upper thoracic regions (C, T1-T6) ascend to medulla without synapsing, forming the fasciculus cuneatus (Option C)

Second-order neurons
  • Synapse in dorsal medulla (cuneate nucleus for upper body, gracile nucleus for lower body)
  • Cross to opposite brain stem side, travel to thalamus (medial lemniscus)

Third-order neurons
  • Synapse in thalamus (ventrobasal complex)
  • Project to somatosensory cortex (postcentral gyrus, lateral parietal cortex)

questions.text: A young boy presents to the OPD with hypoglycemia and muscle cramps, on exertion or while playing. Then he becomes normal after resting for a while. These episodes are recurrent after a period of activity. He has decreased serum lactate and glucose levels. Which of the following diseases is he most likely to be suffering from?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) McArdle disease

Explanation:

  • McArdle's Disease or Glycogen Storage Disease Type V is caused by a deficiency in the enzyme muscle phosphorylase. This enzyme is essential for glycogen breakdown in muscle cells.
  • Patients with McArdle's disease typically present with exercise intolerance, muscle cramps, and myoglobinuria after strenuous activity.

 

Hers' Disease or Glycogen Storage Disease Type VI (Option B): It results from a deficiency in liver phosphorylase. While it does cause hepatomegaly and mild hypoglycemia, the symptoms are generally milder.

Cori Disease (Option C): This condition involves a deficiency in the debranching enzyme, leading to mild hypoglycemia, hepatomegaly seen at infancy, limit dextrin accumulation and muscle weakness.

Andersen disease (Option D): This condition involves a deficiency in the Glycogen branching enzyme, leading to hepatosplenomegaly and death before age 5 due to heart or liver failure

questions.text: A woman presents with a BIRADS-5 breast lesion. Which of the following is a good prognostic factor for this lesion?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) ER positive

Explanation:

  • A BIRADS-5 lesion is highly suspicious for malignancy, and the prognostic factors depend on tumour biology. ER, (Estrogen Receptor) positivity is associated with a better prognosis as it indicates that the tumor is likely to respond to hormonal therapy.

Disease factors that influence prognosis

Histologic Subtypes
  • Invasive Ductal Carcinoma (IDC): Prognosis varies by grade and molecular markers.
  • Invasive Lobular Carcinoma (ILC): Intermediate prognosis.
  • Tubular and Mucinous Carcinomas: Best prognosis.
  • Basal-like Breast Cancer: Aggressive, triple-negative, no targeted treatments.
  • Other Subtypes: Medullary, cribriform, papillary, adenoid cystic, and metaplastic carcinomas vary in prognosis.

Tumor Size & Lymph Node
  • Pathologic staging (tumour size, lymph nodes) guides prognosis and treatment.
  • Larger tumours and positive lymph nodes = worse prognosis.

Molecular Markers
  • Hormone Receptors (ER, PR):
  • ER-positive = better prognosis, responsive to endocrine therapy.
  • HER-2 Status: HER-2 positive = aggressive but treatable with targeted therapies.

Patient factors that influence prognosis

Age

Younger, particularly premenopausal women, may have higher local recurrence rates post-surgery, but radiation therapy can reduce this risk.

BRCA Mutation

(Option A)

Generally more aggressive and associated with poorer prognosis.

Family History

A strong family history may indicate inherited susceptibility and potentially a worse prognosis.

Prior Breast Cancer History

Previous breast cancer can negatively influence the prognosis of a new diagnosis.

Lifestyle Factors

Obesity and inactivity are linked to increased recurrence risk and may affect overall prognosis.

Treatment Adherence

Non-compliance can worsen prognosis.

 

p53 positive (Option B): Mutations in the p53 gene are commonly observed in various cancers, including breast cancer. p53 positivity generally indicates a more aggressive form of the disease, making it a poor prognostic factor.

High Ki-67 (Option D): Ki-67 is a protein expressed in proliferating cells. A high Ki-67 index suggests a rapid rate of cell division, which is typically associated with more aggressive tumours and, therefore, a worse prognosis.

questions.text: Identify the true statement regarding the segment marked in red on the myocardial action potential curve?

choices.text: Due to opening of Na+ and closure of fast K+ channels
Due to slow but prolonged opening of Ca2+ channels
Due to closure of Na+ and opening of slow K+ channels

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Due to slow but prolonged opening of Ca2+ channels

Explanation:

  • The red segment marked on the myocardial action potential curve represents phase 2, the plateau phase of the cardiac action potential. The  plateau phase  is due to a slower but prolonged opening of voltage-gated Ca2+ channels. The Ca2+ current is mostly due to opening of the slower L-type Ca2+ channels. 

 

Option (A ): Opening of Na+ and closure of K+ channels together  doesnot occur in Cardiac action potential.  Opening of Na+ channels alone occurs in phase 0.

Option (C) : closure of Na+ and opening of K+ channels occur in phase 1 - initial rapid repolarisation.

Phases

Opening and Closure of Channels

Phase 0- Depolarization

Opening of voltage-gated Na+ channels

Phase 1- Initial rapid repolarization

Closure of Na+ channels

Opening of K+ channel  (option C)

Phase 2- Plateau phase (Option B)

Slower but prolonged opening of L-type voltage-gated Ca2+ channels

K+ channel also remains open.

Phase 3- Late rapid repolarization

Closure of the Ca2+ channels

Slow, delayed increase of K+ efflux

Phase 4- Baseline

Resting Membrane Potential About −80 to −90 millivolts.

questions.text: A patient presents with a sudden onset of chest pain shooting to the neck and interscapular region. X-ray shows a widened mediastinum. Blood pressure is 110/90 mmHg in the right upper limb and 160/100 mmHg in the left upper limb. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Acute aortic dissection

Explanation:

  • Acute aortic dissection often presents with sudden, severe chest pain radiating to the neck and interscapular region. A widened mediastinum on X-ray is a classic sign. The significant difference in blood pressure between the right and left upper limbs suggests aortic dissection, as it can cause unequal blood flow due to dissection of the aortic wall.

Aortic Dissection: Occurs when a defect or a flap occurs in the aorta, resulting in blood tracking into aortic tissues, splitting the medial layer, and creating a false lumen.

 

Clinical features:

  • Sudden onset of severe, tearing chest, radiating to the interscapular region
  • Renal pain and renal failure
  • Paraplegia
  • Syncope
  • Weakness
  • Hypotension or shock

Investigations:

  • If the patient is stable, CT angiography is the standard investigation of choice.
  • In the case of unstable patients (SBP<100 mm of HG, HR>100 bpm), the preferred investigation of choice will be TEE (TransEsophageal Echocardiography)(Option C)
  • MRI can also be done if CT is unequivocal.
  • Chest x-ray reveals widening of mediastinum along with left-sided pleural effusion.

TEE of an aortic dissection within the descending part

DeBakey Classification

(Based on the pattern of dissection)

Type I

Both ascending and descending aorta are involved

Type II

Only the ascending aorta is involved

Type III

Only the descending aorta is involved

Stanford Classification

(Based on whether the ascending aorta is involved in aortic dissection)

Type A

 

Only the ascending aorta or both ascending and descending aorta is involved.

(It includes both Type I and Type II of DeBakey’s classification)

Type B

 

Only the descending aorta is involved.

(It includes Type III of DeBakey’s classification)

 

Acute coronary syndrome (Option A): This condition usually presents with central chest pain radiating to the left arm or jaw, often accompanied by sweating, nausea, and shortness of breath. The difference in blood pressure between the arms is not a characteristic feature of acute coronary syndrome.

Acute pulmonary embolism (Option B) typically presents with sudden onset dyspnea, chest pain, and possibly hemoptysis. While an ECG might show signs of right heart strain or sinus tachycardia, it does not cause a discrepancy in blood pressure between the limbs.

Esophageal rupture (Option D) often occurs after severe vomiting (e.g., Boerhaave's syndrome) and presents with severe chest pain. The X-ray would typically show mediastinal air rather than a widened mediastinum.

questions.text: What is the probable diagnosis for a 30-year-old male who has nonaxial proptosis in his left eye and a history of a road traffic accident 15 years ago, as suggested by the provided CT image?
questions.solution:
Correct Option: A) Frontal mucocele

  • A mucocele is a cyst-like structure that forms when the lining of a sinus cavity becomes inflamed or blocked.
  • When a mucocele forms in the frontal sinus, it can cause proptosis (bulging) of the eye.
  • This commonly occurs as a result of obstruction to the frontal ostium due to chronic disease of the frontal recess or due to postsurgical/ traumatic fibrosis causing blockage.
  • Symptoms of a frontal mucocele include:
    • Proptosis (bulging) of the eye
    • Headache or facial pain
    • Vision changes or double vision
    • Nasal congestion or discharge
    • Sinus pressure or pain
    • Swelling or tenderness in the forehead

Incorrect Options:

Frontal meningioma (Option B):

  • A meningioma is a tumor that arises from the lining of the brain or spinal cord.
  • When a meningioma forms in the front of the head, it can cause eye proptosis.
  • However, meningiomas are relatively uncommon in young adults, and a history of trauma may not be associated with developing a meningioma.

Juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma (Option C):

  • Juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma is a rare and benign tumor, typically in adolescent males.
  • It arises from the back of the nose or upper throat and can cause eye proptosis as it grows.
  • However, the history of trauma 15 years prior is not usually associated with developing a juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma.

Pseudotumor of the orbit (Option D):

  • Pseudotumor of orbit, also known as an idiopathic orbital inflammatory syndrome, is a condition in which the tissues around the eye become inflamed and swollen, causing eye proptosis.
  • The cause of the pseudotumor of the orbit is unknown, but it is thought to be related to an abnormal immune response.
  • While a history of trauma is not typically associated with developing pseudotumor of orbit, the condition can occur at any age.

questions.text: A patient arrives with pain in the right upper abdomen. One week ago, the patient experienced a bout of diarrhoea. Abdominal CT scan results indicate the presence of a liver abscess measuring approximately 25 cubic centimetres. What should be the subsequent course of action in treating this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Medical therapy

Explanation:

  • The initial treatment for a liver abscess typically involves medical therapy with broad-spectrum antibiotics. Percutaneous drainage or PAIR may be considered if the abscess does not improve with antibiotics or if it grows in size or becomes symptomatic. Surgery is reserved for more complicated or non-drainable abscesses.

Management of Hepatic Pyogenic Abscess:

Initial Management:

  • Broad-Spectrum Antibiotics:
    • Start immediately to control bacteremia and prevent complications.
    • Antibiotics should cover gram-negative, gram-positive, and anaerobic organisms (e.g., ampicillin, aminoglycoside, metronidazole).
    • Typically 2 weeks or more, depending on infection resolution and drainage success.
  • Drainage Techniques:
    • Percutaneous Drainage:
      • First-line treatment with success rates of 66% to 90%.
      • Advantages: Simpler, avoids general anaesthesia.
      • Contraindications: Ascites, coagulopathy, proximity to vital structures.
      • Percutaneous drainage should be attempted first, reserving surgery for failures.
    • Percutaneous Aspiration: Less effective than percutaneous catheter drainage but reasonable for initial treatment.
  • Surgical drainage: Reserved for cases where percutaneous drainage fails or when surgery is needed for underlying conditions (e.g., appendicitis).

Feature

Amebic Abscess

Pyogenic Abscess

Age

20–40 years

>50 years

Male-to-Female Ratio

≥10:1

1.5:1

Solitary vs Multiple

Solitary 80%

Solitary 50%

Location

Usually right liver

Usually right liver

Travel in Endemic Area

Yes

No

Diabetes

Uncommon (∼2%)

More common (∼27%)

Alcohol Use

Common

Common

Jaundice

Uncommon

Common

Elevated Bilirubin

Uncommon

Common

Elevated Alkaline Phosphatase

Common

Common

Positive Blood Culture

No

Common

Positive Amebic Serology

Yes

No

questions.text: A 50-year-old patient presents with confusion and ataxia following trauma one week ago. He has a history of alcohol dependence, with his last intake 2 weeks ago. A CT scan reveals the following findings. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Subdural hemorrhage

Explanation:

  • Given the clinical scenario and radiological findings showing a crescent-shaped blood collection that follows the brain's contours and crosses suture lines, the most probable diagnosis is Subdural Hematoma.

Features

Subdural Hematoma

Extradural Hematoma

(Option A)

Location

Between Dura and Arachnoid

Between Dura and Skull

CT Appearance
  • Crescent-shaped
  • Crosses suture lines
  • Biconvex or lens-shaped
  • Well-defined & Localized,
  • Won’t cross suture lines

Common Causes

Tearing of bridging veins, often due to blunt trauma / acceleration-deceleration injuries

Rupture of the middle meningeal artery or vein due to skull fracture or trauma

Onset

Develop over days to weeks; Acute SDH can occur rapidly

Usually develop rapidly

Management
  • Craniotomy / Craniectomy, if significant.
  • Conservative management for smaller, stable cases.
  • Burr hole drainage is preferred for significant chronic cases

Urgent surgical evacuation for significant or deteriorating cases.

 

 

Intra-parenchymal hemorrhage (Option C) is a type of hemorrhage that involves bleeding within the brain tissue itself and is typically associated with conditions like hypertension, cerebral amyloid angiopathy, or direct traumatic brain injury.

Subarachnoid Hemorrhage (Option D) typically causes sudden severe headache, often described as a "thunderclap," and is seen on CT as blood in the subarachnoid space, often with associated hydrocephalus. It does not usually present with the crescent-shaped lesions seen in SDH.

questions.text: A 55-year-old patient comes with hoarseness of voice and difficulty swallowing. The patient was diagnosed with laryngeal carcinoma, and surgical management was done. The post-operative image of the patient is given below. Which of the following surgery was done on this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Option: D) Total laryngectomy

  • A total laryngectomy is a surgical procedure in which the entire larynx is removed.
  • This procedure is typically performed in advanced laryngeal cancer cases that have not responded to other treatments, such as radiation therapy or chemotherapy.
  • During a total laryngectomy, the trachea is re-routed to the front of the neck to create an opening called a stoma, which serves as the new airway.
  • This procedure has significant implications for speech and swallowing, and patients typically require extensive rehabilitation to learn new communication and eating methods
  • Indications for total laryngectomy:
    1. T4a with thyroid cartilage invasion.
    2. Stage 3 and 4a who cannot tolerate chemotherapy.
    3. Stage 3 and 4 recurrent tumours
    4. Bilateral arytenoid involvement.

Incorrect Options:

Partial laryngectomy (Option A):

  • A partial laryngectomy is a surgical procedure in which only a part of the larynx is removed, leaving the rest of the organ intact.

Percutaneous tracheostomy (Option B):

  • Percutaneous tracheostomy is a minimally invasive procedure where a tube is inserted into the trachea via a small neck incision. It's commonly used for temporary or permanent airway support in conditions like obstructive sleep apnea or chronic respiratory failure, but it's not suitable for treating laryngeal cancer.

Standard tracheostomy (Option C):

  • A standard tracheostomy involves creating a neck incision to access the trachea, commonly used for temporary or permanent airway support in breathing difficulties. However, it's typically avoided in laryngeal cancer cases as it doesn't address the cancerous tissue in the larynx

questions.text: In which of the following nerve injuries is the instrument shown below used?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Radial nerve

Explanation:

Image displayed is Dynamic Cock-up wrist splint used in management of Radial nerve palsy causing Wrist drop.

 

 

Radial nerve management:

Type of Injury
  • Treatment

Open Injuries
  • Immediate exploration and nerve repair or grafting

Closed Injuries
  • Wait 12 weeks for recovery before exploring
  • Use EMG if no improvement; if denervation is detected, perform nerve exploration and repair or grafting

Fractures of Humerus
  • Assess for nerve injury on admission
  • If the injury appears post-manipulation or internal fixation, explore and repair or graft immediately

Recovery Management
  • Perform passive hand movements
  • Splint the wrist in extension-cock up splint:

Long-term Disability
  • Tendon transfers: pronator teres to short radial extensor, flexor carpi radialis or ulnaris to finger extensors, palmaris longus to thumb abductor

 

Incorrect options:

Median nerve (Option B): Median nerve injury can lead to Carpal tunnel syndrome. Rest + Analgesics are the preferred management.

Ulnar nerve (Option C): Knuckle bender splint is used in the management of ulnar nerve injury.

Volkmann's ischemic contracture (Option D): Volkman splint or Turn buckle splint is used in the management.

questions.text: A family consumes only polished rice. Which of the following combinations of vitamin deficiency and enzymatic defect will be present in this family?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Thiamine-transketolase

Explanation:

  • The Aleurone layer of cereals (food grains) is a rich source of thiamine. Therefore, whole wheat flour and unpolished hand-pound rice have better nutritive value than completely polished refined foods.
  • When the grains are polished, the aleurone layer is usually removed.

 

Biochemical parameters:

  • Thiamine deficiency affects the enzyme transketolase, which is involved in the pentose phosphate pathway.
    • Measuring transketolase activity in red blood cells is a specific test for thiamine deficiency and can confirm the diagnosis.
    • Erythrocyte transketolase activity is reduced; this is the earliest manifestation seen even before clinical disturbances.
  • Recommended Daily Allowance of Thiamine is 1–1.5 mg/day.

Riboflavin-glutathione reductase (Option A)

  • Riboflavin (vitamin B2) deficiency affects glutathione reductase, an enzyme involved in maintaining cellular redox balance by regenerating reduced glutathione.
  • Polished rice is not specifically deficient in riboflavin, so this combination is unlikely.

Thiamine-transaminase (Option C)

  • Transaminases (e.g., ALT, AST) are not thiamine-dependent enzymes; they require pyridoxal phosphate (vitamin B6) as a cofactor.

Riboflavin-transketolase (Option D)

  • Transketolase is dependent on thiamine, not riboflavin. Riboflavin deficiency primarily affects flavoprotein enzymes such as glutathione reductase or succinate dehydrogenase.

questions.text: During the examination of a female patient with hearing loss, it was observed that she had a negative Rinne test result at frequencies of 256 Hz and 512 Hz, but a positive Rinne test result at 1024 Hz. What would be the anticipated gap between air conduction and bone conduction in this case?
questions.solution:
Correct Option: B) 15-30 dB

Explanation:

Interpretation of Rinne Test Results:

  • Rinne negative at 256 Hz and 512 Hz:
    → Bone conduction (BC) > Air conduction (AC)
    → Suggests conductive hearing loss at lower frequencies.

  • Rinne positive at 1024 Hz:
    → AC > BC, which may occur if:

    • The conductive loss is mild at high frequencies, or

    • The air-bone gap is narrower at higher frequencies.

  • The negative Rinne at low frequencies indicates a significant air-bone gap (≥15 dB).

  • The positive Rinne at 1024 Hz suggests the gap is less than 15 dB or resolved.

  • Since Rinne becomes positive when the air-bone gap is less than ~15 dB, and is negative when the gap is more than ~15–20 dB, this pattern suggests:

An air-bone gap between 15–30 dB at lower frequencies.

 

Incorrect Options:

Options A, C and D are incorrect as explained above.

questions.text: The radiograph below depicts a patient who is experiencing persistent knee pain without any previous injury. Identify the specific condition displayed in the image?

choices.text: Bipartite patella, X-ray of the opposite knee
Fracture of the upper pole of the patella, Cylindrical cast

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Bipartite fracture patella, X-ray of the opposite knee

Explanation:

In the absence of trauma with the given x-ray appearance showing 2 divided patellar segments is suggestive of Bipartite patella and the most appropriate next step in management is to take X-ray of opposite knee.

Bipartite Patella:

 

Definition

A congenital condition where the patella (kneecap) is divided into two separate bone segments.

Etiology
  • Failure of ossification centers to fuse during development, resulting in separate bone fragments.
  • Occurs in approximately 1-2% of the population, often bilateral.

Anatomy

Typically involves the superolateral corner of the patella.

Types

Based on the location of the secondary ossification centre,

  • Type I: Inferior pole of patella.
  • Type II: Lateral margin.
  • Type III: Superolateral (most common).

Symptoms

Usually asymptomatic, but can cause anterior knee pain, especially after trauma or repetitive stress.

Diagnosis

X-ray: Shows the patella with a well-corticated fragment.

MRI: Useful for assessing associated soft tissue injury or bone edema if symptomatic.

Differential Diagnosis

Patellar fracture (differs by smooth, rounded edges in bipartite patella vs sharp edges in fractures).

Management
  • Asymptomatic: No treatment required.
  • Symptomatic: Rest, NSAIDs, physical therapy, or in severe cases, surgery (excision of fragment).

questions.text: Identify the structure marked by the yellow arrow in the image.
questions.solution:
Correct Option: A) Fossa of Rosenmuller

  • The structure marked in the image is the Fossa of Rosenmüller
  • The Fossa of Rosenmüller is a small indentation in the lateral wall of the nasopharynx located behind the posterior opening of the nasal cavity. In an image, it may appear as a small, rounded depression in the nasopharynx tissue on either side.

Incorrect Options:

Tubal Tonsil (Option B):

  • The Tubal Tonsil is a lymphoid tissue near the Eustachian tube’s opening. It is typically found in the superior aspect of the nasopharynx and may appear as a small, rounded tissue mass in an image.

Opening of Eustachian tube (Option C):

  • The opening of Eustachian tube is located in the lateral wall of the nasopharynx, near the posterior border of the nasal cavity. It may appear as a small, slit-like opening in an image.

Adenoids (Option D):

  • A rectangular mass of lymphatic tissue called the adenoids is present in the nasopharynx.
  • The adenoids on the nasopharynx's roof and back wall are midline structures.
  • They are a component of the Waldeyer ring, which also consists of the adenoids, palatine tonsils, and lingual tonsils. Beginning in the seventh month of pregnancy, they typically develop until they reach adulthood.

questions.text: Below is an image of angiotensin II synthesis and neprilysin action with two arrows at ACE and Neprilysin. Which drug acts on both enzymes?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer B - Omapatrilat

  • Omapatrilat is a dual inhibitor of Neprilysin and Angiotensin-Converting Enzyme (ACE), as mentioned above.
  • This dual inhibition leads to increased levels of bradykinin, a peptide that can cause vasodilation and increased vascular permeability.
  • The accumulation of bradykinin is associated with a higher risk of severe angioedema, which is a serious and potentially life-threatening side effect.

Omapatrilat

Mechanism

Uses

Primarily for the treatment of hypertension and heart failure.

Adverse Effects
  • Angioedema
  • Hypotension
  • Cough
  • Dizziness
  • Fatigue

Sacubitril (Option A) is ARNI (Angiotensin Receptor-Neprilysin Inhibitor) used in heart failure with reduced ejection fraction (HFrEF), having side effects such as hypotension, hyperkalemia, renal impairment, and angioedema.

Losartan (Option C) is an Angiotensin Receptor Blocker (ARB) that functions as a competitive antagonist and inverse agonist at AT1 receptors. Additionally, it has an antiplatelet effect by blocking thromboxane A2 receptors and demonstrates uricosuric properties, which could be advantageous for managing gout.

Nesiritide (Option D) is a recombinant human BNP (B-type Natriuretic Peptide), that acts by increasing the levels of cyclic GMP, promoting vasodilation and natriuresis. It does not act on RAAS or NEP pathways.

questions.text: In the orthopedics outpatient department, a female patient is presenting with difficulty sleeping at night due to experiencing numbness and tingling in the outer three digits of their hand. The symptoms improve when the patient hangs their arms from the bed. Which of the following choices accurately identifies the patient's condition and the test employed to evaluate it?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Carpal tunnel syndrome, Durkan's test

Explanation:

Tingling and numbness of fingers, with symptoms worsening at night is suggestive of Carpal tunnel syndrome (CTS). The most reliable clinical test to diagnose CTS is the Durkan test.

 

Carpal tunnel syndrome:

Definition
  • Compression of the median nerve as it passes through the carpal tunnel in the wrist

Symptoms
  • Numbness, tingling in thumb, index, and middle fingers
  • Pain in hand and wrist, Weakness in grip
  • Symptoms often worse at night and improve during the day.
  • Advanced cases may lead to hand weakness, clumsiness, and muscle atrophy.

Structures Affected
  • Median Nerve: Compressed within the carpal tunnel, leading to symptoms and signs.
  • Flexor Tendons: The nine flexor tendons passing through the carpal tunnel can become inflamed, further compressing the median nerve.

Structures Spared
  • Thenar Eminence: Sensory loss generally spares this area because its nerve (palmar sensory cutaneous nerve) bypasses the carpal tunnel.

Clinical Signs
  • Weakness: Notable weakness in thumb abduction and opposition.
  • Atrophy: Possible atrophy of the thenar eminence in advanced cases.
  • Sensory Loss: Loss typically affects the median nerve distribution (thumb, index, middle, and radial half of the fourth digit).

Causes
  • Idiopathic- commonest cause
  • Inflammatory causes- Rheumatoid arthritis, wrist osteoarthritis
  • Post-traumatic causes- Bone thickening after a Colles' fracture
  • Endocrine causes- Myxoedema, Acromegaly

Diagnostic Tests
  • Nerve Conduction Studies (NCS) - primary diagnostic test
  • Electromyography (EMG)
  • Phalen Test: Positive if pain/paresthesias arise during wrist flexion.
  • Tinel Test: Positive if tapping over the carpal tunnel elicits symptoms.
  • Durkan test: Direct compression on Median nerve for 30 seconds. More specific than the Phalen/Tinel test.

Treatment
  • Conservative: Wrist splinting, NSAIDs, activity modification
  • Corticosteroid injections
  • Surgical: Carpal tunnel release (for severe or refractory cases)

Guyon’s canal syndrome and Froment’s test (Option A):

  • Refers to involvement of the Ulnar side of the wrist leading to compression of Ulnar nerve.
  • Froment’s test: Used to test adductor pollicis muscle (supplied by Ulnar nerve).

questions.text: What do chaperones assist in?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Protein folding 

Explanation:

Chaperones are essential proteins that aid in the folding of nascent or denatured proteins into their correct three-dimensional conformations.

  • Prevent Misfolding: Chaperones prevent incorrect interactions between amino acid residues during protein synthesis or stress conditions (e.g., heat shock).
  • Assist Refolding: In cases where proteins lose their structure due to stress (like heat shock or chemical damage), chaperones help refold them.

Types of Chaperones:

  • Heat shock proteins (HSPs): Act during stress (e.g., Hsp70, Hsp90).
  • Chaperonins (e.g., GroEL-GroES complex): Create a safe environment for folding inside a barrel-like structure.
  • Energy Dependency: Many chaperones require ATP for their function, especially during binding and release cycles (e.g., Hsp70).

questions.text: A bronchial asthma patient on inhalational steroids with white patchy lesions on the tongue and buccal mucosa. Which of the following drugs can be used to treat this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer A) Clotrimazole

The condition characterized by patchy lesions on the tongue and buccal mucosa resulting from the use of inhaled steroids is oral thrush, which can be treated with Clotrimazole.

  • Clotrimazole is a topical antifungal medication (imidazole) that effectively penetrates the skin layers to treat superficial fungal infections.
  • Mechanism of action: Inhibit 14 alpha demethylase enzyme (CYP), which converts lanosterol into ergosterol cell membrane, hence decreasing cell membrane synthesis.
  • All azoles are metabolized by the CYP2C19 enzyme.
  • It is commonly used in the treatment of conditions such as oral thrush, tinea, and candidiasis.

Griseofulvin (Option B) acts by inhibiting microtubules within fungal cells, thereby disrupting mitosis. It is the drug of choice for superficial fungal infections, such as tinea. However, it can cause side effects, including headache, neuritis, hepatitis, photosensitivity, and a disulfiram-like reaction.

Terbinafine (Option C) is an allylamine antifungal that inhibits squalene epoxidase, reducing ergosterol synthesis and disrupting cell membrane integrity. It is the drug of choice for onychomycosis (fungal nail infections), tinea capitis (scalp ringworm), and extensive fungal lesions.

Flucytosine (Option D) acts as an inhibitor of thymidylate synthase and is a narrow-spectrum fungistatic agent effective against Cryptococcus neoformans and chromoblastomycosis.

questions.text: The instrument shown in the image is not used for which of the following?
questions.solution:
Correct Option: B) Upper airway examination

  • The image shown is tracheostomy tube, and it is not used for upper airway examination.
  • Uses of tracheostomy:
    • Airway toileting (Option A)
    • Prolonged mechanical ventilation (Option D)
    • Acute nasopharyngeal obstruction (Option C)
    • Securing airway in facial injuries

questions.text: Which of the following statements is not true regarding the provided medical condition?

choices.text: Repeated radical surgery every 24 hours may be required to adequately manage this condition
This is a case of Meleney's gangrene
The condition is caused by β-hemolytic streptococcus and may sometimes be polymicrobial
Hyperbaric oxygen has no role in the treatment of this condition.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Hyperbaric oxygen has no role in the treatment of this condition

Explanation:

  • The image shows Meleney’s gangrene. Hyperbaric oxygen is actually beneficial in the management of Meleney's gangrene, as it helps to improve oxygen delivery to tissues, inhibit bacterial growth, and promote wound healing.

Necrotizing Fasciitis and Related Conditions:

Meleney’s Synergistic Gangrene and Fournier’s Gangrene are variants of a similar disease process. Necrotising fasciitis is caused by a synergistic polymicrobial infection, most commonly involving Group A β-hemolytic Streptococcus combined with other bacteria such as Staphylococcus, Escherichia coli, Pseudomonas, Proteus, Bacteroides, or Clostridium.

  • 80% of cases are linked to a history of previous trauma or infection.
  • Common locations: Lower extremities in over 60% of cases.
  • Predisposing conditions include:
    • Diabetes mellitus
    • Smoking
    • Penetrating trauma (e.g., bites, abrasions)
    • Pressure sores
    • Immunosuppression
    • Intravenous drug abuse
    • Perineal infections (e.g., perianal abscess, Bartholin’s cyst)
    • Skin infections (e.g., boils)
  • Clinical features:
    • Early signs:
      • Oedema extending beyond visible erythema
      • "Woody" or hard texture in subcutaneous tissues
      • Difficulty distinguishing fascial planes and muscles on palpation
      • Disproportionate pain compared to the affected area
      • Skin vesicles and soft-tissue crepitus
    • Absence of lymphangitis is typical.
    • Progression: Rapid onset of fever, tachycardia, and rapid progression to septic shock.
    • Radiological findings: Air in the tissues may be visible on radiographs, although urgent treatment should not be delayed for imaging.
  • Immediate management:
    • Fluid resuscitation and monitoring of hemodynamic status.
    • Administration of high-dose intravenous broad-spectrum antibiotics.
  • Surgical management:
    • Urgent debridement of necrotic tissue until healthy, viable tissue is reached.
    • The use of vacuum-assisted dressings is recommended.
  • Additional management:
    • Early skin grafting may reduce protein and fluid loss in selected cases.
    • Hyperbaric oxygen therapy after debridement can be beneficial if available.
  • Prognosis:
    • Mortality rate: 30–50%, even with prompt surgical intervention.

questions.text: A 4-year-old child presents with easy fatiguability. The mother also complains that the child has increased hunger between meals, which is relieved after food. Liver examination revealed no glycogen. The enzyme most likely deficient is
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Glycogen synthase

Explanation:

  • Easy fatigability: Indicates impaired energy storage or mobilization.
  • Increased hunger relieved by food: Suggests inability to maintain blood glucose levels between meals.
  • Absence of glycogen in the liver: Points to a defect in glycogen synthesis, specifically in glycogen synthase, the key enzyme responsible for glycogen formation.
  • Deficiency leads to glycogen storage disease type 0 (GSD 0).

 

Glycogen storage disease type 0 (0a and 0b)

Enzyme Deficiency

Glycogen synthase

Affected Gene

GYS2 and GYS1

Clinical Features

Hypoglycemia, Hyperketonemia, early death

Mode of Inheritance

Autosomal recessive

Management

Supportive care: Frequent protein-rich meals and avoidance of fasting. Cornstarch may be given nighttime

questions.text: In a 10-year-old child with symptoms of throat pain, fever, and ear pain, the diagnosis is recurrent tonsillitis. Which specific nerve is associated with the ear pain in this patient?

choices.text: Tympanic branch of the glossopharyngeal nerve
Auricular branch of the vagus nerve

questions.solution:
Correct Option: A) Tympanic branch of the glossopharyngeal nerve

  • The glossopharyngeal nerve is provides sensory and motor innervation to the tongue, pharynx, and middle ear.
  • The tympanic branch of the glossopharyngeal nerve, also known as Jacobson's nerve, provides sensory innervation to the middle ear cavity and the eustachian tube.
  • In cases of middle ear infections or inflammation, such as those associated with tonsillitis, stimulation of this nerve can cause pain in the ear.

Incorrect Options:

Greater auricular nerve (Option B):

  • The greater auricular nerve is a sensory nerve that arises from the cervical plexus and provides innervation to the skin on the side of the head and neck, including the area around the ear. It is not typically involved in ear pain associated with tonsillitis.

Auriculotemporal nerve (Option C):

  • The auriculotemporal nerve is a branch of the trigeminal nerve and provides sensory innervation to the skin of the temporal region, including the area in front of the ear. It is not typically involved in ear pain associated with tonsillitis.

Auricular branch of the vagus nerve (Option D):

  • The auricular branch of the vagus nerve is a sensory nerve that arises from the vagus nerve and provides innervation to the skin of the ear canal and outer ear. However, it is not typically involved in ear pain associated with tonsillitis.

questions.text: A child was brought with pedal edema and cheilosis.Cardiomegaly was present. What is the vitamin deficiency associated with this clinical presentation?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Thiamine

Explanation:

  • Pedal edema and cardiomegaly: Indicate heart failure, commonly associated with wet beriberi, caused by thiamine (vitamin B1) deficiency.
