  • Cheilosis (cracking at the corners of the mouth): Can occur in various nutritional deficiencies, but in this case, the systemic symptoms point toward thiamine deficiency.

 

Conditions

Biochemical Role of Thiamine

Deficiency Manifestations

Dry Beriberi

 

Essential for carbohydrate metabolism and nerve function

CNS manifestations such as peripheral neuritis, sensory disturbances, difficulty walking, and paralysis due to CNS manifestations.

Wet Beriberi

Thiamine is necessary for the PDH complex and low activity causes Lactic acidosis. Lactic acidosis causes vasodilatation and hence cardiovascular manifestations.

Cardiovascular manifestations such as oedema, palpitations, breathlessness, and heart failure.

Maple Syrup Urine Disease

 

Cofactor for decarboxylation of branched-chain keto acids

Accumulation of branched-chain keto acids leads to convulsions, severe mental retardation, vomiting, acidosis, coma, and death.

Lactic Acidosis

 

Cofactor for pyruvate dehydrogenase, converting pyruvate to acetyl-CoA

Impaired conversion leads to increased lactate and pyruvate levels, causing lactic acidosis.

 

Riboflavin (Option A): Riboflavin (vitamin B2) deficiency causes cheilosis, glossitis, and angular stomatitis but does not lead to cardiomegaly or edema.

Pyridoxine (Option C): Pyridoxine (vitamin B6) deficiency can cause cheilosis and glossitis but is not associated with cardiac manifestations like cardiomegaly or edema.

Niacin (Option D): Niacin (vitamin B3) deficiency causes pellagra, characterized by the "3 Ds"—dermatitis, diarrhea, and dementia. Cardiomegaly and pedal edema are not features.

questions.text: What is the probable diagnosis for a child brought to the orthopedics OPD with a lower limb deformity and hyperpigmented skin lesions, based on the presented X-ray of her thigh?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Fibrous dysplasia

Explanation:

Lower limb deformity with x-ray showing ground glass lesion, ‘shepherd crook deformity’ with associated skin lesions is suggestive of Fibrous dysplasia.

Fibrous dysplasia:

Description
  • Non-inherited developmental disorder causing replacement of bone by fibrous tissue

Etiology
  • GNAS1 gene mutation (Chromosome 20)
  • Associated with McCune Albright syndrome - Polyostotic Fibrous Dysplasia

Clinical presentation
  • Usually presents in the 2nd decade
  • Progressive limb pain, swelling
  • Limb deformities with associated fractures
  • Skin lesions (seen with McCune Albright syndrome)

Radiography
  • X-ray: well defined expansile intramedullary lesions with ‘Ground glass’ appearance, ‘shepherd crook deformity’.
  • MRI: is done to know the full extent of the disease

Management
  • Medical: Bisphosphonates
  • Surgical: Deformity correction surgeries

questions.text: A chronic alcoholic patient is diagnosed with gouty arthritis. What biochemical changes will be seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Increased urate and lactate levels

Explanation:

  • Increased Uric Acid (Hyperuricemia):
    • Chronic alcohol consumption is a significant contributor to hyperuricemia, a condition characterized by elevated levels of uric acid in the blood. This occurs due to:
    • Increased turnover of purines from alcohol metabolism.
    • Decreased renal excretion of uric acid as lactate competes with uric acid for excretion through the kidneys.
    • These factors increase the likelihood of uric acid crystal deposition in joints, triggering gouty arthritis.
  • Increased Lactate Levels (Lactic Acidosis):
    • Alcohol metabolism, particularly through the enzyme alcohol dehydrogenase, generates an increased NADH/NAD+ ratio.
    • This shift favors the conversion of pyruvate to lactate, leading to lactic acidosis.
    • Elevated lactate levels further impair the kidney's ability to excrete uric acid, exacerbating hyperuricemia and contributing to gout attacks.

 

Decreased NADH/NAD+ ratio (Option A): Alcohol metabolism increases the NADH/NAD+ ratio, which indirectly contributes to lactate production and hyperuricemia.

Increased urea and urate levels (Option B): While urate levels increase, chronic alcohol use does not typically elevate urea levels unless there is concurrent kidney damage or protein metabolism disturbances.

Increased level of alkaline phosphatase (Option D): This is associated with conditions like bone or liver disease but is not a key feature of gouty arthritis linked to alcohol consumption.

questions.text: Drug contraindicated in asthma patients during the management of postpartum haemorrhage is
questions.solution:
Correct Answer A - Carboprost

Carboprost is contraindicated in women with asthma when treating postpartum hemorrhage.

  • A derivative of prostaglandin F2α and the correct dosage for managing PPH is 250 μg IM, repeated every 15-90 minutes, up to 8 doses.
  • Side effects: Diarrhea, hypertension, vomiting, fever, flushing, tachycardia
  • Contraindications: asthma, pulmonary hypertension, suspected amniotic fluid embolism, and certain renal, liver, and cardiac conditions.

Oxytocin (Option B) is a hormone secreted by the posterior pituitary alongside arginine vasopressin. It is the drug of choice for managing postpartum hemorrhage.

Dinoprostone (Option C) is a prostaglandin E2 analogue (PGE2) and the drug of choice for cervical ripening (vaginal use). It is also utilized for labour induction and medical abortion.

Methyl ergometrine (Option D) is an ergot alkaloid that acts on the myometrium, inducing strong and frequent uterine contractions, which lead to uterine spasms. It is used in the management of postpartum hemorrhage.

questions.text: A child presents with erythematous scaly patches in the perioral region, mucosal ulcers, and impaired epithelial wound healing. The most likely mineral deficiency associated with this condition is
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Zinc deficiency

Explanation:

  • The above scenario is suggestive of Zinc deficiency.
  • Zinc Deficiency Manifestations:
    • Poor Wound Healing
    • Skin Lesions: Rashes, dermatitis, and hyperkeratosis.
    • Alopecia.
    • Impaired Spermatogenesis.
    • Immune Dysfunction: Decreased T and B lymphocyte counts; impaired macrophage function.
    • Neurological Effects: Depression, dementia, and other psychiatric disorders.
      • Zinc also forms plaques with amyloid in Alzheimer's disease.
    • Acrodermatitis Enteropathica: A genetic condition characterized by:
      • Inflammation around the mouth, nose, and fingers.
      • Diarrhea.
      • Hair loss.
      • Ophthalmoplegia and hypogonadism.

 

Iron deficiency (Option A): Iron deficiency typically causes symptoms like pallor, fatigue, and glossitis but does not result in scaly patches or impaired wound healing.

Calcium deficiency (Option C): Calcium deficiency primarily affects bone health, leading to rickets in children or osteomalacia in adults. Skin or mucosal symptoms are not characteristic.

Copper deficiency (Option D): Copper deficiency can cause anemia, neutropenia, and neurological deficits. It is associated with poor connective tissue integrity (e.g., kinky hair in Menkes disease) but does not cause scaly patches or mucosal ulcers.

questions.text: A patient presenting with bleeding gums and easy bruisability was diagnosed with scurvy. This is due to
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Defective collagen formation

Explanation:

  • Scurvy is caused by a deficiency of vitamin C, which is essential for the synthesis of collagen. Collagen is crucial for maintaining the structural integrity of blood vessels, skin, and connective tissues. Without adequate collagen, patients develop symptoms like bleeding gums, easy bruising, and poor wound healing.

 

Low calcium (Option A): Calcium is important for bone health and muscle function, but it does not directly cause the bleeding and bruising seen in scurvy.

Inhibition of clotting factors (Option C): While vitamin K deficiency can lead to clotting issues, scurvy is not related to clotting factor inhibition but rather to impaired collagen synthesis, affecting vascular integrity.

Increased keratinization of epithelium (Option D): Keratinization of epithelium is not a feature of scurvy.

questions.text: A patient presents with swelling in the groin region, diagnosed as a direct inguinal hernia. Weakness in which of the following structures is most likely to cause this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Conjoint tendon

Explanation:

  • The conjoint tendon, created by the union of the internal oblique and transversus abdominis muscles, forms the medial portion of the posterior wall of the inguinal canal and contributes to the posterior wall of the superficial inguinal ring. Weakness in this structure can result in a direct inguinal hernia.

 

Pectineal ligament (Option A): The pectineal ligament, though it contributes to the inguinal canal's floor, is not directly involved in the formation of a direct inguinal hernia. Its weakening alone does not typically cause this condition.

Reflected part of the inguinal ligament (Option C) helps form the inguinal canal's floor, but it is not the primary structure responsible for the weakness leading to a direct inguinal hernia. The weakness is mainly related to the conjoint tendon.

Lacunar ligament (Option D): The lacunar ligament, part of the inguinal ligament, contributes to the inguinal canal's floor but does not play a central role in the development of a direct inguinal hernia. The weakness of the conjoint tendon is the key factor here.

questions.text: A patient with a previous MI and ventricular arrhythmia is on treatment for a few months. He developed fatigue, dyspnea and weight gain. He had also developed pulmonary fibrosis. Which of the following drugs is responsible for this?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer A - Amiodarone

  • Amiodarone, a potassium channel blocker and class 3 anti-arrhythmic drug, is used to treat both atrial and ventricular fibrillation. It may cause side effects such as fatigue, dyspnea, weight gain, and, with prolonged use, pulmonary fibrosis.

Mechanism of Action
  • Prolonged action potential duration and QT interval by blocking delayed rectifier K+ channels.
  • Blocks inactivated Na+ channels, with rapid channel recovery (Decrease phase 0 slope).
  • Partially inhibits myocardial Ca2+ channels, adding to its antiarrhythmic effects.

Adverse effects
  • Hypotension and Bradycardia (with i.v administration or after drug accumulation)
  • Photosensitivity: Skin pigmentation - Purple color (Purple man syndrome, smurf syndrome)
  • Corneal microdeposits: Reversible upon drug discontinuation.
  • Pulmonary alveolitis and fibrosis (On long-term use)
  • Peripheral neuropathy
  • Thyroid Dysfunction: Interfere with thyroid function as it acts as a source of iodine and can potentially lead to goitre, hypothyroidism (Wolf Chaikoff effect), or, in rare cases, hyperthyroidism (Jos-Basedow effect).

Drug Interactions
  • Inhibits CYP3A4, CYP2C9, and P-glycoprotein, leading to potential interactions with drugs metabolized by this system.
  • Increases plasma levels of digoxin and warfarin.
  • Additive AV block with beta-blockers or calcium channel blockers.

Atenolol (Option B) is a beta-blocker used for managing hypertension, stable heart failure, post-myocardial infarction (to prevent sudden cardiac death), and the prevention of left ventricular hypertrophy. Side effects include fatigue, reduced libido, cognitive issues, nightmares, bradycardia, hypotension, rebound hypertension, aggravated ischemia, angina, MI, and increased triglycerides/LDL.

Aspirin (Option C) is an antiplatelet medication that irreversibly inhibits COX-1, thereby preventing platelet aggregation. It is the drug of choice for myocardial infarction (MI), stroke, and Buerger's disease.

Spironolactone (Option D) is a potassium-sparing diuretic that either inhibits sodium channels in the distal nephron or blocks aldosterone receptors. It is used to treat heart failure and hyperaldosteronism. Side effects include hyperkalemia and gynecomastia.

questions.text: What could be the likely diagnosis based on the x-ray image of a 22-year-old female?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Giant cell tumor

Explanation:

Clinical scenario and x-ray showing eccentric expansile lytic lesion on epi-metaphyseal region is suggestive of Giant cell tumor/Osteoclastoma (GCT).

Osteoclastoma/ Giant Cell Tumor:

Description
  • Benign but locally aggressive tumor of bone.
  • It commonly arises from epiphysis.
  • MC Age: 20 and 45 years of age.
  • Females > males.

Sites affected
  • Distal femur > proximal tibia > distal radius > sacrum.

Malignancy
  • Malignant transformation in <1% of cases.
  • Lungs are the most common site for metastases.

Clinical features
  • Swelling, vague pain.
  • Pathological fracture.

Radiology
  • X-ray: Expansile eccentric lytic lesion on epiphysis

Management
  • Extended curettage with Bone grafting

Incorrect options:

Chondroblastoma (Option A):

  • Seen in 1st decade (before skeletal maturity)
  • X-ray: Expansile eccentric epiphyseal lesion
  • Biopsy: Chicken wire calcification is pathognomic

 

Osteochondroma (Option B):

  • The most common bone tumor (not a True bone tumor), usually presents as a painless lump.
  • Radiography shows sessile pedunculated cartilage tumor covered by a cartilage cap originating from the metaphysis.
  • Cartilage thickness > 2 cms is suggestive of malignancy.

 

Aneurysmal bone cyst (Option D):

  • Variant of Giant cell tumor, seen in paediatric age group
  • X-ray: Soap bubble appearance
  • Biopsy: Blood filled cystic spaces seen.

questions.text: A child before playing consumed fruit from the garden. After some time, he developed a high fever, confusion, photophobia, and was unable to urinate. What are the likely causative agent and the appropriate antidote used in this case of poisoning?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Datura, Physostigmine

Explanation

  • The patient's symptoms suggest anticholinergic toxicity, likely due to the ingestion of Datura seeds.
  • Physostigmine 1mg IV (hourly) is used as an antidote for datura poisoning.
  • Datura contains hyoscine (scopolamine), hyoscyamine and traces of atropine
  • Mechanism of Action: Initially, it stimulates the higher centers of the brain and then activates the motor centers. Later, it leads to depression of the vital centers in the medulla, resulting in paralysis.

Clinical features:

  • Dryness of mouth and throat
  • Dysphagia
  • Difficulty in talking
  • Hoarseness of voice
  • Flushed face
  • Pupil dilatation
  • Photophobia + Diplopia
  • Agitation and restlessness
  • Delirium
  • Urinary retention
  • Dry and hot skin
  • Exfoliation of skin may occur
  • Patients can end up in a coma, or death can occur due to respiratory paralysis.
  • Treatment
    • Gastrointestinal decontamination: Administer activated charcoal to absorb toxins. Use a cathartic if indicated.
    • Antidote: Administer Physostigmine 1-2 mg IV slowly, repeating as necessary based on symptom response.
    • Symptomatic treatment: Consider Pilocarpine 5 mg subcutaneously for severe anticholinergic effects.
    • Supportive care: Monitor vital signs and address any respiratory or cardiovascular issues.

Pralidoxime is an antidote for organophosphate poisoning (which inhibits acetylcholinesterase), but it is not effective in treating anticholinergic poisoning caused by Datura or yellow oleander. It works by reactivating acetylcholinesterase that has been inhibited by organophosphates. (Option A & C ruled out)

Yellow oleander poisoning is due to cardiac glycosides and can cause symptoms such as vomiting, arrhythmias, and confusion. The treatment for yellow oleander poisoning is Digoxin-specific antibody or anti-digoxin antibody therapy, or the use of potassium correction and Lidocaine for arrhythmias. (Option C & D ruled out)

questions.text: Which of the following is seen in low insulin:glucagon ratio?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Activation of hormone-sensitive lipase

Explanation:

Hormone-sensitive lipase (HSL) is activated in response to low insulin:glucagon ratio.

HSL breaks down stored triglycerides in adipose tissue into free fatty acids and glycerol, providing energy during fasting.

  • Insulin:Glucagon Bipolar Axis:
    • Insulin: Anabolic hormone promoting glycogenesis, lipogenesis, and protein synthesis.
    • Glucagon: Catabolic hormone stimulating glycogenolysis, gluconeogenesis, and lipolysis.
    • IGR:
      • High IGR → Anabolic state, reduced glucose production.
      • Low IGR → Catabolic state, increased glucose production.
  • Determinants of IGR:
    • Influenced by insulin and glucagon secretion patterns, dietary composition, and metabolic status.
    • Variability in systemic and portal concentrations complicates measurement accuracy.

Activation of lipoprotein lipase (Option A):

  • Lipoprotein lipase is activated by insulin, not glucagon.
  • It facilitates triglyceride uptake from circulating lipoproteins into adipose tissue for storage, which occurs in the fed state.

Activation of glycogen synthase (Option B): Glycogen synthase is activated by insulin, promoting glycogen synthesis in the liver and muscle during the fed state.

Activation of phosphofructokinase (Option C): Phosphofructokinase (PFK) is a key enzyme in glycolysis. It is activated by insulin and suppressed during fasting (low insulin:glucagon ratio), as glycolysis is reduced in favor of gluconeogenesis.

questions.text: The method of autopsy carried out en masse to remove from the tongue to the prostate is:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Letulle technique

Explanation

  • Letulle technique is named after Maurice Letulle which involves the removal of organs together in one mass from tongue to prostate

Methods of Autopsy

1. Virchow’s Method (M/C)

  • One-by-one organ removal. (Option A ruled out)
  • Fast and easy.
  • Typically used for general autopsies.

2. Ghon’s/en-Block Method

  • Targeted organ removal (Cervical, Thoracic, Abdominal, Pelvic blocks). (Option C ruled out)
  • Organ relations remain intact.
  • Thoracic block for chest-related issues, pelvic block for sexual assaults.
  • Useful when preserving inter-organ relationships.

3. Lettule’s/en-Masses/Evisceration (Option D)

  • Large masses of organs removed together (C+T+A+P).
  • Complete viscera removal.
  • Blood vessels and vascular supply intact.
  • Suitable for minor bleeding cases.

4. Rokitansky/In-situ Method (Option B ruled out)

  • Inside dissection.
  • Used in infectious diseases (HIV, Hepatitis, COVID-19).
  • Highly transmissible diseases.
  • Also used for infants <1 year to minimize contamination risk.

questions.text: A young female comes to the emergency department after consuming 100 aspirin tablets. What should be the next step in management?

choices.text: N-acetyl cysteine to replenish glutathione stores
Glucagon to control bradycardia and hypoglycemia
Give sodium bicarbonate to alkalize urine

questions.solution:
Correct Answer D - Give sodium bicarbonate to alkalize urine

The given scenario is a case of aspirin toxicity in which the primary treatment is to give sodium bicarbonate in order to alkalize the urine.

  • It is an antiplatelet medication that irreversibly inhibits COX-1, thereby preventing platelet aggregation.
  • Aspirin stimulates the brain's respiratory center, causing hyperventilation (↓CO2 levels) and respiratory alkalosis.
  • The kidneys excrete more bicarbonate to counteract respiratory alkalosis, resulting in metabolic acidosis (Compensatory metabolic acidosis). High doses of aspirin can disrupt oxidative phosphorylation and kidney function, exacerbating metabolic acidosis.

Dosage and Toxicity:

  • Therapeutic Dose: 3-5 g/day can cause mild chronic toxicity (salicylism).
  • Toxic Dose: Acute ingestion of 10-30 g in adults can be lethal, with much lower doses (4 mL of methyl salicylate) posing a significant risk in children

Clinical presentation:

  • Salicylism: Headache, dizziness, tinnitus, reversible hearing and vision impairment, drowsiness, vomiting, hyperventilation, electrolyte imbalance
  • Severe toxicity: Dehydration, high tone deafness, confusion, petechial haemorrhages, hyperpyrexia, seizures, hypoglycemia, psychosis, coma

Management:

  • Treatment is supportive and includes gastric lavage, correction of metabolic acidosis, vitamin K supplements and urinary alkalinization with intravenous sodium bicarbonate to enhance salicylate excretion. In severe cases, hemodialysis may be necessary.

N-acetyl cysteine to replenish glutathione stores (Option A) is not indicated in the management of aspirin overdose. It is used as an antidote for acetaminophen overdose, which can cause liver toxicity by depleting glutathione stores. Aspirin overdose does not cause glutathione depletion, so N-acetyl cysteine is not useful in this situation.

Pralidoxime (Option B) is not indicated in the management of aspirin overdose. Pralidosime is an antidote for organophosphate poisoning, which can cause cholinergic toxicity by inhibiting acetylcholinesterase activity. Aspirin overdose does not cause cholinergic toxicity, so this option is not used here.

Glucagon to control bradycardia and hypoglycemia (Option C): Glucagon is not indicated in the management of aspirin overdose. Glucagon is used as an antidote to beta-blocker toxicity

questions.text: A 42-year-old HIV-positive patient died, and his body was brought for post-mortem. The method of autopsy to be done is:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Rokitansky technique

Explanation:

Methods of Autopsy

1. Virchow’s Method (M/C)

  • One-by-one organ removal. (Option C ruled out)
  • Fast and easy.
  • Typically used for general autopsies.

2. Ghon’s/en-Block Method

  • Targeted organ removal (Cervical, Thoracic, Abdominal, Pelvic blocks). (Option A ruled out)
  • Organ relations remain intact.
  • Thoracic block for chest-related issues, pelvic block for sexual assaults.
  • Useful when preserving inter-organ relationships.

3. Lettule’s/en-Masses/Evisceration (Option B ruled out)

  • Large masses of organs removed together (C+T+A+P).
  • Complete viscera removal.
  • Blood vessels and vascular supply intact.
  • Suitable for minor bleeding cases.

4. Rokitansky/In-situ Method (Option D)

  • Inside dissection.
  • Used in infectious diseases (HIV, Hepatitis, COVID-19).
  • Highly transmissible diseases.
  • Also used for infants <1 year to minimize contamination risk.

questions.text: A construction worker presents to the OPD with complaints of white fingers. He has been working in the cement and concrete industry and has spent 20 years using heavy machinery drills and polishing wood and furniture. What is the most likely etiology for this condition?

choices.text: Candidal infection of the fingers due to continuous exposure to water
Continuous exposure to cement and concrete
Continuous exposure to drills and machines

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Continuous exposure to drills and machines

Explanation:

  • The patient's symptoms of white fingers are suggestive of the vibration-induced white finger (VWF) or hand-arm vibration syndrome (HAVS), a secondary form of Raynaud syndrome, which is caused by prolonged exposure to vibrating tools and machinery.
  • This condition leads to reduced blood flow and ischemia in the fingers, resulting in the characteristic whiteness of the fingers.

Raynaud’s Syndrome: Raynaud’s syndrome is the peripheral arterial manifestation of a collagen vascular disease, such as systemic lupus erythematosus or rheumatoid arthritis. It shares clinical features with Raynaud’s disease but is often more severe.

  • It can also occur due to vibrating tool use, a recognised industrial disease known as vibration white finger.
  • Clinical features:
    • The symptoms are similar to Raynaud’s disease but can be more aggressive.
    • In secondary Raynaud’s syndrome (due to collagen diseases), there may be necrosis of digits and multiple amputations.
  • Management:
    • Primary treatment focuses on addressing the underlying condition.
    • Conservative measures can be helpful, including:
      • Nifedipine
      • Steroids
      • Vasospastic antagonists
    • Sympathectomy generally provides poor outcomes and is not recommended.
  • Prevention: Patients with a vibrated white finger should avoid vibrating tools to prevent further damage.

questions.text: A 4-year-old child presents with a rectal polyp and painless rectal bleeding. Histopathological examination reveals enlarged and inflamed glands filled with mucin. The child is diagnosed with a juvenile rectal polyp. Which of the following best describes the polyp in this case?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Hamartoma

Explanation:

  • Juvenile rectal polyps are hamartomatous in nature, typically solitary but can sometimes appear in multiples.
  • These polyps are most commonly found in children under 5 years of age and usually present with rectal bleeding.
  • The condition is associated with mutations in SMAD 2, SMAD 4, and BMPR1A. Extra-intestinal features may include digital clubbing and vascular malformations.
  • The histological appearance of a juvenile rectal polyp is shown below:

 

 

Adenomas (Option A) are benign tumours that originate from glandular tissue. While adenomas can occur in the rectum, they are rare in children.

Choristoma (Option B) are ectopic tissues found in abnormal locations. They are rare in the rectum and are not typically associated with juvenile rectal polyps.

Carcinoma (Option D) refers to malignant tumours that arise from epithelial cells. It is highly unlikely for a 5-year-old child to develop carcinoma, making this an unlikely diagnosis in this case.

questions.text: Identify the given condition:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Trophic ulcer

Explanation:

  • Trophic ulcers, also called neuropathic ulcers, occur due to a loss of sensation and an impaired ability to protect the skin, often resulting from conditions like peripheral neuropathy or poor circulation. These ulcers usually have well-defined borders and a pale or pink wound bed, commonly located in weight-bearing areas where pressure or friction is frequent.

Type of Ulcer:

Type

History

Lesion Characteristics

Pain

Ischemic/Arterial

Smoking, intermittent claudication

Irregular edges, poor granulation tissue, dry necrotic base; round or punched-out with sharp demarcation

Severe, particularly at night; relieved by dependency

Venous

Varicose veins, DVT, trauma, surgery, multiple pregnancies

Shallow, irregular/shaggy shape, granulating base, fibrinous material with moderate to heavy exudate

Mild; relieved by elevation

Neurotrophic

Numbness, paresthesias, burning, loss of sensation in the foot, DM

Punched-out, deep sinus, variable depth, partial thickness to severe, involving the tendon, fascia, joint capsule, or bone

None

Malignant Ulcer

History of skin cancer (e.g., basal or squamous cell carcinoma)

Irregular, raised borders, ulcerating tumour with hard, indurated tissue

Often painful, it can be associated with bleeding or foul odour

questions.text: A 10-year-old male child came to the casualty with difficulty in walking and pain in the perianal region. On subjecting the specimen from the perianal region to a test, it produces yellow needle-shaped rhombic crystals with picric acid. What is the test done?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Barberio test

Explanation

  • The above scenario is suggestive of Barberio test, indicated by the presence of yellow needle-shaped crystals.
  • The Barberio test specifically detects Spermine, a compound derived from the prostate, and is used to identify seminal fluid.

Test Name

Substance Detected

Result

Reagent Used

Mnemonic

Notes

Barberio Test

(Option A)

Spermine

Yellow needle-shaped crystals of Spermine Picrate

Picric acid

Barbar picks your hair with a needle

Detects Spermine from the prostate; confirms the presence of seminal fluid.

Florence Test

(Option B ruled out)

Choline

Dark brown rhombic crystals of Choline iodide

KI (Potassium Iodide)

Florence has 'C', C for Choline

It detects choline from the seminal vesicle and is used to identify seminal fluid.

Teichmann test (Option C): This test detects hemoglobin or blood, not seminal fluid.


Acid phosphatase test (Option D): The Acid phosphatase test is used to detect the presence of prostatic fluid in sexual assault cases. It does not produce needle-shaped rhombic crystals with picric acid.

questions.text: A chronic smoker was taking nicotine therapy and clonidine tablets for smoking de-addiction. He stopped taking clonidine tablets and developed a headache. What is the reason behind this?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer C - Rebound hypertension

  • In the given scenario, the patient stopped taking clonidine tablets and now presents with a headache (a common symptom of rebound hypertension). Discontinuation of clonidine can cause rebound hypertension due to decreased alpha-2 adrenergic receptor activity, leading to increased sympathetic outflow and a subsequent rise in blood pressure.

Clonidine:

  • It is a centrally acting alpha-2 adrenergic receptor agonist commonly used to manage hypertension, opioid withdrawal, and smoking cessation.
  • When used for smoking cessation, it helps to reduce the withdrawal symptoms associated with nicotine addiction, such as cravings, anxiety, and irritability.
  • One of the side effects of clonidine therapy is rebound hypertension, which can occur when the drug is abruptly discontinued as alpha 1 receptors are upregulated.
  • Rebound hypertension is characterized by a sudden and significant increase in blood pressure, which can cause symptoms such as headache, dizziness, and confusion.

Postural hypotension (Option A) is characterized by a sudden drop in blood pressure upon standing up, which can cause dizziness and fainting. This is not the cause of the headache in this scenario, as per the patient’s symptoms.

Receptor downregulation (Option B) is a phenomenon in which the number of receptors on the cell surface decreases in response to an increase in the stimulation of receptors. This is not the cause of the headache in this scenario, as the upregulation of receptors leads to rebound hypertension.

Receptor hypersensitivity (Option D) is a condition in which the receptors on the cell surface become more sensitive to the ligand, which can result in an exaggerated response to the drug. This is not the cause of the headache in this scenario, as hypersensitivity of the receptors would not result in rebound hypertension or headache.

questions.text: A patient was brought to casualty with seizures. He had multiple episodes and was taking herbal medicines for the same. He was conscious in between the episodes. During the episodes, he had an arching of his back. What is the likely cause?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Strychnine

Explanation

  • Strychnine poisoning is characterized by seizures and muscle spasms, often causing arching of the back (opisthotonus).
  • The patient is typically conscious between episodes, and the seizures are triggered by minimal stimuli.
  • Strychnine is a potent neurotoxin that acts by blocking inhibitory neurotransmission, leading to overstimulation of the central nervous system.

Source

Seeds of Strychnos nux-vomica and other species of Strychnos plants found in India.

Mechanism of action

  • Stimulates all parts of the central nervous system, especially the anterior horn cells. Greatly increases reflex excitability by removing normal inhibition of motor cell stimulation, causing widespread uncontrolled motor activity of the spinal cord.
  • Slight stimuli like noise, light, or a breeze can cause violent generalized muscle spasms

Clinical Features
  • Opisthotonos- arched body with only the back of head and heels touching the ground:
  • Emprosthotonos- forward curve
  • Pleurothotonus- sideways curve
  • Risus sardonicus- fixed grin:

Treatment
  • Immediate Care: Place in a dark, quiet room.
  • Anesthesia: Chloroform or intravenous barbiturate if spasms allow.
  • Adsorption: Administer animal charcoal to absorb free strychnine, or tannic acid if charcoal is unavailable.
  • Antidotes: Intravenous barbiturates to stop convulsions.
  • Muscle relaxants: Mephenesin, intravenous diazepam for anticonvulsant effects.

Autopsy Findings
  • Rigor mortis: Sets in almost immediately and passes off early.
  • Stomach contents: Remains of seeds may be found.
  • Delayed putrefaction.
  • Toxicological analysis: Strychnine can be detected in putrefied bodies and viscera; brain and spinal cord should be preserved for analysis.

Incorrect Options:

Ricinus (Option B): Ricinus, derived from the castor bean plant, contains ricin, which causes gastrointestinal symptoms, organ failure, and hemorrhagic shock. It does not typically cause seizures with back arching.

Nerium odorum (Option C): Nerium odorum (oleander) contains cardiac glycosides, which primarily affect the heart and can cause symptoms like nausea, vomiting, arrhythmias, and potentially death. Seizures and back arching are not characteristic features of oleander poisoning.

Datura (Option D): Datura contains tropane alkaloids, which cause delirium, hallucinations, and anticholinergic toxicity. Although it can cause seizures, it is not typically associated with arching of the back or the pattern of seizures described here.

questions.text: A patient with varicose veins complains of eczema in the same region. According to the CEAP guidelines, what is the stage of the clinical classification?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) C4a

Explanation:

  • According to the CEAP (Clinical, Etiological, Anatomical, and Pathophysiological) classification system for chronic venous disease, C4a refers to skin changes such as eczema or pigmentation in the presence of varicose veins.

The CEAP (Clinical- Etiology- Anatomy- Pathology) classification for chronic venous disorders:

Clinical Classification (C):

Class Description
C0 No visible or palpable signs of venous disease
C1 Telangiectasia or reticular veins (<1–3 mm)
C2 Varicose veins (>3 mm)
C3 Edema without skin changes
C4a Pigmentation or eczema
C4b Lipodermatosclerosis (LDS) or atrophie blanche
C4c Corona phlebectatica
C5 Healed venous ulcer
C6 Active venous ulcer

Each class can be followed by a modifier:

  • a = Asymptomatic

  • s = Symptomatic

  • r = Recurrent (after successful treatment/healing)
    Example: C2s, C6r

Etiological Classification (E)

Code Description
Ec Congenital
Ep Primary
Es Secondary (e.g., post-thrombotic)
En No venous etiology identified

 

Anatomical Classification (A)

Code Description
As Superficial veins
Ap Perforator veins
Ad Deep veins
An No venous location identified

 

Pathophysiological Classification (P)

Code Description
Pr Reflux
Po Obstruction
Pr,o Reflux and obstruction
Pn No identifiable pathology

Pigmentation/Eczema LDS

 

Atrophic blanche Corona phlebectatica

questions.text: Section 314 IPC deals with

choices.text: Causing miscarriage with the consent of the mother
Causing miscarriage without the consent of the mother
Death of the mother by act done with intent to cause miscarriage
Causing the death of the quick unborn child by an act amounting to culpable homicide

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Death of the mother by act done with intent to cause miscarriage

Explanation:

Section 314 IPC

  • Death caused by an act done with intent to cause miscarriage, if act done without woman's consent.
  • Now it corresponds to BNS 90.

IPC Section

Description

312

Causing miscarriage. (Option A ruled out)

313

Causing miscarriage without a woman's consent. (Option B ruled out)

314

Death caused by an act done with intent to cause miscarriage, if act done without woman's consent. (Option C)

315

Act done with intent to prevent a child being born alive or to cause it to die after birth.

316

Causing death of a quick unborn child by act amounting to culpable homicide. (Option D ruled out)

questions.text: A physician prescribed a drug that reduces the synthesis of uric acid for the gout. Identify the drug.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer D - Allopurinol

  • Allopurinol is an inhibitor of xanthine oxidase (XO).
  • Both allopurinol and its primary metabolite, oxypurinol (alloxanthine), reduce urate production by inhibiting XO, the enzyme that converts xanthine to uric acid.
  • Allopurinol competitively inhibits XO at low concentrations and is a non-competitive inhibitor at high concentrations.
  • It is the drug of choice for the treatment of chronic gout.
  • Other uses of allopurinol:
    • Tumour lysis syndrome
    • Lesch-Nyhan syndrome
    • Post-transplant patients

Probenecid (Option A) is a uricosuric agent that acts by increasing uric acid’s excretion in the urine.

Colchicine (Option B) is an anti-inflammatory medication commonly used to treat acute gout attacks but doesn’t affect uric acid levels.

Diclofenac (Option C) is a nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug (NSAID) that can also be used to manage gout symptoms but does not inhibit uric acid synthesis.

questions.text: The temperature of the body of a deceased person is found to be 39°C. Which of the following is the most probable reason?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Septicemia

Explanation

  • Septicemia, which is a systemic infection with widespread inflammation, is a common cause of fever in both living and deceased individuals.
  • It can cause hyperthermia due to the body's inflammatory response.
  • Elevated body temperature within the first two hours after death points toward a diagnosis of Postmortem caloricity.
    • Postmortem Caloricity:
      • Refers to the condition where the body temperature remains elevated for the first two hours after death.
      • Causes of Postmortem Caloricity:

1. Disturbed heat regulation

2. Increased heat production (excessive muscle contraction)

3. Excessive bacterial activity
  • Sunstroke
  • Pontine hemorrhage
  • Tetanus
  • Strychnine poisoning
  • Septicaemia
  • Cholera

Note: Burns do not typically cause postmortem caloricity.

Incorrect Options:

Cyanide poisoning (Option A): Cyanide poisoning typically causes rapid death and may lead to hypothermia rather than fever. Cyanide inhibits cellular respiration, leading to metabolic acidosis, but does not usually result in a fever like septicemia.

Corrosive poisoning (Option C): Corrosive poisoning (e.g., acid or alkali ingestion) can cause significant damage to tissues, but it does not typically result in a high body temperature like 39°C. It might lead to shock and other complications, but fever is not the hallmark sign.

Intra-abdominal hemorrhage (Option D): Intra-abdominal hemorrhage typically results in hypovolemic shock due to blood loss, leading to low body temperature (hypothermia) rather than fever.

questions.text: What is the most appropriate course of action for the management of a patient who presents to the emergency department with a severe headache and has a blood pressure reading of 160/100 mmHg, along with a CT scan showing evidence of a subarachnoid haemorrhage?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Angiography

Explanation:

  • In a patient presenting with a subarachnoid haemorrhage (SAH) and a severe headache, angiography is the most appropriate next step. This is crucial for identifying the source of the haemorrhage, such as an aneurysm or arteriovenous malformation (AVM).

Subarachnoid Hemorrhage:

  • Causes:
    • Most common: Trauma
    • Ruptured Aneurysm: Most commonly located in the Circle of Willis.
    • Arteriovenous Malformation (AVM)
    • Perimesencephalic SAH: Bleeding is confined to the basal cisterns due to venous bleeding and is associated with a better prognosis.
  • Risk factors:
    • Female sex
    • Hypertension
    • Smoking & Cocaine use
    • Genetic disorders (e.g., adult polycystic kidney disease, Marfan syndrome)
  • Symptoms:
    • Thunderclap Headache: Sudden and severe headache.
    • Associated with Seizures (10%), Unresponsiveness (50%) and Vomiting (70%)
  • Diagnosis:
    • CT Scan: First-line imaging, effective within 12 hours of onset, and its sensitivity decreases after one week.
    • Fisher Grading for SAH on CT:

Grade I

No bleeding.

Grade II

Diffuse SAH with layers <1mm thick.

Grade III

Localised clots or SAH layers >1mm thick.

Grade IV

SAH minimal/absent, with intracerebral/intraventricular haemorrhage.
  • Lumbar Puncture: Used if CT is negative but SAH is suspected.
  • Digital Subtraction Angiography (DSA): Gold standard for visualising aneurysms.

 

  • Management:
    • Surgical or endovascular intervention and addressing complications such as vasospasm and electrolyte imbalances.
    • Early and effective treatment is crucial for improving outcomes.

 

Nimodipine (Option A) is a calcium channel blocker commonly used in the management of SAH to prevent vasospasm, a frequent complication. However, it is not the immediate next step after the diagnosis of SAH.

Surgery (Option C) may be needed to treat the cause of SAH, such as a ruptured aneurysm. However, angiography is generally performed first to identify the location and extent of the aneurysm before proceeding with surgery.

Fibrinolytic therapy (Option D) is not typically used in the acute management of SAH. It is designed to dissolve intravascular clots and improve blood flow in ischemic conditions, but it is not indicated for SAH.

questions.text: A 20-year-old female patient consumed a cleaning product containing 90% sodium hydroxide. She is having complete dysphagia. What is the best step in management?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Feeding jejunostomy

Explanation:

  • Ingesting strong alkalis like sodium hydroxide can lead to significant damage to the esophagus, resulting in a condition called caustic esophagitis. A feeding jejunostomy enables nutrition to bypass the esophagus entirely, allowing it time to heal.

Corrosive injury to the esophagus occurs when it is exposed to acids or alkalis.

Aspect

Details

Pathophysiology
  • Alkali causes liquefaction, saponification, and thrombosis of vessels, leading to fibrosis and stricture.
  • Acid causes intense pylorospasm, antral pooling, coagulation necrosis, and eschar formation.

Acute Phase Management
  • Neutralization: vinegar/citrus for alkali; antacids/milk/egg whites for acid
  • Early endoscopy to assess severity and extent
  • Avoid emetics and sodium bicarbonate to prevent perforation

Management by Burn Degree

1st Degree Burns:

  • 48 hours observation; oral feeds resumed once saliva is swallowed painlessly
  • Regular follow-up endoscopy at 1st, 2nd, and 8th months to identify stricture

2nd & 3rd Degree Burns:

  • Fluid therapy, antibiotics, nutrition, PPIs and aerosolised steroids and resuscitation
  • Fiberoptic-guided airway intubation/tracheostomy, if necessary.
  • Endoscopic esophageal stenting, jejunostomy for feeding.
  • Laparoscopy for evaluation; laparotomy in unstable patients
  • Resection and end cervical esophagostomy with jejunostomy if necrosis is full thickness.
  • Consider re-exploration after 36-48 hours if necessary.
  • Regular endoscopic dilatation for stricture
  • Use of various dilators (e.g., balloon, Savary-Gilliard, Eder-Puestow) for esophageal dilatation.

Surgical Considerations
  • Esophageal resection is technically difficult; bypass may be preferred
  • Resection and end cervical esophagostomy with jejunostomy if necrosis is full thickness
  • A colonic conduit may be used if the stomach is diseased
  • Multiple strictures may require esophageal resection and colonic transposition

questions.text: A patient with a malignancy is undergoing chemotherapy; his platelet counts were reduced during the previous cycle of chemotherapy. What time will you give this to prevent/treat this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer A - Oprelvekin (IL-11)

  • Oprelvekin (IL-11) is a medication used to stimulate platelet production in patients who have undergone chemotherapy.
  • It works by stimulating the production of megakaryocytes, which are the cells that produce platelets.
  • It is approved for use in patients with chemotherapy-induced thrombocytopenia (CIT), a condition characterized by a low platelet count caused by chemotherapy.

Filgrastim (Option B) is a medication used to stimulate the production of white blood cells in patients undergoing chemotherapy. It works by stimulating the bone marrow to produce more white blood cells, which can help to prevent infections. While low platelet counts can be a side effect of chemotherapy, filgrastim is not indicated for treating thrombocytopenia.

Erythropoietin (Option C) is a medication that stimulates red blood cell production in patients with anemia. It is not indicated for the treatment of thrombocytopenia.

Amifostine (Option D) is a medication used to protect healthy cells from the toxic effects of chemotherapy. It does not stimulate the production of platelets and is not indicated for the treatment of thrombocytopenia.

questions.text: A 23-year-old male patient presents with a swelling in the midline of his neck that shifts when he swallows or sticks out his tongue. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Thyroglossal cyst

Explanation:

  • A thyroglossal cyst is a midline neck swelling that typically moves with swallowing or protrusion of the tongue.
  • It results from incomplete closure of the thyroglossal duct, which is an embryological remnant. The cyst often lies in close proximity to the hyoid bone and can be felt to shift with movement of the tongue or swallowing.

Thyroglossal Cyst:

  • It is a congenital neck mass resulting from the persistence of the thyroglossal duct, an embryological structure. It can also be present in adulthood.
  • The cyst represents a remnant of this duct and can be found anywhere along the midline from the base of the tongue to the thyroid isthmus.
  • It presents as midline swelling that moves with deglutition and protrusion of the tongue.
  • Most Common Site: Subhyoid (can also be seen on the floor of the mouth, Suprahyoid, near thyroid cartilage and foramen caecum)

Treatment:

  • Sistrunk Procedure: Complete surgical excision of the cyst and its tract up to the base of the tongue and a portion of the hyoid bone to prevent recurrence.
  • Incision and drainage are never done as they lead to the formation of a Thyroglossal fistula. (It also forms if an inflamed cyst ruptures.)—Always Acquired.

 

Brachial cyst (Option A): A brachial cyst, or branchial cleft cyst, generally appears as a lump along the anterior border of the sternocleidomastoid muscle, not in the midline of the neck.

Plunging ranula (Option C) is a mucous cyst found in the floor of the mouth, typically located laterally rather than in the midline, and it usually doesn't shift with swallowing or tongue protrusion.

Dermoid cyst (Option D), a type of teratoma, is often present at birth and can appear in the midline of the neck. However, these cysts typically do not move with swallowing or tongue protrusion.

questions.text: A farmer was sleeping in the field, and he felt a sting on his leg. He saw something moving away quickly. He then got drowsy and was taken to the hospital. He developed pain around the site and continued to bleed profusely from the wound site. The wound became red with blisters. Which of the following is the most likely cause?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Viper

Explanation

  • The symptoms described, including drowsiness, pain around the wound, bleeding, and blisters, are consistent with a viper bite.
  • Viper bites often lead to profuse bleeding due to the effects of venom-induced coagulopathy.

Incorrect Options:

Cobra (Option B): Cobra bites are primarily neurotoxic, causing paralysis, respiratory distress, and potentially death if untreated. While cobras can cause pain and local swelling, they do not typically cause the extensive bleeding or blisters seen with viper bites. Cobras do not usually cause such local tissue necrosis and blistering.

Wasp bite (Option C): Wasp stings can cause pain, redness, and swelling at the sting site, but they typically do not lead to bleeding, drowsiness, or blisters. The symptoms described here are more consistent with a venomous bite from a snake rather than an insect sting.

Scorpion (Option D): While scorpion stings can cause pain, local swelling, and sometimes neurological symptoms (such as drowsiness), they typically do not cause blisters or profuse bleeding at the sting site.

Signs and symptoms:

  • Dysfunction of cranial nerve and hyperexcitability of skeletal muscles developed within hours.
  • Local: Swelling, prominent, radiating pain, paraesthesia, and hyperesthesia which is accentuated by tapping on the affected area (Tap test)
  • Systemic effects: Restlessness, blurred vision, abnormal eye movements, profuse sweating, slurred speech, muscular fasciculations, respiratory depression and pulmonary edema.
  • Complications: Tachycardia,hypertension, arrhythmias, hyperthermia, rhabdomyolysis and acidosis.

questions.text: An infant is brought by his parents with complaints that his urine turns black on standing. Which of the following metabolic disorders is most likely?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Alkaptonuria

Explanation:

  • Alkaptonuria is Characterized by black urine upon standing due to the oxidation and polymerization of homogentisic acid (HGA).

 

Alkaptonuria

Definition

Rare autosomal recessive genetic disorder caused by a deficiency of homogentisate 1,2 dioxygenase (HGD), an enzyme in the tyrosine metabolism pathway.

Mechanism and Pathophysiology

Defective tyrosine metabolism → homogentisic acid (HGA) accumulation → ochronotic pigment deposition → systemic disease (ochronosis).

 

  • Deficiency: HGD fails to convert HGA to maleylacetoacetate.
  • Consequences:
    • HGA oxidizes into melanin-like polymers → connective tissue deposition (ochronosis).
    • Affects joints, heart valves, kidneys, and vessels.

Clinical Features
  • Triad: Homogentisic aciduria, ochronosis, ochronotic osteoarthropathy.
  • Pediatric signs: Dark urine (oxidized HGA).
  • Musculoskeletal: Arthritis (spine, hips, knees), kyphoscoliosis, spinal stenosis.
  • Cardiac: Aortic stenosis, mitral valve disease, coronary artery disease.
  • Renal/Metabolic: Stones (renal, gallbladder, prostate).
  • Neurological: Peripheral neuropathy, stroke.

Evaluation
  • Clinical scoring: AKU Severity Score Index (AKUSSI).
  • Diagnostic tests:
    • Gold standard: Urinary HGA quantification via gas chromatography-mass spectrometry.
    • Genetic testing for HGD mutations.
    • Imaging (CT/MRI): Joint involvement, valvular calcification.
    • Echocardiography: Valvular abnormalities.

Management
  • Symptomatic: Pain control, physiotherapy, joint surgery.
  • Diet: Low-protein diet (limited efficacy).
  • Medications:
    • Vitamin C: Reduces HGA oxidation but not urinary excretion.
    • Nitisinone: Inhibits tyrosine metabolism, reduces HGA >95%. Side effects: tyrosinemia, leukopenia, thrombocytopenia.

Prognosis and Complications
  • Prognosis: Normal life expectancy; reduced quality of life (pain, sleep issues, disability).
  • Complications:
    • Stones (renal, gallbladder, salivary).
    • Tendon/ligament ruptures.
    • Osteopenia, fractures.
    • Aortic calcification/stenosis.

 

Phenylketonuria (Option A):

  • Caused by phenylalanine hydroxylase deficiency, leading to the accumulation of phenylalanine.
  • Symptoms include intellectual disability, seizures, and musty odor, but no black urine.

Homocystinuria (Option C):

  • Due to cystathionine beta-synthase deficiency.
  • Presents with lens dislocation, thromboembolism, and developmental delay, but not black urine.

Maple Syrup Urine Disease (Option D):

  • Results from branched-chain alpha-keto acid dehydrogenase deficiency.
  • Urine has a characteristic sweet odor but does not turn black on standing.

questions.text: A young patient presents with a 5-day fever history and signs of hypotension, tachycardia, tachypnea, and altered mental status. Lab results show elevated white blood cell count, neutrophil proportion, and serum creatinine. The intern doctor plans to assess the quick Sequential Organ Failure Assessment (qSOFA) score for prognosis prediction and hospitalisation duration. Which elements are part of the qSOFA score?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) SBP, RR, and GCS score

Explanation:

  • The qSOFA score includes three components: Systolic Blood Pressure (SBP) less than 100 mmHg, Respiratory Rate (RR) greater than or equal to 22 breaths per minute, and a Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) score. These components help in the assessment of organ failure and sepsis prognosis.

Sepsis & q SOFA:

Sepsis is now defined as an increase of 2 or more points in the Sequential Organ Failure Assessment (SOFA) score from baseline. However, calculating the full SOFA score can be complex and requires lab results, so a simpler tool, the quick SOFA (qSOFA) score, was introduced for bedside use.

  • qSOFA Criteria: qSOFA involves evaluating three key signs:
    • Respiratory rate ≥ 22 breaths per minute
    • Altered mental status (GCS score)
    • Systolic blood pressure ≤ 100 mmHg (hypotension)
  • If a patient meets at least 2 of the 3 qSOFA criteria and is at risk for sepsis (e.g., has an infection), further evaluation should be conducted to identify the source of infection and initiate appropriate treatment.

questions.text: A child presents with bone pain and hepatosplenomegaly. A trephine biopsy and aspirate shows the following finding. Which of the following is the most likely enzyme deficient in this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Glucocerebrosidase

Explanation:

  • Gaucher's disease is characterized by the accumulation of glucosylceramide in RBCs and platelet membranes due to a deficiency in the enzyme beta-glucosidase (glucocerebrosidase), leading to anemia, hepatosplenomegaly, and thrombocytopenia. Bone marrow biopsy shows macrophages with a characteristic "wrinkled paper" appearance.

 

Gaucher's disease:

  • Lysosomal storage disease
  • Defective enzyme: Glucocerebrosidase (𝛽-Glucosidase)
  • Defect in metabolism: Accumulation of cerebroside (Glucosylceramide) in RBCs and platelet membranes. (Option B)
  • Pathophysiology: Abnormal RBCs and platelets are engulfed by macrophages leading to accumulation inside macrophages causing wrinkled paper appearance.

 

 

Disease

Enzyme deficiency

Features

Tay-Sachs disease

Hexosaminidase A

(Option A ruled out)
  • Mental retardation
  • Blindness
  • Muscular weakness
  • Cherry red spots in the macula

Fabry disease

α-Galactosidase
  • Skin rash
  • Kidney failure (full symptoms only in males
  • X-linked recessive)

Krabbe disease

β-Galactosidase
  • Mental retardation
  • Near absence of myelin
  • Predominant neurological manifestation and cranial nerves causing deafness and blindness.

Gaucher disease

β-Glucosidase
  • Enlarged liver and spleen
  • Erosion of long bones
  • Mental retardation in infants
  • Anemia
  • Thrombocytopenia

Niemann-Pick disease

Sphingomyelinase

(Option C ruled out)
  • Enlarged liver and spleen
  • Mental retardation
  • Fatal in early life
  • Cherry red spot in macula

Farber disease

Ceramidase
  • Hoarseness
  • Dermatitis
  • Skeletal deformation
  • Mental retardation
  • Fatal in early life

 

  • Alpha 1,4-glucosidase (Option D): Deficiency of alpha 1,4-glucosidase (acid maltase) results in Pompe disease, which is associated with glycogen accumulation, hypotonia, cardiomegaly, and muscle weakness, rather than hepatosplenomegaly and bone pain.

questions.text: What is the meaning of neoadjuvant chemotherapy in the context of a 54-year-old woman diagnosed with stage 2A cervical cancer?

choices.text: Chemotherapy is given along with radiation.
Chemotherapy is given before radical surgery to reduce the bulk of the tumour.
Chemotherapy is given after radical surgery for micrometastases.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Chemotherapy is given before radical surgery to reduce the bulk of the tumor.

Explanation:

  • Neoadjuvant chemotherapy refers to chemotherapy given before surgery to reduce the tumor size, making the surgery more effective and improving outcomes.
  • Neoadjuvant Systemic Therapy (NAST) refers to treatments like neoadjuvant chemotherapy (NACT), targeted therapy, or hormonal therapy administered before surgery. The goal is to shrink the tumour and assess its in vivo response to therapy.

Indications for Neoadjuvant Chemotherapy (NACT):

  • Locally advanced breast cancer (T3, T4, N2, N3): To reduce tumor size.
  • Select cases of early breast cancer:
    • To downsize the tumour for breast conservation surgery (BCS).
    • HER2/neu-positive tumors.
    • Triple-negative breast cancer (TNBC).
    • Premenopausal women (age <50 years).
    • Patients with axillary node metastasis.

 

Neoadjuvant Targeted Therapy: Administered for HER2/neu-positive tumours>5 mm in size, using trastuzumab and pertuzumab.

Neoadjuvant Hormonal Therapy: Offered to elderly or frail women with ER and/or PR-positive advanced tumours who are unfit for chemotherapy.

  • This therapy takes longer (3-6 months) for a clinical response to become evident.

questions.text: A child presents with thinning of hair and scaling of the scalp. On taking further history, it is found that she consumes raw eggs in her diet regularly. The given manifestations are due to the deficiency of which of the following vitamins?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Biotin

Explanation:

  • Biotin (vitamin B7) is a water-soluble vitamin essential for carboxylation reactions in metabolism, including fatty acid synthesis and gluconeogenesis.
  • It is crucial for maintaining healthy hair, skin, and nails.

 

Effect of Raw Egg Consumption:

  • Raw egg whites contain avidin, a protein that binds to biotin with high affinity, preventing its absorption in the gut.
  • Chronic consumption of raw eggs can lead to biotin deficiency, causing:
    • Thinning of hair (alopecia).
    • Scaling of the scalp and other skin lesions.
    • Neurological symptoms like depression, lethargy, and paresthesia (in severe cases).

 

Niacin (Option A): Niacin (vitamin B3) deficiency causes pellagra, characterized by the "3 Ds": dermatitis, diarrhea, and dementia. Hair thinning and scalp scaling are not typical features.

Pyridoxine (Option B): Pyridoxine (vitamin B6) deficiency can cause seborrheic dermatitis, irritability, and peripheral neuropathy, but it is not specifically linked to raw egg consumption.

Thiamine (Option D): Thiamine (vitamin B1) deficiency leads to beriberi or Wernicke-Korsakoff syndrome, which primarily affects the cardiovascular and nervous systems, not hair or scalp health.

questions.text: A female patient presented with acne that is not resolving on oral isotretinoin and antibiotics therapy. Which of the following is the next best investigation?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Evaluate for hyperandrogenism

Explanation:

  • The patient presents with acne that is not responding to oral isotretinoin and antibiotics, which suggests that a more systemic or hormonal cause could be contributing to the acne.
  • Hyperandrogenism is commonly associated with conditions like polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS) and congenital adrenal hyperplasia (CAH), both of which can lead to increased sebum production and hormonal imbalances, exacerbating acne.
  • Evaluating for hyperandrogenism through tests like testosterone levels, dehydroepiandrosterone sulfate (DHEAS), and other hormonal markers is crucial to rule out these underlying causes.
  • Hyperandrogenism is when the body produces too much androgen, a male hormone. This can contribute to the development of acne in women and other symptoms such as hirsutism and irregular periods.
  • Treatment may involve medications such as oral contraceptives or anti-androgen drugs.

 

Look for dietary triggers (Option A): Acne can be affected by diet in some people, particularly those with a high glycemic index or a diet high in dairy products. However, this is typically considered after other causes of acne have been ruled out. Additionally, dietary changes may not be sufficient to treat acne on their own, but rather they can be used in conjunction with other treatments.

Check for antibiotic resistance (Option C): Antibiotics are often used to treat acne, but over time, the bacteria that causes acne can become resistant to the antibiotics. If a patient's acne is not improving with antibiotics, checking for antibiotic resistance can help determine if a different treatment approach is needed.

Look for drug triggers (Option D): Certain medications can contribute to the development of acne. For example, corticosteroids, anticonvulsants, and some hormonal medications can cause acne as a side effect. If a patient takes any medications that may increase the risk of acne, it is important to evaluate their treatment plan and consider alternative medications if necessary.

questions.text: A child presents with mental retardation, bone pain, and inability to walk. On a fundoscopy examination, a cherry red spot is seen. There is no organomegaly.What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Tay-Sachs disease

Explanation:

  • In this scenario, the clinical features and fundoscopic image showing cherry red spot in the macula are consistent with the diagnosis of Tay-Sachs disease. It is an inborn error of metabolism due to the failure of degradation of gangliosides, which is caused by a deficiency in the enzyme hexosaminidase A.

 

 

Lipid Storage Diseases (Sphingolipidoses):

  • They are a group of lysosomal storage diseases.

 

Disease

Enzyme deficiency

Features

Tay-Sachs disease (Option C)

Hexosaminidase A
  • Mental retardation
  • Blindness
  • Muscular weakness
  • Cherry red spots in the macula

Fabry disease

α-Galactosidase
  • Skin rash
  • Kidney failure (full symptoms only in males
  • X-linked recessive)

Krabbe disease

β-Galactosidase
  • Mental retardation
  • Near absence of myelin
  • Predominant neurological manifestation and cranial nerves causing deafness and blindness.

Gaucher disease (Option D ruled out)

β-Glucosidase
  • Enlarged liver and spleen
  • Erosion of long bones
  • Mental retardation in infants
  • Anemia
  • Thrombocytopenia

Niemann-Pick disease (Option B ruled out)

Sphingomyelinase
  • Enlarged liver and spleen
  • Mental retardation
  • Fatal in early life
  • Cherry red spot in macula

Farber disease

Ceramidase
  • Hoarseness
  • Dermatitis
  • Skeletal deformation
  • Mental retardation
  • Fatal in early life

 

Hurler syndrome (Option C) presents with developmental delay, coarse facial features, corneal clouding, and organomegaly. It is not associated with a cherry-red spot or lack of organomegaly, making it an unlikely diagnosis in this scenario.

questions.text: A lady developed a skin reaction, as shown in the image after using a hair dye. Which of the following chemicals is responsible for this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) p-Phenylenediamine

Explanation:

  • p-Phenylenediamine (PPD) is a chemical commonly found in hair dyes. It is known to cause allergic reactions in some people, and symptoms can include itching, redness, swelling, and skin blistering. PPD allergies are fairly common and can be quite severe, so it is important to be cautious when using hair dyes that contain this chemical.

Incorrect Options:

Pollen (Option A): Pollen is a common allergen that can cause allergic reactions like hay fever. However, it is not typically found in hair dyes, so it is unlikely to be the cause of a skin reaction from hair dye.

Chromates (Option B): Chromates are chemicals that are sometimes used in hair dyes. They cause allergic reactions in some people, especially those with a history of eczema or other skin conditions. Symptoms of a chromate allergy can include itching, redness, and skin swelling.

Balsam of Peru (Option C): Balsam of Peru is a fragrance commonly used in perfumes, cosmetics, and other personal care products. It is known to cause allergic reactions in some people, and symptoms can include itching, redness, and skin swelling. However, it is not typically found in hair dyes.

questions.text: The true statement among the following is ___:

choices.text: Telmisartan dose should be reduced in renal failure but not in hepatic failure.
Irbesartan dose should be reduced in case of mild-moderate hepatic failure and renal failure.
Candesartan dose should be reduced in mild-moderate liver failure but not in renal failure.
Losartan acts as a thromboxane A2 antagonist and inhibits platelet aggregation.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Losartan acts as a thromboxane A2 antagonist and inhibits platelet aggregation.

  • Losartan is an angiotensin II receptor antagonist that blocks the binding of angiotensin II to the AT1 receptor subtype, leading to the dilation of blood vessels and reduced blood pressure.
  • It also blocks thromboxane A2 receptors and has some platelet antiaggregatory properties.

Telmisartan dose should be reduced in renal failure but not in hepatic failure (Option A): Telmisartan is primarily eliminated by the liver and metabolized by the cytochrome P450 system. In case of hepatic impairment, the dose of telmisartan should be reduced. The dose does not need to be reduced in renal failure.

Irbesartan dose should be reduced in case of mild-moderate hepatic failure and renal failure (Option B): Irbesartan is metabolized by the liver and excreted by the kidneys. In case of mild to moderate hepatic impairment or renal impairment, the dose should be reduced.

Candesartan dose should be reduced in mild-moderate liver failure but not in renal failure (Option C): Candesartan is mainly eliminated through the liver and excreted through the bile. In case of mild to moderate liver failure, the dose of candesartan should be reduced, but no dose adjustment is required in renal failure.

questions.text: What is the probable diagnosis for a young woman who presents with a painless ulcer in the genital region accompanied by pain less swelling of the lymph nodes in the groin?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Syphilis

Explanation:

  • The clinical presentation of a single painless genital ulcer with raised edges and a clean base, accompanied by painless swelling of the inguinal lymph nodes, strongly suggests primary syphilis.
  • Syphilis is a sexually transmitted infection caused by the spirochete bacterium Treponema pallidum. Primary syphilis typically manifests as a chancre, which is a painless ulcer appearing at the site of inoculation. The associated lymphadenopathy is also painless, helping to differentiate syphilis from other sexually transmitted infections.

Treatment of syphilis:

  • Primary, secondary, and early latent syphilis: A single intramuscular injection of benzathine penicillin G 2.4 million units.
  • Late latent syphilis or tertiary syphilis (excluding neurosyphilis): Benzathine penicillin G 2.4 million units IM weekly for 3 weeks.
  • Neurosyphilis: Intravenous aqueous crystalline penicillin G at 18–24 million units daily, divided into doses every 4 hours or by continuous infusion for 10–14 days.

Incorrect Options:

Option A) Chancroid:

  • Chancroid is caused by Haemophilus ducreyi and presents as a painful genital ulcer with irregular edges, often accompanied by tender, suppurative inguinal lymphadenopathy (buboes).

Option C) Herpes genitalis:

  • Caused by Herpes simplex virus (HSV), it presents with multiple painful vesicles or ulcers on the genital area, often associated with burning or itching sensations.

Option D) Granuloma inguinale:

  • Caused by Klebsiella granulomatis, it presents as beefy red ulcers that bleed easily on touch, with no associated lymphadenopathy. The ulcers are typically painless but have a different appearance than the chancre of syphilis.

questions.text: A patient was given digoxin and started having side effects like nausea and vomiting. The serum concentration of digoxin was 4 ng/ml, and the plasma therapeutic range was 1 ng/ml. If the half-life of digoxin is 40 hours, what time is required till you can safely start digoxin again?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer B - 80 hours

  • The Plasma half-life (t½) of a drug is the time taken for its plasma concentration to be reduced to half of its original value.
  • In the scenario, the digoxin serum concentration of 4 ng/ml is significantly above the therapeutic range.
  • Therefore, we should wait at least 80 hours before resuming treatment, considering digoxin’s half-life of 40 hours.

questions.text: Which of the following is associated with the clinical condition shown in the image?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Malignant melanoma

Explanation:

  • The image showing a lesion with irregular borders, asymmetry, and uneven distribution of colors, strongly suggests malignant melanoma. This is a malignant tumor arising from melanocytes located at the epidermal-dermal junction. Though rare, melanoma is highly aggressive with a significant risk of metastasis if not diagnosed early.

Key Diagnostic Features of Malignant Melanoma

  • ABCDE criteria:
    • Asymmetry.
    • Border irregularity.
    • Color variation (brown, black, red, white, or blue).
    • Diameter >6 mm.
    • Evolving lesion (changes in size, shape, or symptoms like bleeding or itching).

Biopsy Findings:

  • Large melanoma cells with enlarged nuclei, irregular contours, and clumped chromatin.
  • Prominent eosinophilic nucleoli.
  • Similar cellular appearance in both radial and vertical growth phases:
    • Radial phase: Horizontal spread of melanoma within the epidermis and superficial dermis.
    • Vertical phase: Deep invasion into dermal layers, forming an expansile mass.

Risk Factors:

  • Fair skin and history of sunburns.
  • Family history or genetic mutations (e.g., CDKN2A mutation on chromosome 9p21).
  • UV exposure and pre-existing nevi (e.g., dysplastic or congenital nevi).

Types of Melanoma:

Type

Site

Description

Image

Superficial spreading (M/C type)

Any (more common on the upper back and, in women, lower legs)

Brown mixed with bluish-red, bluish-black, reddish brown, and often whitish pink. The lesion border is often visibly and/or palpably raised

Lentigo maligna

Sun-exposed surfaces, particularly malar region and temple

In flat portions, brown and tan predominate, but whitish grey sometimes present; in nodules, reddish brown, bluish grey, bluish-black.

Acral lentiginous

Palm, sole, nail bed, mucous membrane

In flat portions, dark brown; in raised lesions (plaques), brown-black or blue-black.

Nodular

Any

Reddish blue, purple, or bluish-black; can be uniform or mixed with brown and black.

Staging and Classification:

  • Breslow thickness: Measures depth of tumor invasion.
  • Clark level: Describes the anatomical level of invasion.

Stage

Classification

Clarke

Breslow

I

Involvement of epidermis

≤ 0.75 mm

II

Involvement of epidermis + dermis

0.76-1.5 mm

III

Involvement of dermal papillae

1.5-4 mm

IV

Involvement of reticular dermis

>4 mm

V

Involvement of subcutaneous tissue

-

Management:

  1. Early detection and histopathological confirmation via biopsy are critical for improving outcomes.
  2. Wide local excision: Margins depend on Breslow thickness.
  3. Sentinel lymph node biopsy: Indicated for lesions >1 mm in thickness.
  4. Advanced cases:
    • Immunotherapy (e.g., immune checkpoint inhibitors).
    • Targeted therapy (BRAF/MEK inhibitors for BRAF-mutant melanoma).
    • Interferon-α: Prevents metastasis in high-risk cases.

Incorrect Options:

Option A) Condylomata lata:

  • Associated with secondary syphilis, these are smooth, moist, flat-topped, and highly contagious warty lesions, typically found in the anogenital region or mucous membranes. They lack the asymmetry, irregular borders, and color variations seen in malignant melanoma.

Option B) Mole:

  • Moles (benign melanocytic nevi) are symmetric lesions with uniform color, smooth borders, and no significant changes over time. They do not exhibit the irregular and evolving features of malignant melanoma.

Option D) Basal cell carcinoma:

  • This is the most common skin cancer, presenting as a pearly or translucent papule with telangiectasias, often on sun-exposed areas. It rarely shows pigmentation or the asymmetry and color variation seen in malignant melanoma.

questions.text: A defect in which of the following forms the structure marked below?

choices.text:
Internal oblique
B) External oblique
C) Parietal peritoneum
D) Fascia transversalis

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Fascia transversalis

Explanation:

  • The structure marked in the image corresponds to the deep inguinal ring, a key anatomical feature of the inguinal canal.
  • The deep inguinal ring is an opening in the fascia transversalis, located just above the midpoint of the inguinal ligament. This defect allows the passage of the spermatic cord in males and the round ligament of the uterus in females.

 

Structure

Description

Parietal peritoneum

(Option C)

Most posterior structure.

Transversalis fascia

Has a defect called the deep inguinal ring, through which the testes and spermatic cord pass. Site for indirect inguinal hernias. Anterior to parietal peritoneum. Forms the posterior in the whole extent.

Lateral umbilical fold

Formed by the inferior epigastric vessels.

Median umbilical ligament

Remnant of the urachus (from the allantois).

Medial umbilical ligament

Remnant of the obliterated umbilical artery.

Pyramidalis muscle

Small muscle attaching to the pubic bone. Rectus abdominis lies above it. Covered by the rectus sheath and supplied by the subcostal nerve (T12).

Rectus abdominis muscle

Receives segmental innervation from T6–T12.

Transversus abdominis muscle

Does not form the anterior wall of the inguinal canal. Contributes to the roof and posterior wall. Combines with internal oblique to form the conjoint tendon.

Internal oblique muscle (Option A)

Forms parts of the anterior, roof, and posterior walls of the inguinal canal. Contributes to cremasteric muscle and fascia.

External oblique muscle (Option B)

Aponeurosis forms the anterior wall of the inguinal canal and the superficial inguinal ring. Forms external spermatic fascia.

Internal spermatic fascia

Derived from the transversalis fascia.

questions.text: Injury at which of the following marked sites causes failure of dorsiflexion?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) 3

Explanation:

  • The injury to common fibular nerve causes failure of dorsiflexion, thus the marked structure 3 i.e. neck of fibula is the right answer

Sciatic Nerve

Origin and Course
  • The thickest nerve in the body.
  • Arises from the ventral rami of L4–S3 spinal nerves.
  • Exits the pelvis through the greater sciatic foramen below the piriformis and descends between the greater trochanter and ischial tuberosity along the back of the thigh.
  • Divides into the tibial and common peroneal nerves above the popliteal fossa.

Distribution

Motor:

  • Undivided Trunk: Supplies all muscles of the back of the thigh (hip extension, knee flexion).
  • Tibial Nerve: Innervates leg muscles (flexion) and foot muscles (plantar flexion).
  • Common Peroneal Nerve: Supplies leg muscles (dorsiflexion).

Sensory:

  • Tibial Nerve: Supplies skin on the back of the calf, heel, lateral border of the foot, and sole.
  • Common Peroneal Nerve: Supplies skin on the anterolateral and lateral surfaces of the leg and dorsum of the foot (except for the deep peroneal nerve area).

Clinical correlation

Injury of the sciatic nerve:

  • Causes: Penetrating wounds, posterior hip dislocation, pelvic fractures, total hip replacement, misplaced injections in the gluteal region.
  • Clinical Features:
    • Inability to extend the thigh and flex the knee (hamstring paralysis).
    • Loss of all movements below the knee (foot drop) leading to flail foot and high-stepping gait.
    • Loss of sensation on the back of the thigh, entire leg, and foot (except for the saphenous nerve area).

Sciatica:

  • Shooting pain along the sciatic nerve distribution (buttock, posterior thigh, lateral leg, dorsum of the foot).
  • Compression/irritation of L4–S3 spinal nerve roots due to herniated lumbar discs.

Neuropathy:

  • Entrapment in the piriformis muscle can lead to piriformis syndrome.

                              Sciatic Nerve Course

 

                     Branches of Sciatic Nerve

questions.text: A schizophrenic patient was prescribed drug A after he did not respond to haloperidol and thioridazine. He now presents with excessive salivation, an increase in blood glucose, and hyperlipidemia. What is drug “A”?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Clozapine

Explanation:

  • Drug A is likely Clozapine, the preferred treatment for treatment-resistant schizophrenia, known to cause side effects like excessive salivation, increased blood glucose, and hyperlipidemia.

Clozapine

Class

Atypical antipsychotic (1st atypical antipsychotic discovered)

Mechanism of action

Primarily works as a dopamine D2 receptor antagonist, but it also has significant effects on serotonin receptors (5-HT2A and 5-HT2C), which helps reduce symptoms in treatment-resistant cases.

Uses

  • DOC for TRS (Treatment-resistant schizophrenia): Used only when a patient doesn't respond to at least 2 antipsychotics.
  • Only antipsychotics with anti-suicidal properties (shown ↓ suicidal ideas in Schizophrenia patients).

Side effects

Severe risks (Pneumonic: SAM):

  • S - Seizures
    • Dose dependant
    • > 600 mg has more seizures
  • A - Agranulocytosis
    • Idiosyncratic
    • ↓ WBC (Neutrophils)
    • The main reason for deaths and withdrawal from the market
    • Weekly monitoring of WBC and Neutrophil count for 1st 6 months is important
  • M - Myocarditis
    • Idiosyncratic
    • Chest pain
    • Dyspnea
    • Abnormal ECG

Common side effects:

  • Sedation (most common)
  • Weight gain (maximum weight gain of all antipsychotics)
  • Hypersalivation (sialorrhea)
  • Sedation
  • Tachycardia
  • Nausea
  • Vomiting
  • Constipation
  • Hypotension

Rare side effects include myocarditis.

Contraindications

  • WBC count - < 3500/mm
  • Previous bone marrow disorder
  • H/o of Agranulocytosis during Clozapine treatment
  • Use of another bone marrow suppressant (carbamazepine)

Monitoring

TLC and ANC

  • Once a week for the first 6 months
  • Once in two weeks for the next 6 months
  • Once a month till the patient continues

Incorrect Options:

Ziprasidone (Option A) is an atypical antipsychotic medication that is less likely to cause the mentioned side effects.

Risperidone (Option B) is another atypical antipsychotic, and while it can cause some metabolic side effects, it is not typically associated with hypersalivation.

Aripiprazole (Option D) is also an atypical antipsychotic, but hypersalivation is not a typical side effect of this medication

questions.text: A patient comes to the casualty with consumption of OPC pesticide. He was started on IV atropine infusion and pralidoxime. After 2 hours, the patient had a sudden rise in temperature. What is the cause of the fever?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer A - Atropine toxicity
