  • Mesothelioma is primarily caused by exposure to asbestos fibres, which is a known risk factor for this type of cancer.
  • Long-term exposure to asbestos, especially in industries such as cement factories, is the most common occupational cause of mesothelioma.
  • Asbestos exposure is a well-established risk factor for developing laryngeal, ovarian, colon, lung, and pleural cancers.
  • Lung mesothelioma is a more specific tumour associated with asbestos exposure. It is common but is less prevalent than Adenocarcinoma.

Mesothelioma

A rare cancer arising from mesothelial cells that most commonly affects the pleura, and it can also affect the peritoneum, pericardium, and tunica vaginalis

Etiology

Mesothelioma is the most specific asbestos-associated cancer

Pathology

  • Advanced pleural mesothelioma can cause extensive pleural fibrosis and thickening,
  • making the affected side rigid and immobile
  • Later stages fix the mediastinum in place due to pleural thickening and fibrosis.
  • A mediastinal shift is not a characteristic feature of mesothelioma.

Clinical features

  • Progressive dyspnea, chest pain, weight loss, chronic cough, hemoptysis
  • Decreased breath sounds and dullness to percussion (due to pleural effusion or thickening).

Diagnosis

CT scan shows Pleural thickening, effusion, or frozen hemithorax (not causing a mediastinal shift in the presence of effusion)

Biopsy (Diagnosis can be confirmed)

  • Epithelioid mesothelioma shows tubules, nests, or papillary structures with uniform round to oval nuclei and eosinophilic cytoplasm.
  • Sarcomatoid mesothelioma consists of spindle-shaped cells resembling fibrosarcoma.
  • Biphasic mesothelioma displays a mixture of both patterns.

Specific markers for mesothelioma

  • Calretinin
  • Epithelial membrane antigen
  • Cytokeratin
  • Mesothelin

Prognosis

Poor - median survival of 9-21 months

Incorrect Options:

Silicosis (Option A) is caused by the inhalation of silica dust, commonly seen in industries such as mining and construction. While silica exposure can lead to lung fibrosis, it is not a direct cause of mesothelioma.

Coal worker pneumoconiosis (Option C), also known as black lung disease, results from the inhalation of coal dust. This condition affects the lungs but is not linked to mesothelioma.

Bagassosis (Option D) is caused by the inhalation of mouldy sugarcane dust and can lead to lung disease, but it is not associated with mesothelioma.

questions.text: A 22-year-old female comes to the STI clinic with minimal vaginal discharge. On speculum examination, erosions are seen on the cervix. Which of the following kit should be given to this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Grey

Explanation:

  • The probable diagnosis would be a sexually transmitted infection.
  • There are 7 color-coded STD kits.
  • Kit 1- Grey is given for urethral discharge, cervicitis, and anorectal discharge.

questions.text: A patient is brought to the OPD by his wife complaining about difficulty in expressing emotions and not taking part in daily activities. On examination, resting tremors and rigidity are noted. Given the possible diagnosis, which part of the brain is affected in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer A - Basal ganglia

  • The patient's presentation of difficulty expressing emotions, lack of participation in daily activities, resting tremors, and rigidity is highly suggestive of Parkinson's disease.
  • Parkinson's disease is primarily caused by degeneration of the substantia nigra, a structure located in the basal ganglia. This degeneration results in reduced dopamine production, which affects the motor control pathways, leading to the hallmark symptoms of rigidity, tremors, and bradykinesia.
  • The basal ganglia is a group of nuclei in the brain involved in motor control, as well as cognitive and emotional functions. The degeneration of dopamine-producing neurons in the substantia nigra disrupts the communication between the basal ganglia and other parts of the brain, resulting in the characteristic motor and non-motor symptoms seen in Parkinson's disease.

Other Features of Parkinson's Disease:

  • Rigidity: Increased muscle tone causing resistance to passive movement.
  • Resting tremors: Involuntary, rhythmic shaking that occurs when the muscles are relaxed.
  • Bradykinesia: Slowness of movement, making daily tasks more difficult.
  • Postural instability: Difficulty maintaining balance, leading to falls.

Hippocampus (Option B): The hippocampus is primarily involved in memory formation, learning, and spatial navigation, and lesions here can lead to issues with memory and emotional behavior. However, it is not primarily associated with the motor symptoms seen in Parkinson's disease.

Cerebellum (Option C): The cerebellum is responsible for coordinating voluntary movement and balance. Lesions in the cerebellum typically cause ataxia, intention tremors, and gait disturbances, but not the resting tremors or rigidity characteristic of Parkinson's disease.

Premotor cortex (Option D): The premotor cortex is involved in the planning and preparation of movements, particularly in coordinating postural adjustments for voluntary movements. While damage here can affect motor planning, it is not typically associated with the specific motor symptoms seen in Parkinson's disease.

questions.text: A 45-year-old HIV-positive male came with complaints of persistent cough and weight loss. He has skin lesions that appear as umbilicated papules and nodules predominantly on the face, trunk, and upper extremities. Chest x-ray showed multiple bilateral nodular infiltrates. His sputum CBNAAT for tuberculosis was negative and he has a low CD4 count. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer A - HIV with disseminated histoplasmosis

  • The clinical presentation of a HIV-positive patient with persistent cough, weight loss, skin lesions (umbilicated papules and nodules), and bilateral nodular infiltrates on chest x-ray, along with a low CD4 count, suggests a diagnosis of disseminated histoplasmosis.

Histoplasmosis

A systemic fungal infection caused by Histoplasma capsulatum, a dimorphic fungus endemic in regions like the Ohio and Mississippi River valleys, Central/South America, and Africa.

Pathophysiology:

  • Acquired by inhaling fungal microconidia from contaminated soil (bird/bat droppings).
  • Yeast forms multiply in macrophages, spreading through lymphatics and bloodstream.
  • Immunocompromised hosts (e.g., HIV/AIDS, CD4+ <200/μL) are at higher risk of dissemination.

Clinical Features:

Asymptomatic: Common in immunocompetent individuals.

Acute Pulmonary: Fever, cough, chest pain, flu-like symptoms.

Chronic Pulmonary: Associated with COPD, presenting with cough, weight loss, and cavitary lung lesions.

Progressive Disseminated Histoplasmosis (PDH):

  • Systemic: Fever, weight loss, hepatosplenomegaly, thrombocytopenia.
  • Lungs: Diffuse interstitial or reticulonodular infiltrates.
  • Skin: Papules, plaques, or ulcers (~10% cases).

Diagnosis:

  • Antigen detection: Urine, serum, or BAL fluid.
  • Culture: Blood, bone marrow, or BAL fluid (gold standard, slow).
  • Histopathology: Yeast forms in macrophages (PAS/GMS stains).
  • Imaging: Chest X-ray or CT shows infiltrates or cavitary lesions.

Treatment:

Mild to Moderate: Itraconazole for 6–12 months.

Severe/PDH: Liposomal amphotericin B (induction) followed by itraconazole (maintenance for ≥12 months).

Chronic Pulmonary: Itraconazole for 12–24 months.

HIV with disseminated cryptococcosis (Option B): Cryptococcosis is commonly associated with meningeal involvement in immunocompromised patients. This patient's symptoms (including the skin lesions and lung involvement) do not suggest cryptococcosis, especially as there are no signs of meningitis.

HIV with molluscum contagiosum (Option C): Molluscum contagiosum is a skin infection caused by a poxvirus, typically characterized by umbilicated papules on the skin. While this patient does have skin lesions, the lung involvement and the bilateral nodular infiltrates on the chest x-ray point to a systemic fungal infection rather than a localized skin condition.

HIV with tuberculosis (Option D): Tuberculosis would typically present with symptoms like cough, hemoptysis, and weight loss. However, the patient's negative sputum CBNAAT for tuberculosis and absence of granulomas on imaging make tuberculosis less likely.

questions.text: In a female patient, there is a complaint of vision loss, specifically affecting the right halves of both eyes. Where is the lesion located?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Left optic tract

Explanation:

  • The lesion described in the question is located in the left optic tract, which explains the vision loss affecting the right halves of both eyes (right homonymous hemianopia).

Visual Pathway:

  • Temporal fibers carry impulses from the Nasal field, and Nasal fibres carry the Temporal field.

Associated Symptoms
  • Memory loss
  • Hearing loss
  • Auditory hallucinations
  • Contralateral hemiplegia
  • Hemianesthesia
  • Optokinetic nystagmus
 

Right Optic Tract (Option D)

  • Effect: Left homonymous hemianopia (left halves of both fields).
  • Vision loss given here is in the right halves, not the left.

questions.text: A male patient presented to the emergency room with seizures. He has a history of fever, headache, and confusion. An MRI brain was done, and it showed inflammation involving the bitemporal lobe. What is the most likely etiology for this presentation?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer C - Herpes simplex virus

The patient presents with fever, headache, confusion, and seizures, symptoms highly suggestive of encephalitis. Neurological examination reveals personality changes and altered consciousness, raising suspicion for focal neurological involvement.

  • MRI: Shows bitemporal lobe hyperintensities, a hallmark feature of HSV encephalitis.
  • Focal Neurological Signs: Symptoms linked to temporal lobe pathology, such as behavioral changes and impaired mental status.

HSV Encephalitis

HSV encephalitis is a rapidly progressive, life-threatening condition, often presenting with:

  • Seizures: Focal or generalized.
  • Neurological symptoms: Aphasia, ataxia, cranial nerve deficits.
  • Behavioral and cognitive changes: Altered sensorium, memory impairment, personality changes (sometimes misdiagnosed as personality disorders).

Additional Features:

  • Urinary/fecal incontinence.
  • Aseptic meningitis.
  • Dermatomal rashes.
  • Rarely, Guillain-Barré syndrome.

Diagnosis

CSF Analysis:

  • Lymphocytic pleocytosis, normal glucose, mild protein elevation.
  • CSF PCR for HSV: Gold standard with 96% sensitivity, 99% specificity.

Neuroimaging (MRI): T2-weighted/DWI: Hyperintensities in temporal and orbitofrontal lobes.

EEG: Periodic slow-wave activity in the temporal lobes, highly suggestive of HSV encephalitis.

Management

Antiviral Therapy: Early initiation of IV acyclovir to prevent permanent neurological damage.

(PMNs)

↓ to normal

150-300

40-600

(Lymphocytes or PMNs, depending on the causative organism)

Parasitic

Normal

50-200

150-2000

(↑↑ Eosinophils) (≥50%)

Cytomegalovirus (Option A): CMV encephalitis typically occurs in immunocompromised individuals (e.g., HIV, organ transplant recipients). On MRI, CMV encephalitis often shows enlarged ventricles and periventricular calcifications, not the typical temporal lobe findings seen in HSV encephalitis.

Toxoplasma gondii (Option B): Toxoplasmosis primarily affects immunocompromised patients (e.g., HIV/AIDS). It usually presents with multiple brain lesions, commonly affecting the basal ganglia and corticomedullary junction, which would be visible on MRI.

Mycobacterium tuberculosis (TB) (Option D): TB encephalitis, which is more common in children or immunocompromised individuals, can present with cerebral edema, seizures, and decreased consciousness. However, TB typically affects the cerebral cortex more diffusely and is less likely to cause bitemporal lobe involvement, as seen in HSV encephalitis.

questions.text: A 2-month-old infant is brought to the OPD with a parietal swelling present since birth. The X-ray image is given below. What could be the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: Option B) Cephalohematoma

Explanation:

Cephalohematoma (subperiosteal hematoma) presents as a well-circumscribed, firm mass over the parietal bones that does not cross suture lines. It typically develops in the first few hours after birth, with increasing size for 12-24 hours, and then stabilizes. This fits the description provided in the scenario.

Characteristic

Caput Succedaneum

(Option C ruled out)

Cephalohematoma

(Option B)

Incidence

Common

Less common

Location

Subcutaneous plane

Over parietal bones, between the skull and periosteum.

Time of Presentation

Maximum size and firmness at birth.

Develops during the 1st few hours of life. Increasing size for 12-24 hours and then stable.

Time Course

Softens progressively from birth.

Takes 3-6 weeks to resolve, but may resolve within 2-3 days.

Characteristic Findings
  • Diffuse Circular boggy area of oedema with indistinct borders.
  • Often with overlying ecchymosis
  • Crosses suture line
  • Well-circumscribed fluid-filled mass.
  • Does not cross the suture line

Association

None

Linear skull fracture (5-25%); hyperbilirubinemia

 

Subgaleal Hemorrhage (Option A) is a more diffuse, larger haemorrhage that crosses suture lines and is associated with more severe symptoms. It is less likely to present as a firm, well-defined mass and is typically associated with significant blood loss, which is not described in the scenario.

Encephalocele (Option D): Encephalocele is a neural tube defect characterized by sac-like protrusions of the brain and the membranes that cover it through openings in the skull. It appears as an external bulge in the skull and requires surgical intervention.

questions.text: A 65-year-old diabetic woman presents with painless loss of vision. The ocular findings are shown in the image below. What is the likely diagnosis and management for this patient?

choices.text: Immature senile cataract and phacoemulsification with IOL

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Immature senile cataract and phacoemulsification with IOL

Explanation:

  • The patient is a 65-year-old diabetic woman with painless loss of vision, which points towards cataracts, a common cause of visual impairment, especially in older individuals and those with diabetes.
  • Immature senile cataract refers to the early stages of cataract formation, where the lens becomes cloudy but is not yet completely opaque. This typically leads to gradual loss of vision without pain.
  • The standard treatment for cataracts, especially in cases with significant visual impairment, is phacoemulsification, a surgical procedure that uses ultrasound to break up the lens, followed by removal and placement of an intraocular lens (IOL) to restore clear vision.

Type of Cataract

Characteristics

Visual Impact

Cuneiform Senile Cortical Cataract
  • Wedge-shaped opacities with clear areas in between.
  • Extends from periphery to center.
  • First appears in the lower nasal quadrant. Present in both anterior and posterior cortex.
  • The radial spoke-like pattern of opacities is seen.
  • Visual disturbances are noted at a comparatively late stage (since it starts at the periphery).
  • Vision improves in bright light with contracted pupils.

Cupuliform Senile Cortical Cataract

  • Saucer-shaped opacities are typically in the central part of the posterior cortex (posterior subcapsular cataract).
  • Extends from center to periphery.
  • Causes an early loss of visual acuity.- Due to the involvement of the nodal point
  • Glares seen in PSC
  • Better vision in dim light with dilated pupils.

Stages of Cortical cataract:

Stage

Description

Characteristics

1. Stage of Lamellar Separation

Earliest stage of senile cataract
  • Formation of vacuoles and water clefts within the cortex
  • Reversible change
  • Can only be demonstrated by slit lamp examination

2. Stage of Incipient Cataract

Detectable opacities with clear areas present between. Causes visual disturbances.

Cuneiform type:

  • Wedge-shaped opacities, extending from the equator appear as radial spoke-like opacities.

Cupuliform type:

  • Saucer-shaped opacity in the central posterior cortex.

3. Immature Senile Cataract

Progression of opacification
  • Iris shadow visible (clear cortex visible) -Iris Shadow present here due to opacities + clear areas
  • Can progress to Intumescent Cataract leading to the shallow anterior chamber.

4. Mature Senile Cataract (aka intumescent cataract)

Complete opacification of cortex
  • The lens appears pearly white
  • Referred to as a "ripe cataract"
  • No iris shadow as the whole lens is opacified with a chalky white color

5. Hypermature Senile Cataract (HMSC)

Advanced stage of cataract beyond maturity

Morgagnian Hypermature Cataract:

  • Cortex liquefies
  • Nucleus sinks to the bottom
  • Bag of milky fluid appearance

Sclerotic Hypermature Cataract:

  • The cortex disintegrates, lens and capsule shrink.
  • Deep anterior chamber
  • Iridodonesis may be present.

Incorrect Options:

Zonular cataract and lensectomy (Option A): Zonular cataract is a specific type of cataract involving changes to the lens fibers and zonules (the ligaments that hold the lens in place). While lensectomy (removal of the lens) can be performed, it is typically not the preferred term for routine cataract surgery, and this condition is not as commonly associated with the age and symptoms described here.

Rosette cataract and sugar control (Option B): A rosette cataract is a rare type of cataract that forms as a star-shaped pattern, usually associated with trauma or certain diseases, but it is not typically seen in diabetic patients or with the presentation described here. Sugar control is important for diabetes management, but it doesn't directly address the cataract-related vision loss.

Sunflower cataract and lesion extraction (Option C): A sunflower cataract is typically associated with Wilson's disease, a condition characterized by copper accumulation in tissues, leading to a distinctive appearance of the cataract. The patient does not have signs of Wilson's disease, and lesion extraction would not be appropriate for a cataract.

questions.text: A male patient presents with sensory loss and weakness of limbs for 3 months. He also has angular stomatitis. On examination, there is loss of proprioception, vibration sensations, UMN-type lower limb weakness, and absent ankle reflex. What is the most probable diagnosis?

choices.text: Subacute combined degeneration of the cord

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Subacute combined degeneration of the cord

  • The clinical features described in this case—sensory loss, weakness of limbs, angular stomatitis, loss of proprioception and vibration sensation, UMN-type weakness, and absent ankle reflexes—are highly suggestive of subacute combined degeneration of the cord (SACD), which is a condition caused by vitamin B12 deficiency.

Subacute Combined Degeneration of the Cord (SACD)

Neurological disorder due to vitamin B12 deficiency, causing demyelination of the posterior columns and lateral corticospinal tracts.

Etiology

Vitamin B12 Deficiency:

  • Pernicious anemia.
  • Gastrectomy or ileal resection.
  • Diphyllobothrium latum infestation.
  • Long-term use of metformin or PPIs.

Affected Areas

  • Posterior columns: Loss of proprioception and vibration sense.
  • Lateral corticospinal tracts: Spasticity and UMN-type weakness.

Clinical Features

Sensory Symptoms:

  • Loss of proprioception and vibration sense: Begins in lower limbs, may progress to upper limbs.
  • Sensory ataxia: Positive Romberg’s test (difficulty standing with eyes closed).
  • Paresthesia: Tingling or numbness in extremities, typically in a glove-and-stocking distribution.

Motor Symptoms:

  • Upper motor neuron signs: Weakness, spasticity, and hyperreflexia.
  • Spastic weakness: Due to lateral corticospinal tract involvement.
  • Absent ankle reflex: A key finding, coexisting with UMN signs due to concurrent peripheral neuropathy.

Signs:

  • Lhermitte's Sign: Electric shock-like sensation down the spine on neck flexion.
  • Angular stomatitis
  • Optic neuropathy

Non-neurological Features:

  • Megaloblastic anemia: fatigue, pallor, glossitis, and jaundice.

Psychiatric Symptoms:

  • Irritability, dementia, psychosis.
  • Depression and memory loss.

Treatment

  • Vitamin B12 Replacement:
    • IM cyanocobalamin or hydroxocobalamin.
    • Oral B12 for maintenance.
  • Address underlying causes (e.g., anemia, parasitic infestation).

Extradural cord compression (Option A), caused by a space-occupying lesion (e.g., tumor or abscess), typically presents with localized back pain, radicular symptoms, and bladder/bowel dysfunction. It typically causes asymmetric neurological deficits, unlike the symmetrical loss of proprioception, vibration, and UMN signs seen in subacute combined degeneration. Additionally, it does not cause angular stomatitis, which is indicative of vitamin B12 deficiency

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) (Option B) primarily affects lower motor neurons and upper motor neurons. It presents with fasciculations, muscle cramps, muscle weakness, and atrophy, as well as bulbar palsy symptoms (dysarthria, dysphagia). Absence of sensory loss is a key differentiator here, as ALS does not typically affect sensory pathways.

Multiple sclerosis (MS) (Option C): MS is an autoimmune demyelinating disease of the central nervous system, affecting both white matter in the brain and spinal cord. It commonly presents with symptoms like paresthesia, optical neuritis, weakness, and gait disturbances. Lhermitte’s sign (pain down the back with neck flexion) and Uhthoff's sign (worsening of symptoms with heat) are classic, but the sensory loss and angular stomatitis here point more toward vitamin B12 deficiency rather than MS.

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy presents with a small nodule on the sclera as shown in the image below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Dermoid cyst

Explanation:

  • Dermoid cyst appears as a lenticular yellow tumor near the corneal margin and consists of epidermoid epithelium with sebaceous glands and hair.
  • Dermoid cyst is a congenital, often benign growth that contains skin-like structures, such as hair follicles, sweat glands, and sebaceous glands. It can present as a small, firm, yellowish nodule on the sclera or conjunctiva. These cysts are often located near the limbus (the junction between the cornea and sclera) and may be noticed in childhood, especially if they grow or become more noticeable over time.
  • A dermoid cyst may be diagnosed based on its characteristic appearance and location, and sometimes imaging or excision is needed for confirmation.

Pterygium (Option A): A pterygium is a fibrovascular growth that extends from the conjunctiva onto the cornea, typically seen on the nasal side of the eye. It is usually triangular in shape and may cause visual disturbance. It is not typically a nodule confined to the sclera.

Pinguecula (Option B): A yellowish, triangular patch on the conjunctiva near the limbus, typically in the elderly, associated with sun exposure and not extending onto the cornea.

Dermolipoma (Option C): A dermolipoma is a benign tumor consisting of fat and skin-like tissue. While they may be located in the eye area, they typically present as larger, softer masses, and this does not match the presentation of a small nodule on the sclera.

questions.text: A patient presented with abdominal pain and sterile pyuria, and the x-ray showed the following features. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: Option A) Putty kidney

Explanation:

  • The X-ray shows a calcified mass of the right kidney, often referred to as "putty-like," indicating dystrophic calcification. Putty kidney is seen in advanced renal tuberculosis, where extensive calcification and atrophy lead to a non-functioning kidney.

 

Calcifications in the Kidney:

Description

Staghorn Calculus

 

Putty Kidney (Option A)

Medullary Nephrocalcinosis

Description

Large, branching stone filling the renal pelvis and calyces, resembling the shape of a staghorn.

Tissue damage in the kidney by TB leads to dystrophic calcification. Indicates end-stage renal TB.

Calcium deposition within the renal medulla (inner kidney).

Cause

Struvite stones formed from magnesium ammonium phosphate due to infection with urease-producing bacteria (e.g., Klebsiella, Proteus)

Renal tuberculosis leads to granuloma formation causing necrosis, cavitation, fibrosis and stricture formation.

Metabolic disturbances (e.g., hyperparathyroidism, sarcoidosis, renal tubular acidosis, medullary sponge kidney disease) leading to calcification of the renal medulla

Imaging Characteristics

Radio-opaque, visible on CT. They often form rapidly; fill the renal pelvis and extend into calyces. (Option B ruled out)

Appears as a lobulated mass of calcified tissue on CT scans, resembling "putty"; indicating a non-functioning kidney.

Detected on plain radiographs, ultrasound, and CT. USG and CT are very specific and hence useful even in mild cases

  • USG- hyperechoic renal parenchyma with posterior acoustic shadowing.

 

  • CT- High-density renal parenchyma in the medulla (Option C ruled out)

Psoas calcification (Option D): Psoas calcification typically refers to calcification within the psoas muscle or tendon, and it's usually associated with chronic inflammation.

questions.text: The eye examination of a 20-year-old male shows a golden ring on the cornea. What of the following is the investigation of choice to diagnose the condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Serum ceruloplasmin

Explanation:

  • The golden ring on the cornea seen in this 20-year-old male is characteristic of Kayser-Fleischer rings, which are typically associated with Wilson's disease. Wilson’s disease is a genetic disorder of copper metabolism that leads to copper accumulation in various tissues, including the liver, brain, and cornea.
  • Kayser-Fleischer rings are copper deposits that form in the Descemet membrane of the cornea, appearing as a golden or greenish ring on slit-lamp examination.

Wilson’s disease

  • Deficiency of ceruloplasmin, leading to abnormal copper deposition in tissues.
  • Symptoms:
    • Liver disease
    • Basal ganglia dysfunction (movement disorders)
    • Psychiatric disturbances
  • Ocular Signs:
    • Kayser-Fleischer ring: Brownish-yellow golden copper deposits in the corneal Descemet membrane, visible on gonioscopy.
    • Sunflower cataract: Anterior capsular cataract in some patients.
  • Diagnosis:
    • Kayser-Fleischer rings detected on gonioscopy.
    • Serum Ceruloplasmin levels
  • Treatment: Penicillamine therapy can reduce copper deposits and improve symptoms.

Incorrect Options:

Alpha-1-antitrypsin (Option A): This is a protein associated with lung and liver diseases (like emphysema and cirrhosis), but it is not related to copper metabolism or Wilson's disease.

Alpha-fetoprotein (Option B): This is a tumor marker, often elevated in certain cancers or during pregnancy, but not associated with Wilson’s disease or corneal findings.

Serum iron (Option C): Elevated iron levels are associated with hemochromatosis or iron overload disorders, not with Wilson’s disease.

questions.text: A woman with endometrial carcinoma is undergoing radiotherapy. Which of the following is true?

choices.text: Intensity is inversely proportional to the square of the distance from the source
Small blood vessels are most radioresistant
Rapidly proliferating cells are most radioresistant
Small intestinal mucosa is most radio-resistant

questions.solution:
Correct answer: Option A) Intensity is inversely proportional to the square of the distance from the source

Explanation:

  • The inverse square law defines that the intensity is inversely proportional to the square of the distance from the source.
  • It is a principle of physics that states that the intensity of an effect such as illumination or gravitational force changes in inverse proportion to the square of the distance from the source.

Radiotherapy:

  • Radiation is a 'Double-edged sword' - it kills cancerous cells; it may also damage normal cells.
  • It kills cells by damaging DNA which produces free radicals.
  • Types: It depends on the source of radiation.
  • Two types:
    • Teletherapy: EBRT (External Beam Radiotherapy), source is at a distance,
    • Brachytherapy: source is nearer to the patient.
      • Brachytherapy is divided into 3 types:
        • Interstitial (into the tissue): Ca Prostate, Ca Breast
        • Intracavitatory (accessible cavity): Accessible tumors like Ca Cervix
        • Mold (Superficial cancers): Penis, Eye cancers

 

Small blood vessels are most radioresistant (Option B): Small blood vessels are not the most radioresistant. In fact, the vascular endothelium is relatively radiosensitive, and radiation can cause vascular damage leading to ischemia and necrosis.

Rapidly proliferating cells are most radioresistant (Option C): Rapidly proliferating cells are not the most radioresistant; in fact, they are more radiosensitive. The reason is that these cells are often in the process of dividing, and radiation damages DNA, disrupting the cell cycle and leading to cell death.

Small intestinal mucosa is most radio-resistant (Option D): Small intestinal mucosa is not the most radio-resistant. The cells of the small intestinal mucosa are rapidly dividing, making them more susceptible to radiation.

questions.text: A 40-year-old female patient came with complaints of chest pain, palpitation, and shortness of breath. On examination, a mid-diastolic murmur was heard, and a prominent 'a' wave was found on JVP. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Tricuspid stenosis

The combination of a mid-diastolic murmur and a prominent 'a' wave in the jugular venous pressure (JVP) suggests tricuspid stenosis (TS).

  • The mid-diastolic murmur, which can also occur in mitral stenosis, is best heard along the left sternal border and over the xiphoid process, increasing during inspiration due to enhanced venous return.
  • The prominent 'a' wave in JVP is a result of increased right atrial pressure, which impedes right atrial emptying during diastole, creating a giant 'a' wave.
  • ECG findings typically show right atrial enlargement, with tall, peaked P waves in leads II, III, and aVF.

Type

Cause

Features of Murmur

Associated Symptoms

JVP Findings

Aortic Regurgitation (AR)

Incomplete closure of the aortic valve, causing retrograde flow into LV.
  • Type: Diastolic decrescendo murmur.
  • Location: Best heard at left sternal border (3rd-4th ICS).
  • Features: High-pitched, decrescendo.
  • Bounding pulses
  • Wide pulse pressure
  • Water-Hammer pulse
  • Heart failure symptoms.

Normal or minimally elevated JVP unless associated with heart failure.

Aortic Stenosis (AS)

Narrowing of the aortic valve, obstructing LV outflow.
  • Type: Systolic ejection murmur.
  • Location: Best heard at right upper sternal border (2nd ICS), radiates to carotids.
  • Features: Crescendo-decrescendo.
  • Angina
  • Syncope
  • Left ventricular hypertrophy
  • Paradoxical S2 splitting.

Normal JVP unless severe.

Mitral Regurgitation (MR) (Option C)

Incomplete closure of the mitral valve, causing backflow from LV to LA.
  • Type: Pansystolic murmur.
  • Location: Best heard at the apex, radiates to the axilla.
  • Intensity: Grade II-IV, soft/absent S1 in chronic cases.
  • Dyspnea
  • Fatigue
  • Orthopnea
  • Atrial fibrillation.

Elevated JVP, prominent V wave due to regurgitant flow.

Mitral Stenosis (MS) (Option A)

Narrowing of the mitral valve, obstructing flow from LA to LV.
  • Type: Diastolic rumbling murmur.
  • Location: Best heard at apex in left lateral decubitus position.
  • Features: Low-pitched, with an opening snap after S2.
  • Dyspnea
  • Pulmonary hypertension
  • Right-sided heart failure
  • Atrial fibrillation.

Elevated JVP with prominent "a" wave due to increased atrial pressure.

Tricuspid Regurgitation (TR) (Option D)

Incomplete closure of the tricuspid valve, causing backflow into the right atrium.
  • Type: Pansystolic murmur.
  • Location: Best heard at the lower left sternal border.
  • Features: Holosystolic, blowing murmur.
  • Hepatomegaly
  • Ascites
  • Edema
  • Right-sided heart failure.

Elevated JVP with prominent "v" wave due to backflow into the right atrium.

Tricuspid Stenosis (TS)

Narrowing of the tricuspid valve, obstructing flow from RA to RV.
  • Type: Diastolic murmur.
  • Location: Best heard at the lower left sternal border.
  • Features: Low-pitched rumbling murmur.
  • Fatigue
  • Hepatomegaly
  • Ascites
  • Peripheral edema.

Elevated JVP with prominent "a" wave due to increased atrial pressure.

questions.text: The patient has a history of fever and cough for the last 5 days. The examination findings show crepitations, and a chest X-ray is shown below. Based on these details, what is the likely diagnosis for this patient?

choices.text: Apical segment of Right lower lobe consolidation
Posterior segment of right lower lobe consolidation

questions.solution:
Correct answer: Option B) Right middle lobe consolidation

Explanation:

  • The X-ray image shows a well-defined opacity in the right middle lobe, which is consistent with the description of pneumonia in the scenario. The loss of the right heart border indicates pathology in the right middle lobe or medial right lower lobe.
  • Pneumonia is typically associated with fever, cough, and crepitations on examination, which match the clinical picture given in this question.
  • The loss of clear demarcation between the surrounding structures and normal lung is called silhouette sign.

Lobar Localization:

  • Lateral radiograph: Right and left upper lobe bronchi can be seen as two circular radiolucent areas with the right above the left.
  • PA view of the chest: Can locate any structure in the superoinferior dimension as well as the mediolateral dimension.
  • Silhouette sign: Locate any structure in the posteroanterior dimension.
  • Left Lung: Only has an oblique fissure, separating the left upper (LUL) and lower (LLL) lobes.
  • Right Lung: Oblique and horizontal fissures separate the right lung's 3 lobes.
    • Oblique fissure divides the RML and RLL.
    • Horizontal fissure divides the RUL and RML.

 

Silhouette Sign:

  • Absence of the depiction of an anatomic soft-tissue border.
  • Produced by an intrathoracic abnormality that touches the borders of the heart or aorta and obliterates those borders on the frontal chest radiograph.
  • The sign actually refers to the absence of a silhouette.
  • Silhouette sign helps localize airspace opacities, atelectasis, or masses in the lung.
  • Loss of normal silhouettes on frontal chest radiographs indicates the site of pathology:
    • Right paratracheal stripe: Right upper lobe
    • Right heart border: Right middle lobe or medial right lower lobe (Option B)
    • Right hemidiaphragm: Right lower lobe
    • Aortic knuckle: Left upper lobe
    • Left heart border: Lingular segments of the left upper lobe
    • Left hemidiaphragm or descending aorta: Left lower lobe

questions.text: What dye and filter are used in the image, as shown below?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Fluorescein dye cobalt blue filter

Explanation:

Fluorescein sodium

  • Fluorescein penetrates poorly into the lipid layer of the corneal epithelium, and therefore, it does not stain normal cornea. Although fluorescein is a very effective stain for the diseased cornea, it is more difficult to detect fluorescein staining of the conjunctiva because of the poor scleral contrast. Fluorescein absorbs light in the blue spectrum (490 nm) and emits yellow-green light of a higher wavelength (530 nm), therefore staining can be more readily viewed if a cobalt blue or yellow (blue-free) filter is used. This combination is particularly useful for detecting corneal defects and ulcers.

Cobalt blue filter:

  • Cobalt blue is a filter that is commonly used in conjunction with fluorescein stain, as it enhances the fluorescence of fluorescein, making it easier to detect corneal defects. It absorbs light in the blue spectrum (around 490 nm) and helps the fluorescein stain emit a bright yellow-green fluorescence when illuminated.

Lissamine green dye

  • It has a high affinity for staining dead and degenerated cells, including mucous strands. The dye appears to stain areas where there are disrupted intercellular junctions. Use of a green (red-free) filter shows the stained areas to appear black in color. As it is better tolerated than rose bengal, it is the preferred dye for staining the bulbar conjunctiva.

Incorrect Options:

Lissamine green dye green filter (Option A):

  • Lissamine green stains dead or degenerated cells and mucous strands on the conjunctiva, not corneal defects.
  • A green filter is used with lissamine green because it enhances contrast, making stained areas appear black. It’s not effective for fluorescein.

Lissamine green dye cobalt blue filter (Option B):

  • Lissamine green doesn’t fluoresce, so a cobalt blue filter (which works with fluorescein) won’t enhance its staining.
  • Cobalt blue is useful for fluorescein fluorescence, not for lissamine green, which requires a green filter.

Fluorescein dye green filter (Option C):

  • Fluorescein works best with a cobalt blue filter for fluorescence, not a green filter. A green filter doesn’t enhance fluorescein’s fluorescence, making it less effective for detecting corneal defects.

questions.text: A patient who is a known case of hypertension on multiple antihypertensive medications came to the OPD. His ECG finding is given below. Which of the following drugs is responsible for the ECG finding?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer D) Spironolactone

  • The ECG finding of tall, peaked T waves suggests hyperkalemia. Among the listed medications, spironolactone is the drug most likely to cause hyperkalemia.

Mechanism of Spironolactone:

  • Spironolactone is a potassium-sparing diuretic. It works by blocking the mineralocorticoid receptor in the distal tubule and collecting duct of the kidneys, which inhibits sodium reabsorption and potassium excretion.
  • As a result, it promotes sodium diuresis but retains potassium, potentially leading to hyperkalemia.

ECG Changes in Hyperkalemia: Tall, peaked T waves are a classic ECG finding in hyperkalemia. As the potassium level rises, it affects the ST-T segments and can lead to changes in repolarization.

Serum Potassium Level (mEq/L)

ECG Changes

5.5–6.5

Tall, peaked T waves

6.5–7.5

Loss of P waves

7.0–8.0

Widened QRS complex

> 8.0

Sine wave pattern

Prazosin (Option A): This is an alpha-1 antagonist used in the treatment of hypertension and does not commonly cause hyperkalemia.

Metoprolol (Option B): This is a beta-blocker used for hypertension and cardiovascular issues. It does not typically cause hyperkalemia.

Hydrochlorothiazide (Option C): This is a thiazide diuretic, which actually promotes potassium loss and would more likely cause hypokalemia rather than hyperkalemia.

questions.text: A newborn presented with chest retractions, dyspnea, and lethargy. The pediatrician diagnosed the baby with respiratory distress syndrome. This occurs due to a deficiency of:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Lecithin

Explanation: Respiratory distress syndrome in a neonate is likely due to a deficiency of Lecithin.

Respiratory Distress Syndrome/Hyaline Membrane Disease (HMD):

  • It is a common respiratory condition in preterm infants (<34 weeks of gestation) caused by surfactant deficiency.
  • Pathophysiology:
    • Surfactant is primarily produced by type II alveolar cells and reduces surface tension, preventing alveolar collapse at the end of expiration.
    • Surfactant is composed of phospholipids, proteins, and lipids.
    • Phosphatidylcholine, also known as lecithin, is a significant phospholipid in mature surfactants.
    • Its production begins around 20 weeks of gestation and peaks at 35 weeks, so infants born before 35 weeks are at higher risk for RDS due to insufficient surfactant.
    • Without adequate surfactant, alveoli collapse during expiration, impairing gas exchange and causing tissue hypoxia. This results in increased pulmonary pressure, ischemic damage, and the formation of a hyaline membrane from protein transudation.
  • Clinical Features: Respiratory distress within the first 6 hours of life is characterised by tachypnea, retractions, grunting, cyanosis, and decreased air entry.
  • Typical X-ray findings in RDS include:
    • Ground glass haziness of lungs: Represents diffuse alveolar atelectasis, commonly seen in RDS.
    • Presence of air bronchogram: Air-filled bronchi are visible against the hazy, collapsed alveoli, a classic feature of RDS. Air bronchogram can be seen in parenchymal pathology of the lung, such as consolidation, pulmonary alveolar proteinosis.
    • Reticulogranular pattern: Another term for the ground-glass appearance, indicating the fine, granular pattern throughout the lungs characteristic of RDS.
  • Management:
    • Neonates with this condition require admission to the neonatal intensive care unit, IV fluids, and appropriate respiratory support.
    • Further management details are depicted in the table below,

 

Dipalmitoyl inositol (Option A): While it serves as a precursor in secondary messenger systems and plays roles in cell signaling and membrane trafficking, it is not involved in surfactant production or the prevention of respiratory distress syndrome.
 

Sphingomyelin (Option C) is the dominant sphingolipid in the plasma membrane. The lecithin/sphingomyelin (L/S) ratio in amniotic fluid is a marker of fetal lung maturity, but sphingomyelin itself does not directly contribute to alveolar stability.
 

Dipalmitoylphosphatidylethanolamine (Option D): Found in cell membranes, it lacks the essential surface tension-reducing properties of dipalmitoylphosphatidylcholine (lecithin), which is crucial for preventing alveolar collapse and respiratory distress syndrome.

questions.text: Which of the following refractive errors is associated with the image given below?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Astigmatism

Explanation:

  • Astigmatism is a refractive error caused by an irregular shape of the cornea or lens, leading to blurred or distorted vision. This results in multiple focal points instead of a single point of focus on the retina.
  • The image shows irregular, blurry distorted vision or varying focal points and is typically associated with astigmatism, where light entering the eye is refracted unevenly.

Astigmatism

  • A refractive error where the eye's refraction varies across different meridians.
  • As a result, light rays entering the eye do not converge to a single point, instead form focal lines.

Regular Astigmatism
  • Refractive power changes uniformly from one meridian to another. There are 2 principal meridians.
    • Oblique Astigmatism- two principal meridians are not horizontal and vertical but are at right angles to each other (e.g., 45° and 135°).
    • Bioblique Astigmatism- two principal meridians are not at right angles to each other (e.g., one at 30° and the other at 100°).

Irregular Astigmatism
  • Irregular change in refractive power in different meridians, with multiple meridians that do not admit geometrical analysis

Incorrect Options:

Presbyopia (Option A): This is an age-related condition where the eye's ability to focus on near objects decreases, typically around age 40. It causes difficulty in reading or seeing close objects, but it's not associated with distorted vision like astigmatism.

Hypermetropia (Option C) (Farsightedness): In hypermetropia, distant objects are seen clearly, but near objects appear blurry. This is due to a shorter eyeball or less curved cornea, not irregular refraction.

Myopia (Option D) (Nearsightedness): In myopia, nearby objects are seen clearly, but distant objects appear blurry, typically due to a longer eyeball or steeper cornea. It does not cause distorted vision as seen in astigmatism.

questions.text:
A 10-year-old child weighing 30 kg presents with a history of loose stools for 2 days. On examination, there is severe dehydration. Laboratory investigations are as follows. What is the initial management as per ISPAD guidelines?


	
		
			
			RBS
			
			
			550 mg/dL
			
		
		
			
			pH
			
			
			7.01
			
		
		
			
			Na+
			
			
			158 mEq/L
			
		
		
			
			Urine glucose
			
			
			3+

choices.text: Manage ABC, NS 20 mL/kg and start insulin after 1 hour
Manage ABC, NS 20 mL/kg along with insulin 0.1 IU/kg/hr
Manage ABC, NS 10 mL/kg along with insulin 0.1 IU/kg/hr
Manage ABC, NS 10 mL/kg and start insulin after 1 hour

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Manage ABC, NS 20 mL/kg and start insulin after 1 hour

Explanation:

  • 10-year-old, 30 kg child

  • Severe dehydration

  • Hyperglycaemia (RBS = 550 mg/dL)

  • Acidosis (pH = 7.01)

  • Hypernatremia (Na⁺ = 158 mEq/L)

  • Glucosuria

This is a case of Diabetic Ketoacidosis (DKA) with severe dehydration, likely precipitated by diarrhoea.

ISPAD Guidelines – Initial Management of DKA:

  • ABC Stabilisation: Always assess and stabilise airway, breathing, and circulation first.

  • Fluid Resuscitation:

    • In severe dehydration or shock, give 0.9% Normal Saline (NS) 10–20 mL/kg over 1–2 hours.

    • In this case (30 kg child with severe dehydration), give 20 mL/kg → 600 mL NS bolus.

  • Insulin:

    • Do not start insulin immediately.

    • Begin insulin infusion after at least 1 hour of fluid resuscitation, to avoid rapid shifts in osmolality and risk of cerebral oedema.

    • Dose: 0.05–0.1 IU/kg/hour, IV infusion.

Diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA):

  • DKA is a frequent complication in children and adolescents with type 1 or type 2 diabetes mellitus.
  • Clinical signs:
    • Dehydration
    • Tachycardia and tachypnea
    • Kussmaul respiration: Deep sighing respiration with a ketotic breath odor (like nail polish remover or rotten fruit).
    • Gastrointestinal symptoms: Nausea, vomiting, and abdominal pain.
    • Neurological symptoms: Confusion, drowsiness, progressive loss of consciousness.
  • Biochemical criteria for DKA diagnosis:
    • Hyperglycemia: Blood glucose >11 mmol/L or ≥200 mg/dL.
    • Acidosis: Venous: pH <7.3 and/or bicarbonate <15 mmol/L.
    • Ketosis:
      • Ketonemia: Blood β-hydroxybutyrate concentration ≥3 mmol/L.
      • Ketonuria: Moderate or large ketones in urine.

DKA Management in Children

Immediate Management (First Hour):

Rapid Assessment:
  • Evaluate the child's vital signs (heart rate, respiratory rate, blood pressure) and weight.
  • Assess GCS and check for signs of dehydration.
  • Obtain blood samples for urgent measurement of blood glucose, blood beta-hydroxybutyrate (BHB) if available, venous pH, electrolytes (including bicarbonate), serum urea nitrogen, and creatinine.
  • Serum BHB concentration: Most precise approach to measuring the severity of DKA

Establish IV Access:

Place two large-bore peripheral IV lines. Central lines are generally avoided (risk of thrombosis) unless necessary.

Initial Fluid Resuscitation

Administer a bolus of 0.9% saline at a rate of 10-20 ml/kg over 20-30 minutes to restore circulatory volume and address dehydration.

After First Hour

Initiate Insulin Therapy

Start an intravenous insulin infusion at 0.05-0.1 U/kg/h, typically one hour after initiating fluids.

Continue Fluid Therapy

 

After the initial bolus, continue fluid replacement with 0.45% to 0.9% saline, to replace the estimated fluid deficit over 24 to 48 hours. Adjust fluids based on clinical status and laboratory values.

Monitoring and Replacing Electrolytes
  • Begin potassium replacement once urine output is confirmed as insulin causes K+ entry into cells, leading to hypokalemia.
  • Monitor vital signs, GCS, fluid balance, and capillary blood glucose every hour.
  • Reassess electrolytes, blood glucose, blood urea nitrogen, calcium, magnesium, phosphate, blood gases, and BOHB every two hours if available.

Transition Phase (6-24 Hours):

Gradual Reduction of IV Fluids and

transition to subcutaneous Insulin

 
  • As DKA resolves and the child can tolerate oral intake, gradually reduce IV fluids while maintaining hydration.
  • Transition to subcutaneous insulin once pH > 7.30, bicarbonate > 18 mmol/L, and BOHB < 1 mmol/L.
  • Administer the first subcutaneous insulin dose 15-30 minutes before discontinuing the IV insulin infusion.

 

 

NS 20 mL/kg along with insulin immediately (Option B): Starting insulin at the same time as the fluid bolus is contraindicated in ISPAD guidelines. Can increase risk of cerebral oedema.

NS 10 mL/kg along with insulin immediately (Option C): Both inadequate fluid volume for severe dehydration and early insulin → not appropriate.

NS 10 mL/kg and insulin after 1 hour (Option D): Correct insulin timing, but underestimates fluid need for severe dehydration → volume should be 20 mL/kg.

questions.text: A 78-year-old woman presents with a progressive decline in daily activity. She gives a history of convulsions and visual hallucinations. She does not talk to anyone and keeps looking at the sky. Pathological examination shows the presence of Lewy bodies within the neurons. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Parkinson's disease

  • This patient's symptoms, including progressive decline in daily activities, convulsions, visual hallucinations, and the presence of Lewy bodies on pathological examination, point toward Parkinson's disease.

Parkinson's Disease: Parkinson's disease is a neurodegenerative disorder caused by the degeneration of dopaminergic neurons in the substantia nigra.

Pathological examination reveals Lewy bodies, which are proteinaceous inclusions found in neurons, particularly in the substantia nigra. These are composed of alpha-synuclein and are characteristic of Parkinson's disease.

Clinical features include rigidity, resting tremor, bradykinesia, and postural instability. In later stages, non-motor symptoms like cognitive decline, visual hallucinations, sleep disturbances, and depression can occur, which align with the symptoms observed in this patient.

Treatment typically includes levodopa with a peripheral decarboxylase inhibitor (like carbidopa), dopamine agonists (e.g., pramipexole, ropinirole), and MAO-B inhibitors (e.g., selegiline, rasagiline).

Classification of Dementia

Type of Dementia

Description

Clinical Findings

Alzheimer's Disease (AD) (Option D)

Most common type of dementia, characterized by amyloid plaques and tau tangles in the brain.
  • Memory loss, especially short-term memory
  • Disorientation
  • Language difficulties
  • Impaired judgment and reasoning
  • Personality changes
  • Progressive cognitive decline2

Vascular Dementia

Results from damage to blood vessels in the brain, leading to reduced blood flow. Often follows a stroke or series of small strokes.
  • Stepwise progression of cognitive decline
  • Memory loss
  • Impaired executive function
  • Gait disturbances
  • Personality and mood changes
  • Signs of previous strokes (e.g., hemiparesis)

Lewy Body Dementia

Caused by abnormal protein deposits (Lewy bodies) in the brain, affecting cognitive and motor functions.
  • Visual hallucinations
  • Parkinsonism (e.g., tremor, rigidity)
  • Cognitive fluctuations
  • Memory impairment
  • REM sleep behavior disorder

Frontotemporal Dementia (FTD)

Characterized by degeneration in the frontal and temporal lobes, often with personality and behavioral changes.
  • Personality and behavior changes (e.g., disinhibition, apathy)
  • Language difficulties (e.g., aphasia)
  • Lack of empathy
  • Impulsive behaviors
  • Social withdrawal

Mixed Dementia

A combination of Alzheimer's disease and vascular dementia. Common in elderly patients.
  • Symptoms of both Alzheimer's and vascular dementia
  • Cognitive decline with stepwise progression
  • Memory problems
  • Behavioral changes
  • Motor problems (e.g., gait disturbances)

Parkinson's Disease Dementia

Occurs in patients with Parkinson's disease, typically years after motor symptoms begin.
  • Memory loss
  • Cognitive impairment
  • Attention deficits
  • Executive dysfunction
  • Visual hallucinations
  • Parkinsonism (e.g., bradykinesia, tremor)

Huntington's Disease

(Option C)

Genetic disorder characterized by progressive motor, cognitive, and psychiatric decline.
  • Involuntary movements (chorea)
  • Memory impairment
  • Personality changes (e.g., irritability, depression)
  • Impaired coordination and motor function
  • Progressive dementia

Creutzfeldt-Jakob Disease (CJD)

(Option B)

Rare prion disease causing rapid neurodegeneration, often with fatal progression.
  • Rapid onset of dementia
  • Motor symptoms (e.g., ataxia, myoclonus)
  • Visual disturbances
  • Psychiatric symptoms (e.g., depression)
  • Death usually within 1-2 years

Wernicke-Korsakoff Syndrome

Caused by thiamine deficiency, often due to alcohol abuse. Can lead to brain damage and dementia.
  • Amnesia (anterograde and retrograde)
  • Confabulation
  • Ataxia
  • Nystagmus
  • Neurological abnormalities due to thiamine deficiency

Normal Pressure Hydrocephalus (NPH)

A condition where excess cerebrospinal fluid accumulates in the brain ventricles, leading to cognitive decline.
  • Gait disturbances (shuffling walk)
  • Urinary incontinence
  • Dementia
  • Enlargement of the ventricles on brain imaging

questions.text: What is the probable diagnosis for an infant brought in with symptoms of excessive tear production, sensitivity to light, and blepharospasm?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Congenital glaucoma

Explanation:

  • True Congenital Glaucoma is characterized by elevated intraocular pressure present during intrauterine life, resulting in ocular enlargement at birth.
  • The presence of Haab’s striae, early onset, enlarged corneas, and the classic triad of symptoms (watering, photophobia, and blepharospasm) are all consistent with newborn glaucoma.

Primary Congenital Glaucoma

Types

1. Newborn glaucoma/ True congenital glaucoma: Elevated intraocular pressure is present during intrauterine life, resulting in ocular enlargement at birth. (40% cases)

Typically presents within the first month of life.

Often associated with developmental anomalies of the anterior segment, such as primary congenital glaucoma, which can result from genetic mutations or other congenital conditions.

2. Infantile: ≤ 3 yrs of age- Infantile glaucoma is labelled when the disease manifests prior to the child's third birthday

Affects infants older than 1 month and children up to 3 years.

Can also result from genetic factors or be secondary to other conditions like Sturge-Weber syndrome or other syndromic associations.

3. Juvenile: > 3 yrs of age who develop pressure rise after 3 years but before adulthood. Also known as Juvenile primary open angle glaucoma(POAG) usually occurs between 10 to 35 years of age.

Buphthalmos, meaning "bull-like eyes," is a condition characterized by the enlargement of the eyeball. It typically manifests before the age of 3 years and results from the accumulation and retention of aqueous humor.

Pathogenesis
  • Trabeculodysgenesis: Maldevelopment of the trabeculum and iridotrabecular junction from neural crest cells impairs aqueous outflow, causing elevated IOP.
  • Angle Recess Absence: The angle recess is absent, with the iris inserting either flatly or concavely into the trabeculum.
  • Iris Insertion Types:
    • Flat Insertion: Reveals the ciliary body and scleral spur.
    • Concave Insertion: Obscures the scleral spur and ciliary body.

Clinical Features

Classic Triad: Lacrimation, photophobia, and blepharospasm; often accompanied by eye rubbing.

Corneal Signs:

  • Oedema: Early sign, may progress to permanent opacity.
  • Enlargement: Corneal diameter >13 mm confirms enlargement; >16 mm indicates poor prognosis.

Haab’s Striae: Tears in Descemet's membrane, visible as opaque lines.

Additional Features:

  • Thin Sclera: Appears blue due to underlying uveal tissue.
  • Deep Anterior Chamber: Indicates elevated IOP.
  • Iris Changes: Iridodonesis and atrophic patches in late stages.
  • Lens Changes: Becomes flat and may subluxate.
  • Optic Disc Changes: Variable cupping and atrophy.
  • Raised IOP: Elevated but not acute.
  • Axial Myopia: Due to increased axial length.

Incorrect Options:

Congenital Cataract (Option B): Causes a cloudy lens and poor vision, but doesn’t typically cause excessive tearing, light sensitivity, or blepharospasm.

Congenital Dacryocystitis (Option C): Leads to tearing and discharge from a blocked tear duct but doesn’t cause light sensitivity or blepharospasm.

Ophthalmia Neonatorum (Option D): Involves eye redness and discharge due to infection at birth, but doesn’t cause light sensitivity or spasms.

questions.text: Which of the following is the best sign to indicate adequate growth in an infant with a birth weight of 2.8 kg?

choices.text: Increase in length of 25 cm in the first year
Weight gain of 300 grams per month till 1 year
Anterior fontanelle closure by 6 months of age
Weight under the 75th percentile and height under the 25th percentile

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Increase in length of 25 cm in the first year

Explanation: The best indicator of adequate growth in an infant is an increase in length of 25 cm in the first year.

  • Normal length at birth: 50cm.
  • In the first year, there is an increase of 25cm, so at 1 year the height is 75cm.
  • In the second year there is an increase of 10-15cm, so at 2 years the height is 85-90cm.
  • There is a steady increase of 6cm/year till 12 years.
  • Height doubles by 4 years
  • Height triples by 12 years
  • Half of adult height in a normal child (80-85cm) is achieved by 2 years (18-24 months).
Age Length

At birth

50cm

By 3 months

60cm

By 9 months

70cm

By 1 year

75cm

At 2 years

90cm

At 4-4.5 years

100cm

 

Weech's formula to estimate the expected weight and height of children using age as a variable.

For <1 year :

x + 9 ÷ 2 ( Where x is age in months )

For 1-6 years :

2x + 8 ( Where x is age in years )

For 7-12 years :

7x - 5 ÷ 2 ( Where x is age in years )

 

Weight gain of 300 grams per month till 1 year (Option B): In the first few months, weight gain typically varies from 20-40 grams per day, and after 4 months, it increases to approximately 400 grams per month, with doubling at 5 months and tripling by 1 year.

Anterior fontanelle closure by 6 months of age (Option C): The anterior fontanelle typically closes between 9 and 18 months, not by 6 months, making it an unreliable indicator for growth.

Weight under the 75th percentile and height under the 25th percentile (Option D): Percentiles are used to compare an infant’s growth measurements with a reference population. However, being under the 75th percentile for weight and under the 25th percentile for height does not guarantee adequate growth.

questions.text: A patient came to medical OPD with complaints of polyuria. He has a history of undergoing total hypophysectomy. His Na+ levels were found to be 155 mEq/L, and his urine osmolarity was 200 mOsm/L. What is the definitive management in this patient?

choices.text: DDAVP for 2 weeks and then discontinue
Upsetting of receptors, so no treatment required

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) DDAVP supplementation for lifelong

This patient's clinical presentation and history are consistent with central diabetes insipidus (DI), which results from insufficient vasopressin (antidiuretic hormone, ADH) secretion due to total hypophysectomy (removal of the pituitary gland). Key findings supporting this diagnosis include:

  • Polyuria (excessive urination) and low urine osmolarity (200 mOsm/L) indicate dilute urine, characteristic of diabetes insipidus.
  • Hypernatremia (Na⁺ = 155 mEq/L) suggests dehydration, commonly seen in DI due to impaired water retention.

Definitive management for central diabetes insipidus due to total hypophysectomy is lifelong desmopressin (DDAVP) supplementation.

  • DDAVP is a synthetic analogue of vasopressin that helps reduce urine output and prevent dehydration. This treatment is required for the patient to manage the symptoms of DI and maintain fluid balance.

DDAVP for 2 weeks and then discontinue (Option A): This is not appropriate for complete hypophysectomy, where the deficiency of vasopressin is permanent. Short-term DDAVP would only be used in cases where the deficiency is transient (e.g., partial hypophysectomy).

Upsetting of receptors, so no treatment required (Option C): In central diabetes insipidus, the issue is the lack of vasopressin, not receptor dysfunction. Without treatment, the patient would experience chronic dehydration and electrolyte imbalances.

Thiazides for 2 weeks (Option D): Thiazide diuretics may be used in nephrogenic diabetes insipidus (due to kidney resistance to ADH), but they are not effective in central DI, where the problem lies in vasopressin production, not renal response.

questions.text: What is the term used to describe the refractive error seen in the ocular examination image of a 60-year-old patient who has complained of reduced distant vision, but no longer requires spectacles for near vision?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Index myopia

Explanation:

  • Myopia = shortsightedness- refractive error where parallel rays of light from distant objects focus in front of the retina when the eye's accommodation is relaxed.
  • Index myopia is a condition that often occurs in older individuals, typically associated with age-related changes in the lens. As we age, the lens of the eye becomes denser and less flexible, which can lead to myopia (nearsightedness) in some cases.
  • The patient has reduced distant vision (a hallmark of myopia) but no longer needs glasses for near vision, which suggests that the lens has become more myopic (thicker or more curved) and is compensating for the near vision loss that typically occurs with presbyopia.
  • Index myopia is usually caused by the increase in refractive index of the lens with age, making it more myopic, particularly for distance vision.

Type of Myopia

Cause

Axial Myopia

Increase in the anteroposterior length of the eyeball (most common form).

Curvatural Myopia

Increased curvature of the cornea, lens, or both.

Positional Myopia

Anterior placement of the crystalline lens in the eye.

Index Myopia

Increase in the refractive index of the crystalline lens, often due to nuclear sclerosis.

Myopia due to Excessive Accommodation

Caused by spasm of accommodation, leading to excessive focusing power.

 

Clinical features

  • Asthenopic symptoms
  • Half-shutting of eyes for better clarity
  • Prominent eyeball.
  • Prominent, large, and somewhat sluggishly reacting pupils.
  • Slightly deeper anterior chamber.
  • Normal fundus; rarely a temporal myopic crescent may be seen.

Treatment
  • Prescription of appropriate concave lenses
  • Surgical Treatment

Incorrect Options:

Axial myopia (Option B): Caused by an elongated eyeball. This typically leads to myopia from birth or early in life and doesn’t relate to the lens changes seen with aging.

Curvatural myopia (Option C): Caused by a change in the curvature of the cornea, which affects the focusing power of the eye. It’s not related to the age-related changes in the lens.

Positional myopia (Option D): Refers to a refractive error caused by the position of the eye or the viewing distance (e.g., looking through different parts of the lens or an unusual gaze position). It's not linked to aging lens changes like index myopia.

questions.text: A 3-month-old baby comes with complaints of deafness, cataract, and patent ductus arteriosus. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Congenital rubella syndrome

Explanation:

  • The clinical presentation of deafness, cataract, and patent ductus arteriosus in an infant is most suggestive of Congenital rubella syndrome.

Congenital rubella
  • Rubella (German measles) is a mild disease in infants and children but can cause congenital rubella syndrome (CRS) if contracted during pregnancy.
  • The risk is highest in the first trimester, especially within the first 8 weeks.

Pathogenesis

  • Viremia is most intense from 10 to 17 days after infection.
  • Viral shedding is from day 10 of infection up to 2 weeks.

Risk of Defects by Gestational Age
  • Highest in the first 12 weeks of gestation and decreases significantly thereafter, with defects being rare after 20 weeks.

Clinical features of congenital rubella syndrome
  • Sensorineural hearing loss (SNHL) (most common)
  • Vision problems (cataracts, glaucoma, salt and pepper retinopathy).
    • Cataracts are the most common ocular abnormality associated with congenital rubella.

\

  • Heart defects (patent ductus arteriosus > pulmonary artery stenosis (right > left) > ventricular septal defect)
  • Low birth weight
  • Neurological issues (microcephaly, intellectual disabilities, encephalitis, behavioral issues)

Chronicity and Complications
  • Chronic presence of the virus can cause ongoing damage
  • The risk of progressive rubella panencephalitis (PRP) years later is a rare complication.
  • Less common complications: Growth retardation, hepatitis, bone lesions.
  • Risk of diabetes and thyroid dysfunction

Diagnosis
  • Rubella IgM enzyme immunosorbent assay (detects antibodies)
  • Viral isolation (growing the virus from samples)
  • Polymerase chain reaction (PCR) (detects viral RNA)

Management
  • No specific treatment for CRS; supportive care is key
  • Early intervention for complications (e.g., hearing loss) is crucial

Prevention
  • Standard with droplet precaution in hospitalized cases
  • Rubella vaccination RA 27/3 live attenuated vaccine (MMR or MMRV with varicella) effectively prevents rubella and CRS
  • MMR vaccine has a 95% efficacy after one dose and 99% after two doses
  • Vaccination side effects: fever, rash, joint pain

Considerations for Pregnant Women
  • Immunoglobulin may be considered if pregnancy is not terminated, though it does not guarantee prevention of fetal infection

 

Congenital herpes simplex virus infection (Option A) can be transmitted in utero, during delivery, or in the neonatal period. Intrauterine infection leads to skin vesicles, eye abnormalities such as chorioretinitis and keratoconjunctivitis, and neurological complications like microcephaly or hydranencephaly. Infection acquired at birth can present as localized disease affecting the skin, eyes, and mouth, as encephalitis, or as disseminated infection resembling neonatal sepsis.

Congenital toxoplasmosis (Option B) results from maternal infection, particularly during pregnancy. The severity depends on the timing of transmission, with early pregnancy infections leading to more severe outcomes, while later infections tend to be milder. The classic presentation includes a triad of chorioretinitis, hydrocephalus, and intracranial calcifications.

Congenital cytomegalovirus (CMV) infection (Option C) is often acquired when maternal infection occurs during pregnancy, with the highest transmission risk in the third trimester. Affected newborns may have growth restriction, microcephaly, periventricular calcifications, chorioretinitis, developmental delays, hepatosplenomegaly, hemolytic anemia, and thrombocytopenia. While many neonates are asymptomatic at birth, sensorineural hearing loss is a common long-term complication.

questions.text: A 65-year-old chronic smoker came to the medicine outpatient department with complaints of upper chest discomfort and drooping of an eyelid. He also complained of pain radiating to the upper arm and a tingling sensation in the 4th and 5th digits of his right hand. The chest X-ray is given below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Pancoast tumor

  • This patient's clinical presentation, combined with the findings from the chest X-ray, points towards the Pancoast tumor, a form of lung cancer that occurs in the apex (upper part) of the lung.

Pancoast Tumor: A Pancoast tumor, also known as a superior sulcus tumor, is a type of lung cancer that arises in the apex of the lung, often extending to involve nearby structures, including the chest wall, nerves, and blood vessels. These tumors are typically non-small cell lung cancers (NSCLC), most commonly squamous cell carcinoma or adenocarcinoma, strongly associated with smoking, which is a major risk factor.

 

Clinical Presentation

The symptoms of a Pancoast tumor are primarily due to the tumor's location rather than systemic effects of lung cancer.

Pain: Severe shoulder, arm, or chest wall pain is common due to invasion of the brachial plexus (C8-T2 nerve roots).

Horner's Syndrome: Results from sympathetic chain involvement, characterized by:

  • Ptosis (drooping eyelid)
  • Miosis (pupil constriction)
  • Anhidrosis (loss of sweating on the affected side)

Weakness and Atrophy: Weakness of the hand muscles and atrophy, due to compression of the lower brachial plexus.

Other Symptoms: Cough, hemoptysis, and weight loss may be present if the disease is more advanced.

Diagnosis

Imaging:

  • Chest X-ray: May show an apical mass.
  • MRI (IOC): Provides detailed information about local invasion into nearby structures.

Biopsy: Confirms histological diagnosis.

PET Scan: Assesses metastasis.

 

Management

  • Radiotherapy: Preoperatively to shrink the tumor.
  • Surgery: For resectable tumors, such as lobectomy or chest wall resection.
  • Chemotherapy: For advanced or unresectable tumors.

Superior vena cava obstruction (Option B): This condition can occur due to a tumor compressing the superior vena cava, causing swelling of the face, neck, and upper limbs, but it would not explain the combination of ptosis and pain radiating to the arm. It is usually associated with anterior mediastinal tumors, not typically with Pancoast tumors.

Upper lobe pneumonia (Option C): Pneumonia could cause chest discomfort and radiographic findings, but it would not explain the drooping eyelid (ptosis) or neurological symptoms in the arm. Pneumonia would also show consolidation on a chest X-ray, not a mass.

Aspergilloma (Option D): Aspergilloma is a fungal infection that typically occurs in pre-existing lung cavities (e.g., after tuberculosis). It could cause chest pain and cough, but it would not explain the ptosis or brachial plexus symptoms. The chest X-ray would typically show a fungal ball within a pre-existing cavity.

questions.text: Chloride level in sweat is used in the diagnosis of which disease:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Cystic fibrosis

Explanation: Chloride level in sweat is used to diagnose cystic fibrosis.

Cystic fibrosis is an autosomal recessive disorder caused by a mutation in the CFTR gene located on chromosome 7q32.

Diagnostic Criteria for Cystic Fibrosis (CF):

  • Presence of one or more phenotypic features (or)
  • A history of Cystic Fibrosis in a sibling (or)
  • A positive neonatal screening test - Dried blood is checked for immunoreactive trypsinogen.

Plus

Laboratory evidence for CFTR (Cystic Fibrosis transmembrane regulator) dysfunction:

  • Two elevated sweat chloride concentrations (highly specific test) obtained at separate labs > 60 mEq/L (or)
  • Identification of two Cystic Fibrosis mutations by DNA sequencing (or)
  • An abnormal transepithelial nasal potential difference measurement

Investigations:

  1. Sweat Chloride Test:
    • The gold standard for CF diagnosis, especially in symptomatic patients.
    • Pilocarpine iontophoresis is used to stimulate sweat production, and chloride concentration is measured.
    • A chloride concentration of:
      • ≥60 mmol/L confirms CF in children and adults.
      • 30-59 mmol/L indicates intermediate results, requiring further evaluation.
    • In CF- sweat chloride levels are increased, while chloride levels are decreased in pancreatic secretions.
  2. Genetic Testing:
    • Genetic testing, particularly for the common F508del mutation, is conducted if CF is suspected.
    • Expanded genetic panels may include hundreds of mutations but are often limited in efficacy for rare variants.
  3. Nasal Potential Difference (NPD):
    • This test measures the bioelectric properties of the respiratory epithelium, reflecting CFTR function.
    • In CF, defective chloride and sodium transport leads to abnormal potential differences.
    • NPD testing is helpful when sweat chloride tests are inconclusive and can provide a more direct assessment of CFTR functionality.
  4. Other Tests:
    • Fecal Elastase: Used to evaluate pancreatic exocrine function, which is impaired in CF.
    • Chest Imaging: Although not diagnostic, imaging can assess lung disease severity, showing bronchiectasis and hyperinflation common in CF patients.
    • Transepithelial Intestinal and Rectal Biopsies: These can be used to directly evaluate CFTR function, though they are generally reserved for research or challenging cases.
    • Serum electrolytes - hyponatremic, hypokalemic, hypochloremic alkalosis are seen in CF (contraction alkalosis)

 

Phenylketonuria (Option A) is caused by a deficiency in phenylalanine hydroxylase, leading to high levels of phenylalanine. It is diagnosed by measuring plasma phenylalanine concentration, not by sweat chloride testing.

Gaucher’s disease (Option C) results from a deficiency of ß-glucosidase, and diagnosis is made by testing ß-glucosidase activity in fibroblasts or leukocytes, along with genetic testing, not by sweat chloride levels.

Osteogenesis imperfecta (Option D) is caused by mutations in type-1 collagen genes, and it is diagnosed through genetic testing or DNA sequencing, not through sweat chloride measurement.

questions.text: A child presents with fever and a rash spreading from the face, behind cheeks and buccal mucosa to other body parts. On examination, Koplik's spot is present. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Measles

Explanation: The clinical scenario of fever, rash spreading from the face to other body parts, and the presence of Koplik's spots in a child points towards a diagnosis of measles.

Measles:

Aspects

Description

Causative agent

Measles (rubeola) is a highly communicable childhood exanthematous illness caused by the measles virus, an RNA virus from the Paramyxoviridae family.

Transmission

Contact with droplet aerosols (through the respiratory tract or conjunctiva)

Pathogenesis

Primary viremia occurs, resulting in infection of the reticuloendothelial system, followed by secondary viremia, which results in systemic symptoms.

Incubation period

8-12 days

Period of infectivity

From 3 days before to 4 days after the rash onset

Clinical manifestations
  • Common in preschool children
  • Prodromal phase: Fever (before rash), rhinorrhea, conjunctival congestion and a dry hacking cough.
  • Koplik spots, pathognomonic for measles, appear on the 2nd or 3rd day of illness as grey-white, sand-like lesions with surrounding erythema on the buccal mucosa opposite the lower second molars.

Rash

The erythematous maculopapular rash in measles appears on the 4th day, starting behind the ears, along the hairline, and posterior cheeks, then spreading to the rest of the body over the next 2-3 days.

Management

Symptomatic and conservative (antipyretics, maintenance of hygiene, ensuring adequate fluid and caloric intake, and humidification).

 

Rubella (Option B) presents with low-grade fever, a centrifugal macular rash, and prominent lymphadenopathy, with tiny rose-colored lesions on the soft palate (Forchheimer spots), which are different from Koplik's spots seen in measles.

Varicella (Option C) presents with a characteristic pruritic rash that evolves in stages (macules, papules, vesicles, and crusts) and does not present with Koplik's spots.

Mumps (Option D) presents with fever, headache, parotitis, and ipsilateral auricular pain, with a morbilliform rash that may occur, but it is not associated with Koplik's spots.

questions.text: A 3-week-old infant presents with a cough and sore throat. The mother reports that the infant develops a paroxysm of cough followed by apnea. The total leukocyte count is >50,000 cells/μL. Which of the following drugs will you prescribe for this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Azithromycin

Explanation:

  • An infant presenting with paroxysmal cough, apnea, and marked leukocytosis (>50,000 cells/μL) is suggestive of pertussis (whooping cough). Azithromycin is the first-line treatment for pertussis in all age groups.

Pertussis

Causative agent

Bordetella pertussis, Bordetella parapertussis

Secondary attack rate

100%

Clinical Stages
  1. Catarrhal (1-2 weeks): Cold-like symptoms, worsening cough
  2. Paroxysmal (2-6 weeks): Severe cough, "whoop", vomiting
  3. Convalescent (1-4 weeks): Recovery

Complications

Apnea, Otitis media, Pneumonia, Pulmonary hypertension, Cardiogenic shock, Hemorrhage, Seizures, hernia and malnutrition.

Diagnosis

Clinical signs, nasopharyngeal swab culture, PCR, serology.

Differential Diagnosis

Adenoviral infection, TB, foreign body inhalation, airway compression.

Management

 

First-line antibiotics for treating pertussis:

  • Azithromycin is the first-line treatment for pertussis in all age groups.
  • Erythromycin and clarithromycin are alternative treatments but are C/I in <1 month old due to risk for infantile hypertrophic pyloric stenosis (IHPS). (Option D)

Alternative antibiotics: For patients allergic to macrolides or there is unavailability of azithromycin, trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole (cotrimoxazole) may be used, but it is C/I in <2 months old (due to the risk for kernicterus) (Option C)

Timing of treatment: Antibiotics are most effective during the catarrhal stage

Isolation: Patients diagnosed with pertussis should be isolated from others, especially vulnerable populations like infants and the elderly, for at least 5 days after starting antibiotics.

Prevention

DTaP vaccine (Diphtheria, Tetanus, and Pertussis): Given to children under 7 years of age as part of routine childhood vaccinations.

 

Tdap vaccine (Tetanus, Diphtheria, and Pertussis): Recommended for adolescents, adults, and pregnant women (preferably between 27 and 36 weeks gestation) to provide protection and reduce transmission to infants.

Amoxicillin (Option B) is not used in pertussis because it is ineffective against Bordetella pertussis in the nasopharynx.

questions.text: A child is brought to the hospital with respiratory distress and biphasic stridor. The radiograph is shown below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Acute laryngotracheobronchitis

Explanation:

  • A child with biphasic stridor and respiratory distress are hallmark features of acute laryngotracheobronchitis.

Laryngotracheobronchitis (Croup):

Refers to viral infection of the glottic and subglottic regions.

Causative Agent
