  • Parainfluenza viruses (types 1,2 and 3) cause about 75% cases.
  • Other Viruses:
    • Influenza A and B
    • Adenovirus
    • Respiratory syncytial virus
    • Measles

Age Group
  • Most common in children aged 3 months to 5 years.
  • Peak incidence occurs in the 2nd year of life.

Initial Symptoms

These symptoms last 1-3 days before development of upper airway obstruction signs and symptoms.

  • Upper Respiratory tract infection
  • Rhinorrhea
  • Pharyngitis
  • Mild cough
  • Low-grade fever

Progressive Symptoms

  • Barking cough
  • Hoarseness
  • Inspiratory stridor
  • Fever may reach 39-40°C (102.2-104°F) or be absent.
  • Child prefers to sit up in bed or be held upright.
  • Symptoms worsen at night, recur over days and resolve within a week.

Physical Examination Findings
  • Hoarse voice
  • Coryza
  • Normal to moderately inflamed pharynx.
  • Slightly increased respiratory rate.
  • Hypoxia and low oxygen saturation (seen only in complete airway obstruction).

Diagnosis

 
  • Clinical diagnosis
  • X-ray PA view of neck: Steeple sign, which is characteristic of subglottic narrowing

Treatment

  • Mainstay of Treatment: Focus on airway management and hypoxia treatment.
  • Mild croup: Single dose dexamethasone.
  • Moderate to severe croup: Nebulized epinephrine in addition to dexamethasone.
  • Nebulized Racemic Epinephrine: Used for moderate to severe stridor at rest, possible need for intubation, respiratory distress and hypoxia.
  • Corticosteroids:
    • Decrease edema in laryngeal mucosa
    • Oral steroids beneficial in mild croup
    • Dexamethasone 0.6 mg/kg single dose; as low as 0.15 mg/kg may be effective.
  • Antibiotics are not indicated.


Acute epiglottitis (Option A) typically presents with a rapidly worsening fever, difficulty breathing, drooling, and a child in a hyperextended neck position to ease breathing. Stridor is a late sign, often accompanied by a toxic appearance. Radiographs show the thumb sign (enlarged epiglottis).

 

Foreign body aspiration (Option C) often presents with a sudden onset of symptoms, including coughing, choking, and gagging, followed by localized wheezing or differences in breath sounds on auscultation.

 

Laryngomalacia (Option D) is a congenital condition characterized by chronic inspiratory stridor in infants, typically low-pitched and worsening with activity or crying. Laryngoscopy reveals an omega-shaped epiglottis, a key diagnostic feature.

questions.text: A 3-month-old baby presents with jaundice and clay-colored stools. Lab investigation reveals that the baby has conjugated hyperbilirubinemia. The liver biopsy shows periductal proliferation. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Biliary atresia

Explanation:

  • The clinical scenario of jaundice, clay-colored stools, and conjugated hyperbilirubinemia in an infant, along with liver biopsy findings of periductal proliferation, most likely indicates biliary atresia.

Extra-Hepatic Biliary Atresia (EHBA)

  • Biliary atresia, not associated with cyst formation.
  • Also known as Non-Cystic Obliterative Cholangiopathy.
  • Characterized by complete obliteration of extrahepatic bile ducts and intrahepatic ducts at the hilum.
  • Symptoms:
    • Typically appear by 2 to 6 weeks of age
      • Jaundice (yellowish coloration of skin and sclera)
      • Abnormally pale stools
      • Dark urine
  • Classification:
    • Perinatal Type (70% cases): No associated anomalies.
    • BASM Syndrome (15% cases):
      • Biliary Atresia
      • Splenic malformations (Polysplenia)
      • Situs inversus
      • Cardiac defects
      • Malrotation of the GIT
  • Other 15% cases:
    • Associated with renal anomalies
    • Associated with choledochal cyst
  • Association with other Anomalies:
    • The most common is polysplenia or asplenia
    • Other associated malformations include absent inferior vena cava, cardiac anomalies, situs inversus, intestinal malrotation, duodenal atresia, anomaly of the portal vein, renal anomalies, and choledochal cyst.

Investigations:

  1. Liver Function Tests:
    • Increased conjugated bilirubin.
    • Markers of cholestasis:
      • 5' nucleotidase
      • Alkaline phosphatase (ALP)
      • GGT (Gamma-glutamyl transferase):
        • Normal: Up to 40 U/L
        • 4x elevation: Intrahepatic causes
        • 10x elevation: Extrahepatic causes
        • Exception: Low in PFIC type I and II
  2. Ultrasound:
    • High-frequency USG (HUS) for neonatal cholestasis.
    • Used as initial investigation
    • Fasting USG is the gold standard when biliary atresia is suspected.
    • Characteristic findings:
      • Triangular cord sign (hyperechoic areas indicating fibrous/atretic bile duct)
      • Non-visualized gallbladder/microgallbladder/gallbladder ghost
  3. Radionucleotide Study:
    • HIDA Scan (Hepatobiliary scan with Tc labelled imino-di-acetic acid):
      • Used as a screening test.
      • Decreased tracer excretion due to obstruction
    • Phenobarbitone loading/priming (5 days) to improve tracer uptake
    • Used as a screening test, not specific
  4. Best Investigation:
    • Liver biopsy:IOC for confirming diagnosis, shows periductal proliferation.

Surgical Management:

  1. Algorithm:
    • Exploratory laparotomy
    • Per Operative cholangiogram
    • Temporary procedure: Kasai procedure/hepaticojejunostomy
    • Definitive management: Liver transplantation
  2. Kasai Procedure:
    • Temporary procedure
    • Creates communication between liver and jejunum for bile drainage
    • Also known as hepaticojejunostomy
    • Should be performed within 8 weeks after birth

 

Crigler-Najjar syndrome (Option A) is caused by a deficiency in glucuronyl transferase, leading to unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia. It does not show periductal proliferation on liver biopsy. The conjugated hyperbilirubinemia and periductal proliferation seen in this case make Crigler-Najjar syndrome unlikely.

Rotor syndrome (Option B) is caused by mutations in the SLCO1B1 and SLCO1B3 genes, which affect the hepatic uptake and biliary excretion of bilirubin, resulting in mild conjugated hyperbilirubinemia. Liver biopsy shows normal histology, not periductal proliferation. The severe cholestasis with clay-colored stools and periductal proliferation, in this case, makes Rotor syndrome unlikely.

Dubin-Johnson syndrome (Option C) is caused by a mutation in MRP-2, impairing the excretion of conjugated bilirubin. Liver biopsy shows dark pigmentation due to epinephrine metabolite accumulation, not periductal proliferation. The dark liver and benign presentation make Dubin-Johnson syndrome inconsistent with the findings here.

questions.text: Which of the following is false regarding the given image?

choices.text: It is associated with facial angiofibroma
They are diagnostic of a neurocutaneous syndrome

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) It is associated with facial angiofibroma

Explanation:

  • The given image shows discrete tan nodules on the iris, called Lisch nodules, which are a hallmark of Neurofibromatosis Type 1 (NF1) and are melanocytic hamartomas of the iris.
  • Facial angiofibromas are a characteristic feature of Tuberous Sclerosis Complex (TSC), not NF1.

Neurofibromatosis Type 1 (NF1):

  • Incidence: 1 in 3,000 live births.
  • Inheritance:
    • 50% of cases are inherited from a parent.
    • 50% due to spontaneous mutations.
  • Genetics: Autosomal dominant loss-of-function mutations in the NF1 gene on chromosome 17q11.2. The gene encodes neurofibromin, which inhibits the oncogene Ras.
  • Diagnosis Criteria (Two or more required):

Feature

Description

Café-au-lait macules (CALMs)

>5 mm in prepubertal, >15 mm in postpubertal.

6 or more needed for diagnosis

Axillary/Inguinal Freckling

Multiple hyperpigmented areas, 2-3 mm in diameter.

Iris Lisch Nodules (Option D)

Hamartomas in the iris (Option A), best seen with a slit-lamp.

2 or more needed for diagnosis and doesn’t cause any visual disturbances. (Option B)

Neurofibromas

Two or more neurofibromas or one plexiform neurofibroma.

Osseous Lesion

Sphenoid dysplasia (which may cause pulsating exophthalmos) or cortical thinning of long bones with or without pseudoarthrosis (most often the tibia).

Optic Gliomas

CNS tumor affecting the optic nerve.

Family History

First-degree relative with an NF1 diagnosis based on these criteria.
  • Management:
    • Regular Monitoring
    • Treatment Considerations:
      • Avoid routine brain/optic tract imaging unless symptomatic.
      • Selumetinib: Effective in children with inoperable plexiform neurofibromas.
    • Neuropsychological and Educational Support.
  • Genetic Counseling
    • Inheritance: Autosomal dominant; over 50% of cases are de novo mutations.
    • Molecular Testing:
      • Useful in cases with unclear clinical diagnosis or severe disease.
      • Prenatal/preimplantation diagnosis may be considered.

questions.text:
A patient hailing from Delhi presents with high fever, arthralgia, retrobulbar pain, and extensive petechial rash for 3 days. Lab investigations reveal:


	Hemoglobin: 9 g/dL
	WBC count: 9000 cells/mm³
	Platelet count: 20,000 cells/mm³
	Positive tourniquet test


What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Dengue hemorrhagic fever

Explanation:

  • Dengue hemorrhagic fever is characterized by high fever, thrombocytopenia (<100,000/mm³), plasma leakage (leading to hemoconcentration, pleural effusion, or ascites), and hemorrhagic manifestations (petechiae, gum bleeding, or positive tourniquet test). The patient’s low platelet count (20,000/mm³) and petechiae confirm this diagnosis.

Dengue complications

Neurological
  • Dengue encephalopathy is most commonly encountered neurological complication of dengue virus
    • Linked primarily to dengue hemorrhagic fever and dengue shock syndrome
    • EEG may show abnormalities such as burst suppression and seizures
    • CSF profiles typically remain normal.
    • Neuroimaging can be normal or reveal diffuse cerebral edema.
  • Encephalitis
  • GBS
  • Stroke

Cardiomyopathy
  • Dengue virus-induced dilated cardiomyopathy should always be considered if a dengue fever patient has refractory shock and signs and symptoms of congestive heart failure.

Hepatic injury
  • Liver involvement in dengue is a crucial feature
  • The effect ranges from an asymptomatic rise in liver enzymes to the development of ALF
  • The most common atypical manifestation reported was hepatitis

Pneumonia

 
  • Staphylococcus pneumonia is an important accompanying problem seen in dengue patient
  • Co-infection between dengue and influenza can result in exacerbation of pneumonia

Orchitis
  • Orchitis usually occurs together with epididymitis
  • Commonly seen in men between 14 and 35 years of age.

Dengue Hemorrhagic Fever

All of the following:

  • Acute onset of fever
  • 2-7 days duration
  • Hemorrhagic manifestations
    • Positive tourniquet test/Petechiae
    • Ecchymosis
    • Purpura/Bleeding from mucosa, GIT, Injection sites, etc
  • Platelet count ≤ 100,000 cells/cu.mm.
  • Plasma leakage
    • Rising hematocrit
      • Hemoconcentration >20%
    • Pleural effusion, ascites/Hypoproteinemia)

Dengue Shock Syndrome
  • DHF criteria plus Signs of Shock
  • Tachycardia/Cool extremities/Weak pulse/Lethargy/Restlessness
  • Pulse pressure <20 mm Hg with increased Diastolic pressure (e.g. 100/80)
  • Hypotension (Systolic <80 mm Hg for age <5 years/80-90 mm Hg for older children and adults)

Incorrect Options:

Dengue fever (Option A): Classical dengue fever presents with fever, arthralgia, myalgia, retro-orbital pain, and rash but does not involve significant thrombocytopenia (<100,000/mm³) or plasma leakage. The presence of petechiae and a positive tourniquet test suggests progression to Dengue Hemorrhagic Fever (DHF).

Dengue shock syndrome (Option C): Dengue shock syndrome is a severe complication of DHF, with hypotension, circulatory collapse, and organ failure. The absence of shock symptoms (low BP, tachycardia, cold extremities, altered sensorium) rules out DSS.

Malaria (Option D): Malaria presents with cyclic fevers, chills, sweating, and anemia. While severe Plasmodium falciparum infection can cause thrombocytopenia, petechial rash and a positive tourniquet test are not typical findings.

questions.text: A 54-year-old woman was diagnosed with advanced cervical cancer. She has a 14-year-old daughter. What advice would you give her?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Advise HPV vaccine

  • The clinical scenario suggests that the best advice for the daughter is to get the HPV vaccine as HPV is a known risk factor for carcinoma cervix, and vaccination can prevent it.

Human Papillomavirus (HPV):

  • HPV, a dsDNA virus, causes almost all cervical cancers.
  • HPV vaccine is against L1 capsid protein.
  • Viral replication is carried out by E1 and E2 protein
  • It primarily infects human squamous cells or metaplastic epithelial cells.
  • Clinically, HPV is divided into 2 types:
    • Low-risk HPV (6 & 11) causes nearly all genital warts, and laryngeal papillomas and are rarely oncogenic.
    • High-risk HPV (16 & 18) causes approximately 95% of cervical cancers. HPV 16 is the most oncogenic in high-risk HPV types.

Screening for the BRCA gene (Option A) is done for breast and ovarian cancers as these are associated with BRCA gene mutations and not related to cervical cancers.

 

Screening for the PTEN gene (Option C) is done for diseases associated with PTEN gene mutation, like Cowden syndrome, characterized by an increased risk of certain cancers, including breast, thyroid, and endometrial cancers.

 

Cervical biopsy (Option D) is a diagnostic procedure to evaluate cervical abnormalities or suspected cervical cancer. In this scenario, the daughter does not present with any specific cervical abnormalities or symptoms that warrant a cervical biopsy. Cervical biopsies are not routine screening tests and are not typically performed without specific indications.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true about Trichomonas vaginalis?

choices.text: Twitching motility is seen on wet saline mount
Cysts are seen on wet saline mount of vaginal secretions

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Twitching motility is seen on wet saline mount

Explanation:

Trichomoniasis

  • Trichomonas vaginitis is the most common cause of vaginitis in women of reproductive age.
  • The characteristic appearance seen is ‘Strawberry cervix,’ an erythematous and edematous cervical mucosa with characteristic punctate red papules. It is caused by microscopic punctate haemorrhages of the cervix.
  • Symptoms include:
    • Sudden, profuse, yellowish-green, frothy, foul-smelling discharge
    • Irritation and itching in and around the vaginal opening
    • Painful urination
    • Pain during intercourse
    • Recurrent infections
    • Inflamed vulva
    • Inflamed vaginal walls with small, punctate hemorrhages ("strawberry cervix")
  • The standard treatment is Metronidazole 2g PO single dose.

Incorrect Options:

Trophozoite has 2 nuclei (Option A): Trichomonas vaginalis exists only as a trophozoite, which has a single nucleus and four anterior flagella, not two nuclei.

Cysts are seen on wet saline mount of vaginal secretions (Option C): Trichomonas vaginalis does not form cysts; it exists only as a trophozoite.

Infective form is cyst (Option D): The infective form of T. vaginalis is the trophozoite, not a cyst. It is transmitted through sexual contact, and the absence of a cyst form contributes to its reliance on direct human-to-human transmission.

questions.text: A 50-year-old female patient presents with a foul-smelling bloody discharge mixed with mucous from the vagina, upon examination, exhibits a necrotizing growth in the cervix with lateral parametrium involvement. What is the management for this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: C) Chemoradiation

  • The clinical scenario points to cervical carcinoma, and the involvement of parametrium in cervical cancer categorizes it into stage 2b, which is ideally treated by chemoradiation.

Stage

Surgical Management

Post-Surgical Management

IA1
  • Simple hysterectomy (Type I).
  • Conization if family not complete

 

 

Regular pelvic exams and Pap smears.

IA1 (with LVSI)
  • Modified radical hysterectomy (Type II) + pelvic lymphadenectomy (PLND).
  • Radical trachelectomy + PLND (consider SNLB) for selected patients desiring fertility

IA2
  • Radical hysterectomy + PLND (consider SNLB if tumour <2 cm).
  • Radical trachelectomy + PLND for selected patients desiring fertility.

 

 

  • If the specimen shows high-risk features - Adjuvant chemoradiation.
  • Regular pelvic exams and Pap smears.

IB1
  • Radical hysterectomy + PLND (consider SNLB if tumour <2 cm).
  • Radical trachelectomy + PLND for selected patients desiring fertility.

IB2

Radical hysterectomy + PLND

IIA1

IB3 - IIA2

Chemoradiation

 

Regular pelvic exams and Pap smears

IIB - IVA

Chemoradiation

IVB

Palliative chemotherapy and/or Palliative radiotherapy

 

LVSI: Lymphovascular space involvement

NOTE: In young females, the ovaries are often spared during surgery to prevent premature menopause. Removing the ovaries can lead to long-term health issues such as osteoporosis, cardiovascular disease, and cognitive decline.

 

Chemotherapy (Option A) alone is not sufficient for the treatment of locally invasive cervical carcinoma and is used as a part of the treatment in advanced disease or metastatic disease.

Brachytherapy (Option B) involves the placement of radioactive sources directly into or near the tumor, which is an important component of radiation therapy for cervical cancer, particularly in early-stage disease, or as a boost to external beam radiation therapy. However, in the case described, the involvement of the lateral parametrium suggests a more advanced stage where brachytherapy alone would not be adequate.

Surgery (Option D), such as radical hysterectomy and pelvic lymphadenectomy, is commonly performed for early-stage cervical cancer. However, in the case described, the involvement of the lateral parametrium indicates locally advanced disease where surgery alone would not be sufficient.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman with a history of multiple sexual partners presents with lower abdominal pain for 1 month. She experiences minimal discharge and complaints of inter-menstrual bleeding. What is the most likely cause?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Neisseria gonorrhoea

  • The clinical scenario points to an infection due to Neisseria gonorrhoea leading to pelvic inflammatory disease.

 

Morphology:

  • They are cocci that have pili that help in adhesion to the urethra or other mucosal surfaces.
  • They penetrate the intracellular spaces and reach the subepithelial tissue by the 3rd day of infection.

 

Clinical features:

  • Urethritis
  • Cervical discharge: Purulent and thick
  • Pruritis
  • Dysuria
  • Intermenstrual bleeding

 

Specific features of the disease:

  • About half of the female patients remain asymptomatic
  • The ectocervix and vagina remain unaffected, usually
  • The main sites of infection are the columnar and transitional epithelium
  • It initially affects the cervix and urethra and may extend to the Bartolin’s glands, skene glands, endometrium, and fallopian tubes (salpingitis)

 

Complications:

  • Pelvic inflammatory disease and salpingitis can lead to sterility
  • Tubo-ovarian abscesses
  • Ectopic pregnancies
  • Peritonitis with perihepatic inflammation (Fitz-Hugh-Curtis syndrome)
  • In Males:
    • Acute urethritis can extend along the urethra to involve the prostate, seminal vesicles, and epididymis
    • Mucopurulent genital discharge resembling the ‘flow of seed’ (semen)
    • Urethral strictures
    • Water-can perineum due to the spread of infection to the periurethral tissues, leading to abscesses and multiple discharging sinuses

 

Genital tuberculosis (Option B) presents with irregularities in the menstrual cycle but may also be associated with systemic symptoms such as fever, malaise, and weight loss. It may also be associated with concurrent pulmonary disease.

Vaginal candidiasis (Option C) presents with intense pruritus and copious vaginal discharge that has a cottage cheese appearance.

Herpes simplex (Option D) appears as blisters that develop into painful ulcers on breaking.

questions.text: According to the Colombo plan, which of the following statements regarding cancer treatment is correct?

choices.text: Help with PET scan units for diagnosis of cancer

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Setting up cobalt therapy units

Explanation:

  • The Colombo plan consists of 20 developing countries within the region and 6 non-regional members.
  • Canada made a contribution by setting up Cobalt therapy units.
  • The Colombo plan helps in promoting good living standards for the people of the area by evaluating the developmental plans and coordinating development assistance.

 

The Colombo Plan
  • Multilateral agency.
  • Promotes the concept of collective intergovernmental for economic and social development in South and Southeast Asia.
  • Primary focus is on agricultural and industrial development and sometimes on health.
  • Membership - 20 developing countries.
  • 6 non-regional members - Australia, Canada, Japan, New Zealand, UK, USA.
  • Provides Cobalt Radiotherapy Units to Medical Colleges
  • AIIMS in New Delhi was established with financial assistance from New Zealand.

questions.text: A lady from West Rajasthan presented with an ulcer surrounded by erythema on the right leg. Microscopy of the biopsy from the edge of the ulcer showed organisms with dark staining nuclei and kinetoplast. What is the most likely causative agent?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Leishmania tropica

Explanation:

  • Leishmania tropica causes cutaneous leishmaniasis, also known as oriental sore, which is endemic in parts of Rajasthan. It presents as a chronic, non-healing ulcer with surrounding erythema. The amastigote form, seen on microscopy, has a characteristic dark-staining nucleus and kinetoplast inside macrophages.
  • Leishmaniasis is a vector-borne disease caused by a protozoan species belonging to the genus Leishmania. It is transmitted by sand fly vectors.

 

Clinical manifestations of Leishmaniasis vary, depending on the species, from cutaneous ulcers to systemic multiorgan disease.

Mucocutaneous involvement can be seen in:

a. Cutaneous Leishmaniasis (CL)

I. Old world leishmaniasis - caused by L. major/ L. tropica

II. New world leishmaniasis - caused by L. mexicana

 

CL typically begins as a pink-coloured papule that enlarges, then develops into a nodule or plaque, finally forming a painless ulceration with an indurated border.

Old World CL: The ulcer is often covered with hyperkeratotic eschar. The ulcer margins may be raised (volcano sign).

New World CL: The ulcer may be covered with thick white-yellow fibrinous material. ‘Chiclero’s ulcer’ - multiple, small, chronic ulcers on the ear, due to multiple sandfly bites.

 

b. Mucosal Leishmaniasis (ML) caused by L. braziliensis

  • Characterized by mucosal destruction. The most commonly involved tissues include the nose, mouth, and nasal septum.
  • Symptoms include nasal stuffiness and mucosal bleeding, while some experience pain and deformity. Substantial disfigurement can result.

Incorrect Options:

Babesia (Option B): Babesia is an intracellular parasite that affects red blood cells, causing malaria-like hemolytic anemia, fever, and thrombocytopenia, not skin ulcers.

Trypanosoma cruzi (Option C): Trypanosoma cruzi causes Chagas disease, which presents with Romana's sign (unilateral periorbital swelling) and cardiomyopathy, rather than cutaneous ulcers. The trypomastigote form is seen in blood smears, not in tissue biopsy.

Histoplasma (Option D): Histoplasma capsulatum is a fungus that primarily causes pulmonary infections. Though it can cause cutaneous lesions in disseminated histoplasmosis, it lacks the kinetoplast seen in protozoal parasites like Leishmania.

questions.text: A poor farmer with a history of successive crop failure develops progressive spastic paraparesis, signs of upper motor neuron paralysis, and gait instability. Name the toxin responsible for this condition.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Beta-oxalyl-amino-alanine

Explanation:

  • The condition in the given case scenario is called Lathyrism, which is due to the toxin beta-oxalyl-amino-alanine present in Lathyrus seeds.

Lathyrism:

Causative agent
  • Beta-oxalyl amino alanine (BOAA) present in Lathyrus sativus
  • Significant exposure : >30% inclusion in diet over 2-6 months

Clinical features
  • Latent stage: preventive can be best implemented here
  • No stick stage: most common point of diagnosis
  • One-stick stage: muscular stiffness begins
  • Two-stick stage: will need crutches
  • Crawler stage: muscular atrophy sets in.

Treatment
  • Vitamin C prophylaxis: 500-1000 mg per day
  • Banning the crop

Toxin removal
  • Steeping method: soaking in hot water for 2 hours, drained and sun-dried.
  • Parboiling: overnight soaking in limewater.
  • Genetic approach: selecting variants with less BOAA content and cultivating the same.
  • Educating people.
  • Bringing socio-economic changes.

 

Aflatoxin (Option A): They are toxins produced by Aspergillus flavus and Aspergillus parasiticus and cause a condition called Aflatoxicosis. It is derived from infested grains and contaminated groundnuts. B1 and G1 are hepatotoxic and carcinogenic.

Ergot alkaloids (Option C): They cause ergotism. They are derived from infested grains which are stored for a longer duration. They cause nausea, vomiting, and dizziness which may last for up to 24-48 hours. Sometimes it can cause peripheral gangrene and painful leg cramps.

Fusarium toxin (Option D): It can cause contamination of sorghum. Rice is also considered as a substrate for this toxin.

questions.text: What would be the most appropriate approach to managing a young male patient who has presented at the hospital with a clean-cut wound that is not bleeding, and who received a complete tetanus vaccination 10 years ago?

choices.text: Human tetanus immunoglobulin and full course of vaccine

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Single-dose tetanus toxoid

Explanation:

  • Single-dose tetanus toxoid needed for clean cut wound with previous booster within 10 years
  • Thorough wound cleaning advised, removal of foreign bodies

Tetanus Management Protocol:

Category

Clean wound

Unclean wound

Category A

Has had a complete course of toxoid or a booster dose (full immunisation) within the past 5 years.

Only wound care.

Only wound care.

Category B

Full immunization > 5 years

ago < 10 years.

Wound Care + TT single dose.

Wound Care + TT single dose.

Category C

Full Immunization > 10 years

ago.

Wound Care + TT single dose.

Wound Care + TT single dose + Human Tetanus Immunoglobulin.

 

Category D

Unknown, not known, never

taken immunisation.

Wound Care + TT complete

course.

Wound Care + TT complete

course + Human Tetanus

Immunoglobulin.

questions.text: A 16-year-old girl who experiences cyclical pelvic pain every month and has not yet experienced menarche presents to the clinic. On examination, there was a central suprapubic bulge. The swelling is in the anterior aspect on PR examination. What is the most likely diagnosis?

choices.text: Transverse vaginal septum above the vagina

questions.solution:
Correct answer: C) Imperforate hymen

  • The patient's presentation of cyclic abdominal pain, the absence of menarche, and the finding of a bulging central suprapubic bulge on physical examination are characteristics of an imperforate hymen causing cryptomenorrhea.

 

Causes:

  • Congenital Causes:
    • Imperforate hymen
    • Transverse vaginal septum
    • Atresia of the upper third of the vagina and cervix
  • Acquired Causes:
    • Stenosis of the cervix following amputation, deep cauterization, and conization
    • Secondary vaginal atresia following neglected and difficult vaginal delivery.

 

Clinical Features:

  • Patients are usually around 13-15 years old (congenital cases).
  • Symptoms: Periodic lower abdominal pain and, in cases of hematocolpos, urine retention occurs
  • Physical Examination:
    • An abdominal exam reveals a uniform globular mass in the hypogastrium.
    • Vulvar inspection shows a bulging hymen.
    • Rectal examination confirms a full vagina and uterine mass.

 

Management:

  • Imperforate Hymen: Perform a cruciate incision and drain the accumulated blood.
  • Cervical Stenosis: Dilate the cervix to relieve the obstruction.

A transverse vaginal septum (Option A) refers to the presence of a band of tissue or membrane that obstructs the vaginal canal and can cause various symptoms depending on the location and extent of the septum. However, in the given scenario, a bulging swelling in the lower abdomen and a bulging swelling on PR examination is more consistent with an imperforate hymen rather than a transverse vaginal septum above the vagina.

Vaginal atresia (Option B) is the absence or incomplete development of the vagina that can be a congenital condition or result from acquired causes such as scarring or radiation therapy. While vaginal atresia can present with cyclical pelvic pain and delayed menarche, it doesn’t present with suprapubic bulging.

Cervical agenesis (Option D) is a rare condition in which the cervix (the lower part of the uterus) fails to develop properly or is absent and is usually associated with other abnormalities of the reproductive system.

questions.text: A child presents with fever and rash. Urine examination shows cells with an "owl-eye" appearance. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Cytomegalovirus

Explanation:

  • Cytomegalovirus (CMV) infection is associated with "owl-eye" intranuclear inclusions in infected cells, which are enlarged and found in urine, blood, or tissue biopsy.
  • In neonates, congenital CMV can present with jaundice, hepatosplenomegaly, microcephaly, and petechial rash.
  • In immunocompromised patients, CMV can cause retinitis, pneumonitis, and colitis.

Cytomegalovirus

General Characteristics
  • Herpesvirus (HHV-5), widespread prevalence.
  • Often asymptomatic in healthy individuals but severe in immunocompromised and congenital infections.
  • Remains latent post-infection and may reactivate.
  • Linked to mucoepidermoid carcinoma and possibly prostate cancer.
  • Transmission: Blood transfusions, organ transplantation, breastfeeding, close contact, perinatal, and sexual routes.
  • Reactivation occurs in immunocompromised individuals, increasing morbidity and mortality.

Pathophysiology
  • Persists in myeloid cells, reactivates with immune suppression.
  • Controlled mainly by cytotoxic T-cell immunity.
  • Lifelong immune burden, affecting T-cell surveillance.

Clinical Manifestations
  • Immunocompetent patients: Often asymptomatic or mononucleosis-like syndrome (fever, rash, leukocytosis).
  • Immunocompromised patients: Can cause severe organ-specific disease:
  • CMV hepatitis → Risk of fulminant liver failure
  • CMV retinitis → “Pizza pie” fundoscopic appearance
  • CMV esophagitis, colitis, pneumonitis, polyradiculopathy, encephalitis, transverse myelitis

Diagnosis
  • Quantitative PCR: Preferred for viral detection.
  • Histopathology (CMV inclusion bodies): Gold standard.
  • Serology: Used for pre-transplant risk assessment but not for acute infection diagnosis.
  • CMV-negative blood transfusions reserved for neonates and immunocompromised patients.
  • Ganciclovir resistance testing is routine in transplant centers.

Management
  • Immunocompetent patients: Self-limiting, only symptomatic treatment required.
  • Immunocompromised & severe cases: Require antivirals (ganciclovir, valganciclovir, foscarnet, cidofovir).
  • Prophylaxis: CMV-negative recipients of CMV-positive organ transplants should receive valganciclovir or ganciclovir with serological monitoring.
  • Antiviral toxicity must be weighed against benefits.

Incorrect Options:

Epstein-Barr virus (Option B): Epstein-Barr virus (EBV) causes infectious mononucleosis, which presents with fever, pharyngitis, and lymphadenopathy. It is associated with atypical lymphocytes in blood smear, but not "owl-eye" inclusions in urine.

Herpes simplex virus (Option C): Herpes simplex virus (HSV) causes painful vesicular lesions in the oral or genital region. It shows multinucleated giant cells with Cowdry type A inclusions on Tzanck smear, but not "owl-eye" inclusions.

Toxoplasma gondii (Option D): Toxoplasma gondii causes congenital toxoplasmosis, which presents with chorioretinitis, hydrocephalus, and intracranial calcifications. It is a protozoan, and its cysts do not show "owl-eye" inclusions.

questions.text: How is water collected for bacteriological examination during a disease outbreak?

choices.text: Collect water from already leaking taps
Before collecting, let water flow for at least 1 minute
Water sample container is kept close to the tap avoid spillage
Collect from a gentle stream of water to avoid splashing

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Collect from a gentle stream of water to avoid splashing

Explanation:

  • Before collecting a sample from a regularly used tap, let the water flow for at least 2 minutes.
  • Hold the bottle at the base with one hand.
  • Collect from a gentle stream of water to avoid splashing.
  • Water from leaky taps is avoided.
  • Before collecting samples for taps that are not regularly used, the taps are sterilized by heating either with a blow lamp or a piece of cotton that is soaked in methylated spirit.

Sample for physical and chemical examination:

  • Collection glass: Winchester Quart bottles
  • Capacity: > 2L
  • Pre-collection: Rinse well thrice with water
  • Collection
  • Fill with water
  • Tight placement of stopper with a piece of cloth
  • Seal the string

Sample for bacteriological examination:

  • Collection glass: Clean bottle made of neutral glass
  • Capacity: 200-250 ml
  • If the sample is likely to have chlorine: 0.1 ml of sodium thiosulphate is added before cleaning

Transport and storage of sample:

  • Precaution: Keep the sample in ice till it's taken for analysis.
  • Analysis: Should be done within 48 hours of collection
  • Details
  • Date and time of collection
  • Source
  • Survey findings

 

Collect water from already leaking taps (Option A): is avoided as it can contaminate the sample if the water runs outside the tap and enters the bottle.

Before collecting, let water flow for at least 1 minute (Option B): Before collecting a sample from a regularly used tap, the water flow is allowed for at least 2 minutes and not for 1 minute.

Water sample container is kept close to the tap avoid spillage (Option C): Keeping the water sample container close to the tap can cause the contaminants from the tap to pass into the water container.

questions.text: A boys' hostel has an outbreak of fever cases with headache, followed by the development of pleomorphic rashes sparing palms and soles. What is the next best step in the management of suspected cases?

choices.text: Isolate for 6 days after giving acyclovir, followed by VZIG within 72 hours of exposure
Isolate for 12 days after giving acyclovir, followed by VZIG within 48 hours of exposure

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Isolate for 6 days

Explanation:

  • The probable diagnosis, in this case, is chicken pox, also called varicella, which is caused by the Varicella zoster virus.
  • Control measures include isolation of the child for a period of 6 days after the onset of rashes, and disinfecting all materials that are contaminated by nasal or throat secretions.

Parameter

Details

Chickenpox
  • Seasonal affinity: Winter season
  • Etiology: HHV-3
  • Route of transmission: Respiratory / aerosol route
  • Age group affected: 5-9 years (school going age)
  • Incubation period: 14-16 days
  • Infectivity: 2 days prior to 5 days after the onset of rash
  • SAR:> 90%

Clinical Features
  • Pre-eruptive stage: Sudden onset of mild to moderate fever lasting 2–3 days.
  • Eruptive stage: Centripetal, pleomorphic rash with "Dew drop on rose petal" appearance.

Complications
  • Adults/Immunosuppressed: Pneumonia.
  • Maternal varicella: Low birth weight, microcephaly, cataract, deafness, fetal wastage.
  • Secondary bacterial infection: Cellulitis, osteomyelitis, erysipelas.

Diagnosis
  • PCR: Detecting VZV DNA.
  • Cell culture: From saliva or vesicle fluid.
  • Tzanck smear: Multinucleated giant cells.

Control and Prevention

(Options A, B, and D)
  • Isolation: 6 days after rash appearance.
  • Disinfection: Used specimens with infective secretions.
  • Acyclovir: For adults to prevent complications; not indicated in children.
  • VZV Immunoglobulin: Within 72 hours of exposure, for immunosuppressed individuals.
  • Vaccine: 12–18 months of age; 0.5 ml subcutaneous injection.

questions.text: A 35-year-old homeless man presented with a 1-month history of fever, cough, and weight loss. Both sputum smears turned out to be negative, but the chest x-ray ordered was suggestive of tuberculosis. According to the recent NTEP guidelines, which is the next best line of management?

choices.text: Wait until TB culture results to start ATT

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Ask for CBNAAT

Explanation:

  • According to the NTEP guidelines, a negative smear with positive chest X-ray findings would require a CBNAAT.
  • It is the current gold standard for diagnosis of tuberculosis within 90 minutes.

 

 

Diagnostic Modality

Description

Usage

Sputum Smear Microscopy

Microscopic examination of sputum samples to detect acid-fast bacilli (AFB).

Used for initial screening and diagnosis, especially in resource-limited settings.

Chest X-ray

Imaging done to identify abnormalities suggestive of TB.

Used to support diagnosis when clinical suspicion is high; not definitive for TB diagnosis.

TruNAAT/CBNAAT

Molecular tests that detect Mycobacterial DNA and rifampicin resistance.

Recommended for initial diagnosis due to high sensitivity and specificity; rapid results.

Line Probe Assay (LPA)

Molecular test to detect specific genetic mutations associated with drug resistance (e.g., rifampicin, isoniazid).

Used for detecting drug resistance in confirmed TB cases, not for initial diagnosis.

Tuberculin Skin Test (TST)

A skin test to measure immune response to injected tuberculin protein.

Primarily used for screening latent TB infection; not specific for active TB diagnosis.

Interferon-Gamma Release Assays (IGRAs)

Blood cytokine analysis test that measures immune response to TB antigens.

Used for detecting latent TB infection

Sputum Culture

Growing Mycobacteria from sputum samples to confirm TB and test for drug susceptibility.

Gold standard for TB diagnosis; takes several weeks to obtain results.

Drug Susceptibility Testing (DST)

Testing TB bacteria from patient samples to determine resistance to TB drugs.

Used to guide treatment by identifying drug-resistant strains in confirmed TB cases.

 

Repeat sputum smears (Option A): Previously it was done but not done after 2016. Repeat sputum smears are taken to monitor the treatment response.

Ask for line probe assay (Option C): Line probe assay is usually used for the diagnosis of the first line antitubercular drug resistance tuberculosis and are not indicated in this case scenario.

Wait until TB culture results to start ATT (Option D): Since it is slow growth, it takes around 4 weeks to get the sputum culture reports. Hence, it is not ideal to depend on culture reports to start ATT.

questions.text: A 17-year-old girl with a height of 155cm and weight of 48kgs presents with primary amenorrhea. She has not developed breasts or hair in the pubic or axillary regions and has bilateral inguinal masses. USG examination shows an absent uterus, fallopian tube, and ovary. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: A) Hypergonadotropic hypogonadism

The clinical scenario here is of a female with an absent uterus, breasts, and other structures with primary amenorrhea and inguinal masses (undescended testes) that suggests the XY karyotype thus leading to the diagnosis of hypergonadotropic hypogonadism.

  • In individuals with the XY karyotype, a Mullerian-inhibiting substance is secreted from the Sertoli cells, which inhibits the development of the uterus, fallopian tubes, cervix, and upper vagina.
  • This happens in XX individuals when there is Mullerian agenesis, but their ovaries are normal.
  • The given scenario has no ovaries and can hence be confirmed to have the ‘Y’ chromosome, hence the XY karyotype.
  • The conditions that can have the XY karyotype with features in the scenario (absent uterus, fallopian tubes, and ovaries) are hypergonadotropic hypogonadism (seen in XY and XX) and androgen insensitivity syndrome.
  • The scenario also states that the individual has not developed breasts which is concurrent with the diagnosis of hypergonadotropic hypogonadism.

 

Hypergonadotropic hypogonadism

Aetiology:

  • Usually seen in disorders with LH or hCG receptor mutations.

 

Pathophysiology:

  • It is an autosomal recessive 46, XY disorder where there are LH receptor mutations.
  • This prevents the normal hormone binding and thus reduces the number or function of Leydig cells.
  • This decreases fetal testosterone production and leads to the failure of normal male sexual differentiation.
  • The lack of testosterone leads to impaired Wolfian duct development and failure of the development of male internal genitalia.
  • This also leads to a lack of DHT which causes masculinization of the male external genitalia giving rise to female-looking external genitalia and undescended testes.

 

Features:

  • The anti-Mullerian hormone level is normal. (in XY karyotype and hence absent ovaries)
  • Decreased testosterone leads to impaired Wolfian duct development and failure of testicular descent.
  • Appear female at birth.
  • Females at puberty present with primary amenorrhea.
  • No breast and pubic hair development.
  • Raised LH level but normal FSH levels.

 

Complete androgen insensitivity syndrome (Option B) is an X-linked disorder where the androgen receptors are absent or scanty or fail to respond to testosterone. They may appear as female phenotypically at birth but with an XY karyotype. They usually present with primary amenorrhea and absent or scanty pubic hair development. But unlike hypergonadotropic hypogonadism, these individuals have normal well-developed breasts which is not the given scenario.

Polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS) (Option C) is a common endocrine disorder characterized by hormonal imbalances, multiple cysts in the ovaries, and symptoms such as irregular periods, hirsutism (excessive hair growth), and acne. While PCOS can present with amenorrhea or irregular periods, the absence of a uterus, fallopian tubes, and ovaries on ultrasound examination is inconsistent with PCOS.

Turner syndrome (Option D) is characterized by the absence of one X chromosome (45, X0 karyotype) in females, i.e., monosomy. These individuals do not develop ovaries and breasts or other secondary sexual characteristics. However, an individual with Turner’s syndrome does develop a uterus which is not the given scenario.

questions.text: Infection with Clonorchis sinensis is associated with an increased risk of which of the following cancers?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Cholangiocarcinoma

Explanation:

  • Clonorchis sinensis is a liver fluke that infects the biliary ducts, leading to chronic inflammation, epithelial hyperplasia, and fibrosis, which increase the risk of cholangiocarcinoma (bile duct cancer).

Cholangiocarcinoma

  • Cholangiocarcinoma is an aggressive adenocarcinoma of the bile ducts, commonly presenting as obstructive jaundice.

Risk Factors

  • Biliary and Liver Conditions:
    • Primary sclerosing cholangitis (PSC)
    • Choledochal cyst
    • Hepatolithiasis
    • Caroli's disease
  • Infections:
    • Clonorchis sinensis infestation
    • Hepatitis B and C (risk factors for intrahepatic cholangiocarcinoma)
  • Genetic Conditions:
    • Lynch syndrome II
  • Other Conditions:
    • Multiple biliary papillomatosis
    • Previous biliary enteric anastomosis
  • Toxins:
    • Thorotrast
    • Nitrosamines
    • Dioxin

Types based on its location

 

 

Clinical Features

  • Primary Presentation:
    • Painless obstructive jaundice of short duration
  • Liver Changes:
    • Palpable liver, which may be smooth and soft (hydrohepatotic) or hard and nodular (secondaries)
  • Other Symptoms:
    • Weight loss and anorexia (typical and significant)
  • Gender Prevalence:
    • More common in men (1.5:1)

Incorrect Options:

Cervical cancer (Option A): Cervical cancer is primarily caused by persistent HPV (Human Papillomavirus) infection, not Clonorchis sinensis.

Gastric carcinoma (Option C): Chronic infection with Helicobacter pylori is a major risk factor for gastric carcinoma, but Clonorchis sinensis is not involved in gastric cancer development.

Bladder carcinoma (Option D): Schistosoma haematobium, not Clonorchis sinensis, is associated with bladder carcinoma, particularly squamous cell carcinoma of the bladder due to chronic inflammation and irritation.

questions.text: Which of the following is the sensitive indicator to assess the availability, utilization, and effectiveness of healthcare in a community?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Infant mortality rate

Explanation:

  • The infant mortality rate is the deaths of infants less than 1 year of age in a specific year to the total number of live births in the same year.
  • It is an important indicator of the health status of an entire population, socio-economic conditions, and the health status of infants.
  • It is a sensitive indicator to assess the availability, utilization, and effectiveness of healthcare usually in perinatal care.

 

Mortality indicators:

Crude death rate

CDR = (Total no. or deaths in a community/ MYP (Mid-year population) in the same area) x 100

  • The mid-year population is taken on 1st July
  • Limitation: It does not consider the age and sex of the population

Age-specific death rate

ASDR = (Total no. of deaths in a particular age group (eg. 20-24yrs) a given area in a year/ MYP of the age group in the same area and year) x 1000

Expectation of life

 

 
  • Life expectancy at birth: A positive mortality indicator· Average no. of years a newborn is expected to live, considering the current age-specific mortality rates in a community.
  • Important component to calculate the Human Development Index (HDI).
  • Life expectancy at one year is PQLI. In 2021, life expectancy in India is 69.7 years.

Infant mortality rate

IMR = (Total number of deaths (0-1-year-old) in a given year / Total number of live births in the same year) x 1000. It is a health status indicator.

Under-five mortality rate

U5MR = (Total number of deaths (0-5 years old) in a given year /Total number of live births in one year) x 1000

Maternal Mortality Rate (Option B)

Maternal Mortality Rate (MMR) = (Total no. of maternal deaths/women in the reproductive age group [15-49 years]) x 100,000

Maternal Mortality Ratio (MMR)

Maternal Mortality Ratio (MMR) = (Total no. of maternal deaths/Live Births) x 100,000

 

Adult mortality rate

Probability of dying between 15 to 60 years of life

Year of potential life lost

Premature death measurement. If life expectancy is 75 years, and death happens at age 30, then 45 years of potential life is lost

Proportional mortality rate

The simplest measure of the burden of disease (Total deaths due to disease 'x'/ Total deaths in a community)́ x 100

Case fatality rate

CFR = (Deaths due to diseases ‘z’ / total no of cases of disease ‘z’) x 100

 

Disability Indicators:

Quality-adjusted Life Years (QALY)
  • Quality and quantity of life lived.
  • Assesses number of years of life added due to the intervention and hence the benefit and value for money of the intervention
  • QALY - 1 year of life lived in perfect health
  • Positive indicator of the cost-effectiveness of an intervention.
  • Scored between 0 (death) and 1 (perfect health).

Disability-adjusted Life Years (DALY)

(Option D)
  • DALY= Years of life lost to premature death + years lived with disability
  • 1 DALY: 1 year of healthy life lost
  • It is a measure of the burden of disease and the effectiveness of intervention
     

Year of life lost (YLL):

  • Calculated from the number of deaths at each age multiplied by the expected remaining years of life according to a global standard life expectancy.
     

Years lost to disability (YLD):

  • Where the number of incident cases due to injury and illness is multiplied by the average duration of the disease and a weighting factor reflecting the severity of the disease on a scale from 0 (perfect health) to 1 (dead).

 

DALY = YLL + YLD

Health Adjusted Life Expectancy (HALE)
  • The average number of years a newborn is expected to live in full health considering the current age-specific mortality rate.
    Healthy Life Expectancy
    • HALE = Life Expectancy at birth + adjustment of time spent in poor health
    • HALE = LE-DALY

Life Expectancy

  • Average no. of years a newborn is expected to live, considering the current age-specific mortality rate.

Sullivan’s index
(or DFLE)
  • Disability-free life expectancy (DFLE) with the current pattern of mortality and disability.

Immunization coverage (Option C): Proportion of infants vaccinated.

questions.text: A patient presented with persistent dry cough, fever, and weight loss. He was diagnosed as HIV positive 6 months ago but has been poorly adherent to medications. Gomori methenamine silver (GMS) staining of bronchoalveolar lavage (BAL) reveals a crushed ping-pong ball appearance. What is the most likely causative organism?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Pneumocystis jirovecii

Explanation:

  • Pneumocystis jirovecii is an opportunistic fungal pathogen that causes Pneumocystis pneumonia (PCP), especially in HIV/AIDS patients with CD4 counts <200 cells/µL.
  • The Gomori methenamine silver (GMS) stain reveals a round, crushed ping-pong ball–like cysts, which is characteristic of P. jirovecii.

Pneumocystis jirovecii: Cause and Transmission

  • Opportunistic Pathogen:
    • Primarily affects immunocompromised individuals (e.g., HIV/AIDS patients with CD4+ counts <200 cells/mm³).
  • Colonization in Healthy Individuals:
    • Common in healthy lungs; most children are exposed by age 4.
    • Reactivation in adults is possible from childhood exposure or new infections.
  • Airborne Transmission:
    • Spreads through person-to-person contact, especially in hospital settings.
    • Colonized individuals exhale the organism, contaminating the environment.
  • Reinfection vs. Reactivation:
    • Both reinfection with new strains and reactivation of dormant infection are possible causes of recurrent PCP.
  • Environmental Reservoir:
    • Exact environmental source unknown, but the organism has been found in air samples near infected patients.

Clinical Features

  • General Symptoms
    • Fever
    • Nonproductive cough
    • Dyspnea (shortness of breath)
    • Tachypnea (rapid breathing)
  • Symptom Variations by Immune Status

Parameter

HIV-Infected Patients

Non-HIV Patients

Onset

Gradual (2 weeks to 2 months)

Sudden (within a week)

Symptom Severity

Milder respiratory distress initially

Rapid progression to respiratory failure

Course

Chronic

Acute

Oxygen Impairment

Less severe

More severe

Incorrect Options:

Paracoccidioides brasiliensis (Option A): Paracoccidioides brasiliensis causes paracoccidioidomycosis, commonly found in South America. The yeast form appears as pilot wheel (captain's wheel) structures on staining, not ping-pong ball-like cysts.

Histoplasma capsulatum (Option B): Histoplasma capsulatum causes histoplasmosis, which may present with disseminated infection in AIDS patients. The yeast form appears as intracellular budding yeast within macrophages on GMS stain, not crushed ping-pong ball appearance.

Coccidioides immitis (Option C): Coccidioides immitis causes coccidioidomycosis (Valley fever) and forms spherules containing endospores, not crushed ping-pong ball structures.

questions.text: A woman is to undergo a complete laparoscopic hysterectomy and wants to know about the disadvantages of the procedure. What are the disadvantages of laparoscopic hysterectomy over open surgery?

choices.text: Not knowing the extent of thermal burns

questions.solution:
Correct answer: B) Not knowing the extent of thermal burns

  • Laparoscopic surgery holds many advantages over an open hysterectomy, but one disadvantage is that due to the lack of complete visualization, the extent of thermal burns cannot be assessed.

 

Different laparoscopic techniques:

  • Diagnostic laparoscopy before vaginal hysterectomy
  • Vaginal hysterectomy assisted by laparoscopy
  • Laparoscopically assisted vaginal hysterectomy
  • Laparoscopic hysterectomy
  • Total laparoscopic hysterectomy

 

Advantages:

  • Lower analgesia needs (low pain) (Option D)
  • Shorter hospital stays
  • Lesser blood loss (Option C)
  • Faster recovery (Option A)
  • Lower rates of surgical site infection
  • Greater patient satisfaction
  • Lower rate of hematoma formation

 

Disadvantages:

  • Longer surgical time
  • Lesser field of visualisation

questions.text: A sewage worker presented with abdominal pain, jaundice, conjunctival injection, and hematuria for the past 5 days. Which of the following is the investigation of choice?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Microscopic Agglutination Test (MAT)

Explanation:

  • Microscopic agglutination test (MAT) is the gold standard test for diagnosing Leptospirosis. It detects Leptospira-specific antibodies by agglutination of live leptospiral antigens. It is highly sensitive and specific for confirming leptospiral infection.

Leptospirosis

Agent
  • Leptospira interrogans (zoonotic bacteria)

Reservoir
  • Rodents (Ratus norvegicus, Mus musculus) and domestic animals

Source
  • Direct contact or contamination with excreta, urine of infected animals.

At risk individuals
  • Males 20-45 years (most common)
  • Urine-contaminated mud(Soil) or water
    • Sports: Rafting, fishing and swimming
    • Rice field workers, sewer workers, animal handlers

Mode of transmission
  • Direct contact: Urine through skin abrasion
  • Indirect contact: Contact of broken skin with soil, water, vegetation
  • Droplet infection: Inhalation while milking cows.

Incubation
  • 4-20 days

Diagnosis
  • Clinical features
  • Dark Field examination: Thin and motile spirochete.
  • IgM ELISA: High sensitivity
  • Labs: Elevated liver enzymes, increased bilirubin, thrombocytopenia

Incorrect Options:

Widal test (Option A): The Widal test is used for typhoid fever (Salmonella typhi) and is not useful for diagnosing Leptospirosis.

Weil-Felix reaction (Option C): Weil-Felix is a serological test for Rickettsial infections and is not specific for Leptospirosis.

Paul-Bunnell test (Option D): The Paul-Bunnell test is used to detect heterophile antibodies in infectious mononucleosis (caused by Epstein-Barr virus) and has no role in diagnosing Leptospirosis.

questions.text: During the removal of a submucosal fibroid by hysteroscopy, a deficit of 2000 mL is estimated in a patient. What is the immediate complication of this?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Pulmonary edema

  • The immediate complication of a fluid deficit (the amount of fluid absorbed by the body) of 2000mL during hysteroscopy is pulmonary oedema.

 

Hysteroscopy and distension fluid:

  • Hysteroscopy is both a diagnostic and therapeutic procedure
  • Fluid distension is done to improve visualization of the uterine cavity
  • For monopolar surgical instruments: Electrolyte-free, hypotonic solutions are used
  • For bipolar surgical instruments: Isotonic distension fluids can be used
  • A fluid deficit is a difference in the amount of distension fluid inserted and removed, which makes up the amount absorbed by the body.

 

A complication associated with hysteroscopic procedures is excessive absorption of media.

 

Distension media

Feature

Complications

Carbon dioxide
  • Highly soluble in blood so poses less risk
  • The flow rate must be below 100ml/min
  • Insufflation pressure must be < 100mmHg
  • CO2 emboli (rare)
  • Intraoperative morbidity
  • Death

Dextran 70
  • Hyperosmolar medium
  • Volume used should be < 300ml
  • Allergic reaction (rare)
  • Coagulopathy (rare)
  • Vascular overload
  • Heart failure

Low viscosity fluids

  • 1.5% glycine
  • 3% sorbitol
  • 5% mannitol

 
  • Hypotonic
  • Electrolyte free

 
  • Absorption leads to major volume and electrolyte disturbances
  • Pulmonary oedema
  • Hyponatremia
  • Heart failure
  • Cerebral edema
  • Death
  • Cardiac and renal toxicity (from glycine)

Other complications of hysteroscopy:

  • Uterine perforation
  • Hemorrhage
  • Gas embolism

 

Acute tubular necrosis (ATN) (Option A) is a kidney disorder involving damage to the renal tubules, usually due to ischemia (lack of blood supply) or nephrotoxic agents. While severe dehydration can lead to kidney injury, ATN is not the immediate complication resulting from a fluid deficit during a hysteroscopic procedure.

DIC (Option B) is a serious condition characterized by widespread activation of the clotting cascade, leading to the formation of microclots throughout the bloodstream. This excessive clotting consumes clotting factors and platelets, leading to bleeding tendencies elsewhere in the body. It occurs with significant fluid loss.

Thromboembolism (Option D) refers to the formation of a blood clot that dislodges and travels through the bloodstream, potentially causing blockages in vital organs. While clotting issues can arise from factors related to dehydration and surgery, immediate thromboembolism is not a direct complication of a fluid deficit during a hysteroscopic procedure.

questions.text: Which of the following laboratory tests is used to diagnose rotavirus diarrhea?

choices.text: Antigen detection in the stool sample

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Antigen detection in the stool sample

Explanation:

  • Enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay (ELISA) and latex agglutination tests are commonly used to detect rotavirus antigen (VP6 protein) in stool samples. This is the most sensitive and specific test for diagnosing rotavirus infection.

Sandwich ELISA Procedure:

  1. Coating: Coat microtiter wells with goat anti-rotavirus antibody; add sample and incubate (overnight at 4°C or 2 hours at 37°C).
  2. Detection Antibody: Add enzyme-labelled anti-rotavirus antibody (e.g., with alkaline phosphatase) and incubate.
  3. Substrate Addition: Add para-nitrophenyl phosphate; enzyme activity causes colour change if rotavirus is present.
  4. Interpretation: Yellow colour development confirms a positive test; the ELISA reader provides quantitative colour readings.

Incorrect Options:

Antigen detection in blood (Option B): Rotavirus primarily affects the gastrointestinal tract and does not cause significant viremia; therefore, detecting antigens in blood is not a standard diagnostic method.

Antibody detection in serum (Option C): While serology can detect past exposure to rotavirus, it is not useful for acute diagnosis, as antibodies appear later in the infection.

Light microscopy of stool specimen (Option D): Routine light microscopy does not detect rotavirus, as the virus is too small to be seen. However, electron microscopy can visualize viral particles but is not routinely used due to cost and expertise requirements.

questions.text: For which of the following diagnoses in the given OT list would hysteroscopy be the preferred procedure?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Asherman syndrome

  • Asherman syndrome is the spectrum of scarring due to firm adhesions, dense bands or complete obliteration of the uterine cavity, which must be evaluated by hysteroscopy.

Hysteroscopy

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

Indications

Diagnostic:

  • AUB
  • Infertility (Asherman syndrome)
  • Recurrent miscarriage (Asherman syndrome)
  • Congenital Uterine Anomalies

Therapeutic:

  • Lost or displaced IUD
  • Uterine septum
  • Polyps
  • Leiomyomas: It is preferred for fibroids below 5cm
  • Endometrial ablation
  • Hysteroscopic sterilization
  • Intrauterine adhesions
  • Proximal tubal obstruction

 

 

 

Procedure
  • Position: Modified dorsal lithotomy
  • Cervical exposure
  • Anesthesia: Based on the patient’s requirement
  • Cervical dilation
  • Uterine distention
  • Visualization and imaging
  • Intrauterine cutting and hemostasis
  • Other instrumentation: Based on the patient's condition.

 

Contraindications
  • Active uterine or cervical infections
  • Large uterine cavity ( > 10 cm in length)
  • Confirmed cervical or endometrial cancer
  • Pregnancy.

 

Tubal ligation (Option A), also known as female sterilization, is a procedure performed to block or seal the fallopian tubes, thereby preventing the fertilization of eggs by sperm. This procedure does not involve the uterine cavity, so hysteroscopy would not be necessary for tubal ligation.

A cervical polyp (Option C) is a benign growth that arises from the inner lining of the cervix. It does not involve the uterine cavity but rather protrudes into the cervical canal. Therefore, hysteroscopy is not typically required for the diagnosis or removal of a cervical polyp.

A subserosal fibroid (Option D) is a type of uterine fibroid that grows on the outer surface of the uterus. It does not protrude into the uterine cavity, so hysteroscopy is not necessary for its diagnosis or treatment.

questions.text: A boy presented with fever and chills. A rapid test was positive for specific antigen HRP-2. Which of the following species of Plasmodium is the most likely causative agent?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Plasmodium falciparum

Explanation:

  • The Histidine-Rich Protein 2 (HRP-2) antigen is specific to P. falciparum and is widely used in rapid diagnostic tests (RDTs) for malaria.
  • This antigen is produced by the parasite and remains in circulation for several days after treatment, making it useful for detection but sometimes leading to false positives in recent infections.

Malaria

Agent

Plasmodium species

Species

Type

Fever Cycle

P.falciparum

Malignant Tertian Malaria

Every 48 hours

P.vivax

Benign Tertian Malaria

Every 48 hours

P.malariae

Quartan Malaria

Every 72 hours

P.ovale

Ovale Malaria

Every 48 hours

P. knowlesi

Quotidian Malaria

Every 24 hours (daily)

Incubation Period: 7-30 days, depending on Plasmodium species

Vector

Female Anopheles mosquitoes

  • Behavior: Nocturnal feeders; prefer to bite between dusk and dawn
  • Breeding Sites: Stagnant water bodies such as ponds, marshes, swamps, and artificial containers

Transmission
  • Bites of infected female Anopheles mosquitoes
  • Can be transmitted through blood transfusions and organ transplants.

Host
  • Humans (Primary Host)
  • Higher risk in pregnant women, infants, and immunocompromised
  • Anopheles mosquitoes (Vector and Intermediate host)

Environmental Factors
  • Climate: Warm and Humid environment
  • Seasonality: Rainy seasons
  • Geographical Distribution:
    • Most prevalent in tropical and subtropical regions
    • India: Endemic in several states, particularly in the northeastern states (Assam, Tripura, Meghalaya), Eastern states (Odisha, Jharkhand), and some parts of Maharashtra and Karnataka

Incorrect Options:

Plasmodium malariae (Option B): P. malariae is not detected by HRP-2-based tests, as it lacks this antigen. Instead, it is diagnosed via microscopy or PCR.

Plasmodium vivax (Option C): P. vivax is typically detected using lactate dehydrogenase (pLDH)-based RDTs, not HRP-2 tests. HRP-2 does not reliably detect P. vivax infections.

Plasmodium ovale (Option D): Like P. vivax, P. ovale lacks HRP-2 and is not detected by HRP-2-based rapid tests. Its diagnosis depends on microscopy or PCR.

questions.text: A 23-year-old woman accompanied by her mother-in-law came to the infertility clinic. She has been having regular intercourse for 6 months but is not able to conceive. What is the next step in the management?

choices.text: Reassure and review the couple after 6 months

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Reassure and review the couple after 6 months

  • The clinical scenario here shows that the couple have been trying to conceive only for 6 months. For considering infertility, at least 1-year duration of unprotected intercourse of reasonable duration is required, and hence, the best step is to reassure the couple and reevaluate after 6 more months.

 

In couples who are unable to conceive after 1 year of trying, the following evaluations may be done based on the possible causes under suspicion.

Evaluation of infertility based on aetiologies

Aetiology

Evaluation

Ovulatory function/ ovarian reserve
  • Ovulation predictor kit
  • Early follicular FSH +/- estradiol level
  • AMH level
  • Endocrine disorders (TSH, prolactin)
  • Ovarian sonography (antral follicle count)

Tubal /pelvic disease
  • Hysterosalpingography
  • Laparoscopy + chromotubation

Uterine factors
  • Hysterosalpingography
  • TVS /saline infusion sonography +/- MRI
  • Hysteroscopy +/- laparoscopy

Male factor
  • Semen analysis

Semen analysis (Option A) is an important initial step in evaluating infertility. It assesses the quality and quantity of sperm in the semen. However, in this case, the woman has been trying to conceive for only 6 months, which is below the recommended timeframe for seeking further evaluation.

Hysterolaparoscopy (Option C) is a combined diagnostic procedure involving hysteroscopy (visualizing the uterine cavity) and laparoscopy (visualizing the pelvic organs) to assess the female reproductive system for any anatomical abnormalities or conditions that may be affecting fertility. It is an invasive procedure and is typically reserved for cases where there is a suspected underlying pathology or infertility after a longer duration of unsuccessful attempts at conception.

Diagnostic hysteroscopy (Option D) is a procedure that allows direct visualization of the uterine cavity using a thin, lighted instrument called a hysteroscope. It is used to evaluate and diagnose uterine abnormalities that may contribute to infertility, such as polyps, fibroids, or intrauterine adhesions. However, similar to hysterolaparoscopy, diagnostic hysteroscopy is not typically the initial step in the evaluation of infertility, especially after only 6 months of trying.

questions.text: A child was brought with complaints of high fever, multiple seizures, headache, and neck rigidity. CSF analysis revealed low glucose, high protein, and many polymorphs. The CSF culture showed pleomorphic gram-negative bacilli. What is true about the causative organism?

choices.text: Produces non-lactose fermenting colonies on MacConkey agar
Exhibits satellitism around Staphylococcus aureus colonies
It exhibits alpha hemolysis on sheep blood agar

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Exhibits satellitism around Staphylococcus aureus colonies

Explanation:

  • The pleomorphic gram-negative bacilli in CSF culture suggest Haemophilus influenzae, a major cause of bacterial meningitis in children.
  • H. influenzae requires Factor X (hemin) and Factor V (NAD) for growth. Staphylococcus aureus releases NAD, promoting the growth of H. influenzae around its colonies, a phenomenon known as satellitism.
  • The type b capsular polysaccharide (polyribosylribitol phosphate or PRP) is the most virulent serotype, particularly in unvaccinated children under 5 years old, often causing invasive diseases like meningitis.

Clinical features:

  • Meningitis: Fever, irritability, neck stiffness
  • Other invasive diseases: Epiglottitis, pneumonia, septic arthritis
  • Nontypeable strains often cause mucosal infections like otitis media, sinusitis

Diagnosis:

  • CSF analysis in meningitis: elevated protein, low glucose, pleocytosis
  • Gram stain: small gram-negative coccobacilli
  • Culture on chocolate agar
  • Antigen detection tests (latex agglutination) for rapid diagnosis
  • PCR for definitive identification and serotyping

Treatment:

  • Empiric therapy: Third-generation cephalosporins (ceftriaxone or cefotaxime)
  • Alternative: Chloramphenicol (if cephalosporin allergy)
  • Duration: Usually 10 days for meningitis

Incorrect Options:

It is bacitracin sensitive (Option A): Bacitracin sensitivity is a characteristic of Haemophilus ducreyi, not Haemophilus influenzae.

Produces non-lactose fermenting colonies on MacConkey agar (Option B): H. influenzae does not grow on MacConkey agar, as it requires Factor X (hemin) and Factor V (NAD), which are absent in this medium.

It exhibits alpha hemolysis on sheep blood agar (Option D): H. influenzae does not hemolyze red blood cells, whereas Streptococcus pneumoniae (another common cause of meningitis) exhibits alpha hemolysis on sheep blood agar.

questions.text: A 24-year-old woman who is being treated for infertility with human menopausal gonadotropin came with complaints of sudden abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, and breathlessness. USG reveals a classic spoke-wheel appearance. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Ovarian hyperstimulation syndrome

  • The clinical scenario and the classical USG finding of a spoke wheel appearance all suggest the diagnosis of ovarian hyperstimulation syndrome.

 

Ovarian hyperstimulation syndrome

  • Ovarian hyperstimulation syndrome (OHSS) is a potential complication of ovarian stimulation medications, such as human menopausal gonadotropin (hMG).
  • OHSS occurs when the ovaries become excessively stimulated, leading to the development of multiple ovarian cysts and an increase in vascular permeability.
  • This can result in the accumulation of fluid in the abdomen and chest.

 

Clinical features:

  • Abdominal pain & distension
  • Ascites
  • GI symptoms
  • Respiratory compromise
  • Oliguria
  • Hemoconcentration
  • Thromboembolism

 

Investigations:

Ultrasound:

  • Enlarged ovaries
  • Ovaries with multiple follicular cysts: Spoke wheel pattern
  • Ascites

 

Treatment:

  • Supportive management
  • Paracentesis for abdominal discomfort and respiratory distress
  • Fluid balance to prevent renal, hepatic, or pulmonary failure (monitor electrolytes)
  • Thromboembolism prophylaxis

 

Polycystic ovarian syndrome (Option B) is a hormonal disorder characterized by multiple cysts in the ovaries, menstrual irregularities, and symptoms such as acne, hirsutism (excessive hair growth), and weight gain. While both PCOS and OHSS can present with ovarian cysts, the sudden onset of symptoms after ovarian stimulation with hMG and the characteristic ultrasound findings make OHSS a more likely diagnosis in this case.

Theca lutein cysts (Option C) are a type of functional ovarian cysts that are associated with high levels of beta-human chorionic gonadotropin (hCG), which can occur in conditions such as gestational trophoblastic disease or multiple gestations. These cysts are typically bilateral and can be seen in cases of excessive hCG stimulation. The sudden onset of symptoms and the absence of risk factors for gestational trophoblastic disease or multiple gestations make OHSS a more likely diagnosis.

Granulosa cell tumours (Option D) are rare ovarian tumours that arise from the granulosa cells, which are responsible for producing estrogen. While these tumours can cause symptoms such as abdominal pain and hormonal disturbances, they are less common and usually not associated with ovarian stimulation medications.

questions.text: A man presents with dysuria and urethral discharge after having unprotected sexual intercourse. Gram staining of the purulent discharge is shown in the image. What is the treatment of choice for this infection?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Ceftriaxone + Azithromycin

Explanation:

  • The presence of Gram-negative diplococci in purulent urethral discharge suggests Neisseria gonorrhoeae, a common cause of gonococcal urethritis.
  • First-line treatment recommended by WHO is a single dose of intramuscular Ceftriaxone (500 mg) + oral Azithromycin (1 g) to cover both gonorrhea and possible Chlamydia trachomatis co-infection.

Urethritis

Etiology

Infectious Causes:

  • Neisseria gonorrhoeae (gonococcal)
  • Chlamydia trachomatis (nongonococcal)
  • Mycoplasma genitalium (recurrent urethritis)
  • Trichomonas vaginalis (protozoal)
  • Other: HSV, Treponema pallidum, Candida, Corynebacterium, Haemophilus influenzae

Non-Infectious Causes:

  • Irritants (soaps, spermicides, tight clothing)
  • Trauma (catheterization, instrumentation)
  • Menopause (low estrogen, atrophic vaginitis)

Clinical Presentation
  • Symptoms:
    • Dysuria (worse in morning, alcohol-exacerbated)
    • Urethral discharge (varies by pathogen)
    • Urethral pruritus, orchalgia (testicular pain in men)
    • Systemic symptoms rare (except viral causes)
  • Discharge Characteristics:
    • Thick, yellow-green → N. gonorrhoeae
    • Clear, white → C. trachomatis
    • Purulent/mucopurulent → M. genitalium

Diagnosis

Clinical suspicion in sexually active individuals with urethral symptoms.

Laboratory Tests:

  • Gram stain: Gram-negative intracellular diplococci (gonococcal)
  • NAAT (preferred): Detects C. trachomatis, N. gonorrhoeae, T. vaginalis, M. genitalium
  • Additional: Cultures, fungal KOH prep, NAAT for syphilis/HIV, pregnancy testing, wet mount for T. vaginalis (low sensitivity).

Alternative Methods:

  • MB/GV smear (similar to gram stain, sensitivity 97.3%)
  • Urethral culture (for N. gonorrhoeae resistance testing)
  • C. trachomatis suspected if pyuria present but no bacteria on stain/culture
  • M. genitalium confirmed only via NAAT (limited availability)

Emerging Pathogens

Haemophilus spp. increasingly linked to nongonococcal urethritis, especially with oral exposure.

Treatment

Indications for Antibiotics:

  • Positive gram stain/culture
  • Contact with an infected partner
  • Clinical urethritis without confirmed etiology if follow-up is uncertain.

Gonococcal Urethritis:

  • Ceftriaxone 500 mg IM (if <150 kg) or 1 g IM (if ≥150 kg)
  • If C. Trachomatis not ruled out: Add Doxycycline 100 mg PO BID x 7 days
  • Alternatives: Gentamicin + Azithromycin or Cefixime

Nongonococcal Urethritis:

  • Doxycycline 100 mg PO BID x 7 days (preferred)
  • Alternative: Azithromycin (multi-day better than single dose)

Persistent/Recurrent Urethritis:

  • M. genitalium suspected: Doxycycline 7 days → Moxifloxacin 400 mg PO daily x 7 days
  • If T. vaginalis suspected: NAAT confirmation or empiric Metronidazole 2 g PO

Special Cases

Pregnancy:

  • Azithromycin 1 g PO (preferred)
  • Alternatives: Amoxicillin, Erythromycin (varied dosing)
  • Avoid: Doxycycline, Quinolones

Resistant M. Genitalium: Moxifloxacin or Pristinamycin

T. vaginalis Treatment:

  • Women: Metronidazole 500 mg PO BID x 7 days
  • Men: Metronidazole 2 g PO single dose
  • Sexual partners must be treated to prevent reinfection.

Incorrect Options:

Erythromycin (Option A): Erythromycin is not effective against gonorrhea and is primarily used for Chlamydia infections in neonates (ophthalmia neonatorum prophylaxis).

Ciprofloxacin + Azithromycin (Option B): Fluoroquinolone resistance is widespread in N. gonorrhoeae, making ciprofloxacin no longer recommended for treatment.

Penicillin G (Option D): Penicillin-resistant N. gonorrhoeae strains are common, leading to the discontinuation of penicillin-based therapy.

questions.text: A primigravida presents to you with anaemia early in her pregnancy. She is 7 weeks pregnant, as seen on ultrasound. Her haemoglobin level is 9 gm%. When should the iron supplements be started for her?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) 8 to 10 weeks

  • The pregnant woman here is 7 weeks pregnant and has a haemoglobin level of 9 gm%, for which the treatment is oral iron therapy, and the best time to start is as early as possible, which is 8 to 10 weeks.

Anaemia management protocol for pregnant women

Target Group

Pregnant women registered for antenatal care

Screening and Periodicity

By health service provider at every ANC checkup

Degree

Of anaemia

First Level of Treatment

Follow-up

If No Improvement

Mild anaemia (Hb 10–10.9 g/dl)
  • Two Iron and Folic Acid tablets (60 mg elemental Iron and 500 mcg Folic Acid) daily, orally given by health provider.
  • Parenteral iron (IV Iron Sucrose or Ferric Carboxy Maltose) may be considered for late pregnancy or low compliance cases
  • Every 2 months for treatment compliance.
  • Discontinue treatment if Hb levels normalize, continue prophylactic IFA dose
  • Refer to First Referral Unit (FRU)/District Hospital (DH) if Hb <1 g/dl increases after one month of treatment. Further investigation and management with IV Iron Sucrose/FCM

 

Moderate anaemia (Hb 7–9.9 g/dl)
  • Two Iron and Folic Acid tablets (60 mg elemental Iron and 500 mcg Folic Acid) daily, orally given by health provider.
  • Parenteral iron (IV Iron Sucrose or Ferric Carboxy Maltose) may be considered for late pregnancy or low compliance cases.
  • Every 2 months for treatment compliance. Monthly Hb estimation. Discontinue treatment if Hb levels normalize, continue prophylactic IFA dose.
  • Refer to FRU/DH if Hb <1 g/dl increases after two months of treatment. Further investigation and management with IV Iron Sucrose/FCM

Severe anaemia (Hb 5.0–6.9 g/dl)
  • Managed by the medical officer at PHC/CHC/FRU/DH.
  • Treatment with IV Iron Sucrose/Ferric Carboxymaltose.
  • Immediate hospitalization in the third trimester is recommended at a higher facility.
  • Monthly or as prescribed by the medical officer
  • Follow treatment protocol as prescribed by the medical officer

Early initiation of iron supplementation at the start of 2nd trimester, 10 to 12 weeks (Option A) is preferred to ensure adequate iron stores throughout the pregnancy. But in the given scenario, the woman already suffers from iron deficiency anemia, and hence, the management is started as soon as possible, unlike in a normal pregnancy.

Delaying iron supplementation until after 14 weeks (Option C) would not be optimal for a pregnant woman with anaemia. Early initiation is preferred to prevent further decline in haemoglobin levels and to support fetal development.

Delaying iron supplementation until after 20 weeks (Option D) would not be ideal for a pregnant woman with anaemia. By this time, the woman may have experienced a further decline in haemoglobin levels, which can have adverse effects on both the mother and the developing fetus.

questions.text: A patient presented with high fever, altered sensorium, headache, neck rigidity, and seizures. He was diagnosed with HSV encephalitis. Which of the following tests can be used to confirm the diagnosis?

choices.text: CSF culture on chick embryo lines

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) CSF PCR for viral DNA

Explanation:
