  • Polymerase chain reaction (PCR) for HSV DNA in CSF is the gold standard for diagnosing HSV encephalitis due to its high sensitivity and specificity.

HSV Encephalitis
  • Herpesviruses: Large, double-stranded DNA viruses; 8 types affect humans (HHV-1 to HHV-8).
  • HSV Types:
    • HSV-1: Most common in adults & children; sporadic, non-seasonal.
    • HSV-2: More common in neonates & immunocompromised individuals.

Etiology
  • Causative Agents: HSV-1 (90%), HSV-2 (10%).
  • Structure: Enveloped, icosahedral, double-stranded DNA virus.
  • Host Cell Entry: Via nectin-1 and HVEM receptors on neurons.
  • Pathogenesis:
    • Primary infection: HSV infects skin/mucosa, enters neurons, and travels retrogradely to ganglia.
    • Latency: Controlled by immune mechanisms (histone deposition, cytokines).
    • Reactivation: Can spread to CNS via trigeminal or olfactory nerves.

Pathophysiology
  • Transmission: Close contact; HSV-1 → oral, HSV-2 → genital.
  • Brain Invasion Routes:
    1. Oropharyngeal infection → Trigeminal/Olfactory nerve spread.
    2. Reactivation in ganglia → CNS spread.
    3. Latent HSV in the brain reactivates.
  • Affected Areas: Temporal lobes, limbic system → hemorrhagic necrosis.
  • Immunosuppression Risks: Natalizumab, TNF-α inhibitors, whole-brain radiation.

Clinical Presentation
  • Prodrome: Fever, malaise, headache, nausea.
  • Typical Features:
    • CNS signs: Confusion, seizures, focal deficits, personality changes.
    • Behavioral syndromes: Hypomania, Klüver-Bucy, amnesia.
    • Other findings: Incontinence, dermatomal rash, Guillain-Barré syndrome.
  • Neonatal HSE:
    • Presents at 1–3 weeks with irritability, lethargy, poor feeding, tremors, seizures.
    • Herpetic skin lesions, thrombocytopenia, liver dysfunction may be present.
  • Immunocompromised Patients: Atypical/subtle presentation, fewer focal deficits.

Histopathology
  • Gross Findings: Hemorrhagic necrosis in medial temporal and inferior frontal lobes.
  • Microscopic Findings:
    • Early: Neuronal ischemia, capillary dilation.
    • Cowdry type A inclusions: Eosinophilic intranuclear inclusions in neurons.
    • Late (>3 weeks): Necrosis, gliosis, inflammation.
  • Atypical in Immunocompromised: Less inflammation, persistent viral antigens.

Evaluation
  • CSF Analysis (Gold Standard):
    • ↑ WBCs (lymphocytic pleocytosis), ↑ protein, normal glucose.
    • HSV PCR: 96% sensitive, 99% specific.
    • Repeat PCR if negative within 72 hours in high-suspicion cases.
    • HSV IgM in CSF is useful if PCR is unavailable or delayed.
  • Imaging:
    • CT: Initial test; may be normal early, later shows hypodensities, hemorrhage.
    • MRI (Best Test): Temporal lobe hyperintensities on T2/FLAIR, sparing basal ganglia.
  • Other Tests:
    • CBC, metabolic panel.
    • HSV PCR in blood useful in neonates & immunocompromised.

Incorrect Options:

IgM in CSF (Option A): IgM detection is not reliable for diagnosing HSV encephalitis because antibody production is delayed, and false negatives are common in early infection.

Tzanck smear of CSF (Option B): Tzanck smear is used for HSV skin and mucosal lesions but is not useful for diagnosing CNS infections. It detects multinucleated giant cells, which are not seen in CSF.

CSF culture on chick embryo lines (Option D): HSV culture requires human cell lines (not chick embryos), and CSF cultures are rarely positive in encephalitis. Culture is not a reliable diagnostic method for CNS infections.

questions.text: A pregnant woman comes to the GYN OPD with a positive UPT test result. She already has twins by normal delivery. Which of the following is the correct representation of her obstetric score?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) G2P1

In this case scenario,

  • G (gravida)- present pregnancy + twin pregnancy = 2
  • P (parity)- twin pregnancy =1

 

  • Hence, the obstetric score in this case is G2P1 as she has two total pregnancies and 1 delivery that completed 20 weeks of gestation.

The obstetric score includes:

Gravida

Denotes a pregnant state both present and past, irrespective of the period of gestation

Parity

Denotes a state of previous pregnancy beyond the period of viability(28 weeks)

Abortion

Number of pregnancies lost before 24 weeks

Living

Number of living children

Note: Twin pregnancy counts as one for both gravida and parity.

questions.text: A 27-year-old pregnant G3P2L2 woman presents at 36+6 weeks. The ultrasound shows the fetus in a transverse lie. The liquor is adequate, the placenta is normal, and she has no risk factors. Both her previous delivery were normal vaginal deliveries. How will you manage this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer B - External cephalic version

  • In the given scenario, the pregnant woman presents at 36+6 weeks with a transverse lie and an external cephalic version could be the appropriate next step in management to attempt to reposition the fetus for a potential vaginal delivery.

Management of transverse lie

  • Antenatal management: If there are no contraindications, attempt an external cephalic version (ECV) beyond 35 weeks for the transverse lie.
  • If Version Fails or is contraindicated: Elective cesarean section is the preferred delivery method.
  • Management in labor: In early labour, try an external cephalic version (ECV) if appropriate or opt for cesarean section if ECV is unsuccessful. In late labour, ECV is usually impractical due to ruptured membranes, so cesarean section is preferred in such cases.
  • Internal version considerations: Only for specific cases like managing the second twin.

 

Cesarean section (Option A) is a surgical procedure in which the baby is delivered through an incision in the mother's abdomen and uterus. While a transverse lie is an indication of cesarean section, it is not the first-line management option in this scenario. If possible, non-invasive and conservative approaches are preferred before resorting to surgery.

Expectant management (Option C) involves closely monitoring the patient and waiting for spontaneous changes in the fetal position or the onset of labour. However, in the case of a transverse lie at term, expectant management is not recommended due to the increased risk of cord prolapse and potential complications during delivery.

Induction of labour (Option D): The fetal head is not engaged in the pelvis, which means the baby is not in a favourable position for a safe vaginal delivery. Attempting induction could increase the risk of complications such as cord prolapse or obstruction.

questions.text: What should be the subsequent course of action in managing a patient who presents with fever and a positive filarial antigen test?

choices.text: Detection of microfilariae in the blood smear

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Detection of microfilariae in the blood smear

Explanation:

  • A filarial antigen test is highly sensitive but does not differentiate between active and past infections.
  • The next step is to confirm the presence of microfilariae in a peripheral blood smear, preferably collected at night (due to nocturnal periodicity of Wuchereria bancrofti).
  • Thick and thin smears with Giemsa or Wright’s stain are used to visualize microfilariae.

Diagnosis of filariasis

1.

Thick blood film
(Investigation of choice)

Nocturnal microfilariae are seen in blood between 10 PM to 2 AM

Lymphatic filariasis

Brugian/Malayan filariasis

Large, smooth (graceful) curve with countable nuclei

Small, kinked at an acute angle with a long head and uncountable nuclei

2.

Rapid Detection Test
  • Also called the filarial strip test
  • Used for monitoring, mapping, and evaluation activities

3.

Membrane filter concentration method
  • Most sensitive methods for detecting low-density microfilaraemia
  • Require specialized equipment.

4.

DEC provocation test:
  • A single oral dose of 100mg DEC followed by blood smear after 1 hour
  • Microfilariae can appear in the daytime.
  • Highest specificity

5.

Serological tests
  • Cannot differentiate between past and present infection

6.

Mass blood survey
  • Thick blood films for epidemiological Survey

Incorrect Options:

Bone marrow biopsy (Option A): Filarial infections affect the lymphatic system and do not require a bone marrow biopsy.

DEC provocation test (Option B): The Diethylcarbamazine (DEC) provocation test was historically used to stimulate microfilariae circulation, but it is rarely used today due to the availability of antigen detection tests.

Ultrasound of the scrotum (Option D): Ultrasound of the scrotum (for "Filarial Dance Sign" - movement of microfilariae in dilated lymphatic channels) is useful if scrotal involvement or hydrocele is present, but it is not the first-line confirmatory test.

questions.text: A woman presents to you at 36 weeks of gestation with complaints of breathlessness and excessive abdominal distension. Fetal movements are normal on examination, fetal parts are not easily felt, and fetal heartbeat is heard but muffled. Her symphysis-fundal height is 41 cm. Her abdomen is tense but not tender. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Polyhydramnios

  • The given clinical scenario points to the diagnosis of polyhydramnios, characterized by excessive amniotic fluid accumulation.

Polyhydramnios

  • In pregnancies without diabetes or hypertension, fetal anomalies such as anencephaly are commonly associated with polyhydramnios, occurring in about 50% of cases.
  • The excessive production of amniotic fluid can be attributed to:
    • Leakage from the exposed meninges
    • Lack of fetal swallowing reflex
    • Inhibition of fetal antidiuretic hormone, resulting in increased fetal urine output
  • It can be categorized as follows based on the Amniotic Fluid Index (AFI):
    • Mild: AFI = 25 to 29.9 cm
    • Moderate: AFI = 30 to 34.9 cm
    • Severe: AFI ≥ 35 cm

Causes

Polyhydramnios

Fetal Factors
  • Fetal anomalies (e.g., anencephaly, esophageal atresia) (Option A)
  • Twin-to-twin transfusion syndrome (TTTS)
  • Hydrops fetalis

Maternal Factors
  • Diabetes mellitus
  • Cardiac disease
  • Renal disease

Placental Factors

Chorioangioma

 

Abruptio placenta (Option A)refers to the premature separation of the placenta from the uterine wall before delivery. It typically presents with sudden onset of painful vaginal bleeding, abdominal pain, and a firm/tender uterus.

Hydrocephalus (Option B) refers to the accumulation of excess cerebrospinal fluid within the ventricles of the brain. It can cause an enlarged head circumference in the fetus and may present with additional symptoms such as macrocephaly, bulging fontanelles, and neurological signs.

Fetal-maternal ascites (Option D), also known as fetal hydrops, is a condition characterized by abnormal fluid accumulation in both the fetal and maternal compartments. Various factors, such as fetal cardiac abnormalities or chromosomal abnormalities, can cause it. While it can present with abdominal distension, it typically involves additional signs such as oedema, pleural effusion, or skin changes.

questions.text: A female presents to you with 6 weeks of amenorrhea, complaining of bleeding per vagina and slight abdominal pain. The urine pregnancy test is slightly positive, and the hCG level is 2800 IU/L. A mass is seen on the left adnexa measuring 3 x 2.5 cm. She is hemodynamically stable. How will you manage this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Single-dose methotrexate injection

  • The patient here is hemodynamically stable with an unruptured ectopic pregnancy with hCG levels <3000 IU/L and adnexal mass of size <4 cm; hence, the best method of treatment is medical management using single-dose methotrexate injection.

Management of Unruptured Ectopic Tubal Pregnancy

Management

Criteria/Indication

Description

Expectant Management
  • Beta hCG < 1,500 IU/L
    And falling subsequent levels
  • No significant symptoms
  • Strong likelihood of spontaneous resolution
  • Monitoring without intervention, relying on the natural resolution of the ectopic pregnancy.

Medical Management
  • Beta hCG < 3,000 IU/L
  • Adnexal mass < 4 cm
  • No fetal cardiac activity
  • Hemodynamically stable
  • Methotrexate (single dose/ multi-dose regimen) (best)
  • KCl (directly in sac)
  • Mifepristone
  • Prostaglandins

Surgical Management

(Option D)
  • Beta hCG > 5,000 IU/L
  • Size of ectopic > 4 cm
  • Presence of cardiac activity
  • Linear Salpingostomy (best)
  • Resection Anastomosis

Oral methotrexate (Option A) is not the preferred route of administration for this medication in the management of ectopic pregnancy.

Serial methotrexate with leucovorin rescue (Option C) is an option for the medical management of ectopic pregnancy, but it is typically used in cases where single-dose methotrexate is not successful or contraindicated. This approach involves administering multiple doses of methotrexate over several weeks, with leucovorin rescue given to counteract the side effects of methotrexate.

questions.text: A woman presents to you at 36 weeks of gestation with complaints of feeling lightheadedness and dizziness when she lies on her back. She says she feels alright if she lies on her side or when she walks. What is the most likely reason behind this?

choices.text: Excessive venous pooling at the feet

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) IVC compression (IVC- Inferior Vena Cava)

  • The symptoms of shortness of breath due to lying on her back imply a decreased cardiac output. It usually occurs in pregnant women due to compression of the inferior vena cava and aorta by the gravid uterus when lying in the supine position and is called supine hypotensive syndrome.
  • It leads to reduced venous return, decreased cardiac output, and hypotension.
  • It causes nausea, dizziness and shortness of breath.
  • This condition is relieved by shifting to a left lateral position.

Increased intracranial pressure (Option A): The fact that the woman feels fine when lying on her side or walking suggests that it helps alleviate the pressure on the IVC and improves blood flow to the heart and brain. This position promotes better circulation and reduces the risk of increased intracranial pressure and associated symptoms. Although increased intracranial pressure can cause this condition, it is less likely than IVC compression.

While heavy meals (Option C) can cause postprandial hypotension (a drop in blood pressure after eating), the woman's symptoms are specifically associated with lying on her back, indicating a different underlying cause.

Excessive venous pooling at the feet (Option D), such as in cases of dependent oedema, is unlikely to cause lightheadedness and dizziness, specifically when lying on the back.

questions.text: A partogram of a woman who is in labor is shown below. Oxytocin infusion is already given. How will you manage the condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Cesarean section

  • In the given scenario, the prolonged labor curve is beyond the established alert line on the partogram, indicating a lack of progress in labor due to cephalo-pelvic disproportion. This is a concerning finding and suggests the need for intervention as an emergency Cesarean section.

The above partogram also shows the following:

  • The cervix is fully dilated
  • Moulding is 2+
  • The station is 3+, and oxytocin infusion is already given
  • The uterine contractions are adequate
  • The amniotic fluid is stained with meconium, and there is a fall in fetal heart rate indicating fetal distress.
  • All these point to CPD and indicate an emergency C-section

Forceps-assisted delivery (Option A) is typically decided based on various factors, such as fetal distress or maternal exhaustion, and would require a specific indication beyond the information provided in the question.

Vacuum-assisted delivery (Option B) involves using a vacuum extractor to assist in the delivery of the baby. Similar to forceps-assisted delivery, the given information does not provide any specific indications for vacuum-assisted delivery.

Oxytocin infusion (Option C) is already mentioned in the scenario, indicating that it has already been given. Oxytocin is commonly used to induce or augment labour by stimulating uterine contractions. However, if the labor is not progressing despite the oxytocin infusion, it would not be appropriate to continue with oxytocin as the sole management option.

questions.text: A woman comes with complaints of pain and swelling in the perianal area. She also has complaints of difficulty in walking and sitting. She gives a history of multiple sexual partners. On examination, tender swelling is seen with redness on the labia, as shown in the image given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Bartholin abscess

The clinical features here of pain, swelling, redness, and a tender mass on the labia are characteristic of a Bartholin abscess. The Bartholin gland becomes blocked, leading to the accumulation of fluid and subsequent infection.

  • Bartholin cyst characteristics: Painless, smooth, cystic swelling in inferior labia majora or posterior vestibule near the fourchette.
  • Bartholin gland characteristics: Bilateral, 0.5 to 1 cm in diameter, located deep to vestibular bulb and bulbospongiosus muscle.
  • Complication: Infection can lead to abscess formation.
  • Common Pathogens: E. coli, gram-positive/negative aerobes, anaerobes.

 

Clinical Features:

  • Severe vulvar pain during walking, sitting, or coitus
  • Swelling
  • Erythematous and red swelling
  • Tender mass on the labia
  • Labial asymmetry (larger abscesses)

 

Treatment:

  • Symptomatic cysts (abscesses) are managed by incision and drainage (I&D), marsupialisation, or Bartholin gland excision.

 

Chlamydial infection (Option A) is a common sexually transmitted infection that can cause symptoms such as vaginal discharge, pain during urination, and pelvic pain. However, it does not typically present with a tender swelling on the labia, as seen in the image. Chlamydial infection is more commonly associated with urethritis, cervicitis, or pelvic inflammatory disease.

Genital tuberculosis (Option C) is a rare condition caused by Mycobacterium tuberculosis infection. It can present with various symptoms, including pelvic pain, menstrual irregularities, and infertility, but a localized, tender mass on the labia is more consistent with Bartholin abscesses.

Herpes infection (Option D) can cause painful blisters or ulcers in the genital area. However, in this case, the image does not show typical herpes lesions, such as vesicles or ulcers. Additionally, the presentation of difficulty in walking and sitting is not commonly associated with herpes infection.

questions.text: Please identify the manoeuvre being executed in the image provided.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: Option A) Head tilt, chin lift

Explanation:

  • The given manoeuvre is Head tilt and chin lift.

Head Tilt Chin Lift Maneuver:

  • The head is tilted back while lifting the chin upwards to prevent the tongue from obstructing the airway.
  • Used to open the airway in an unconscious patient without suspected spinal injury.

Jaw Thrust Maneuver: (Option B ruled out)

  • The lower jaw is lifted forward by placing fingers behind the angle of the mandible, moving the tongue forward and clearing the airway without moving the neck.
  • Used to open the airway in patients with suspected cervical spine injury.

 

Head extension (Optio C): It involves tilting the head backward but without lifting the chin. It is not as effective as the head tilt, chin lift for airway opening and is generally not recommended alone as a maneuver for maintaining a patent airway.

In-line manual stabilization (Option D): This technique is used to stabilize the cervical spine in patients with suspected spinal trauma, especially during airway management or intubation. The rescuer holds the patient’s head in a neutral position to prevent any cervical movement, which could worsen a spinal injury.

questions.text: Which of the following is the drug of choice for preoperative antibiotic prophylaxis in a patient undergoing cardiac surgery?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: Option D) Cefazolin

Explanation:

Cefazolin is a first-generation cephalosporin antibiotic commonly used for preoperative antibiotic prophylaxis in patients undergoing cardiac surgery. It works by inhibiting the growth and multiplication of bacteria that can cause surgical infections.

Penicillin G (Option A ): It isn't often used in cardiac surgery prophylaxis due to its limited spectrum of activity, which doesn't cover all potential infection-causing bacteria.

Erythromycin (Option B): It isn't commonly used in cardiac surgery prophylaxis because it's less effective than other antibiotics in preventing surgical infections.

Azithromycin (Option C): It isn't commonly used in cardiac surgery prophylaxis because it's ineffective against all bacteria that can cause surgical infections.

questions.text: When should the indicated position be used during resuscitation?

choices.text: Unconsciousness with pulse absent and breathing absent
Unconsciousness with pulse present and breathing absent
Unconsciousness with pulse and breathing present
Unconsciousness with pulse absent and breathing present

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: Option C) Unconsciousness with pulse and breathing present

Explanation:

  • The given position (Recovery position) involves placing the patient on their side with the lower arm extended and the upper leg flexed at the hip and knee. This helps prevent the tongue from blocking the airway and allows secretions to drain from the mouth. It can help to maintain an open airway and improve ventilation.
  • The given position is particularly useful in cases where the unconsciousness has been caused by alcohol or drug use, as these substances can increase the risk of aspiration (inhaling vomit or other liquids) and airway obstruction.
  • By maintaining an open airway, the given position can help to prevent these complications and improve oxygenation of the tissues.

Unconsciousness with pulse absent and breathing absent (Option A): This situation indicates cardiac arrest and requires cardiopulmonary resuscitation (CPR), including chest compressions and rescue breaths.

Unconsciousness with pulse present and breathing absent (Option B): This situation requires artificial ventilation to support oxygenation.

Unconsciousness with pulse absent and breathing present (Option D): This is a highly unlikely combination physiologically, as breathing is typically absent if the heart has stopped. If it were to occur, it would require immediate assessment and intervention, not the recovery position.
